webTitle: You say you want a revolution

fields.headline: You say you want a revolution
fields.standfirst: Guy Kawasaki helped turn Apple around. Now he's on a mission to bring venture capital to the masses.  Simon Caulkin listens in
fields.trailText: Guy Kawasaki helped turn Apple around. Now he's on a mission to bring venture capital to the masses. Simon Caulkin listens in
fields.body:
Guy Kawasaki is CEO of garage.com - CEO as in chief evangelist officer. This is a reference to his time at the ultimate Silicon Valley garage start-up, Apple Computer. As 'software evangelist' for the original Mac, Kawasaki became a legend for his ability to persuade developers to write software for a device that at that time had a processor that was 'too slow, had infinitesimal RAM, no hard disk, no colour, no expansion slots, no installed base' - and, apparently, not much future.

These days Kawasaki, 46, evangelises for a different cause. He wants radical, world-changing entrepreneurs like those who developed the Mac to set up their revolutions in his garage.

Garage.com's mission is, he says, to 'democratise the venture capital process'. By this he means that Silicon Valley's acclaimed capital allocation market has been distorted by its own success. At the top end, big venture capital funds have attracted so much cash that they will only invest in tranches of $10 million and up. They won't even look at a business plan unless it is introduced by someone they know.

At the bottom end, the three Fs (family, friends and fools) remain the first source of funds for most budding entrepreneurs. But in the middle there's a gap, inhabited by infant companies that need a first round of institutional money to complete a prototype, ship their first product and find customers. This is the gap garage.com aims to fill.

'What we're trying to do is foster a meritocracy,' Kaw asaki says. 'If you have a good idea and a good background, you too can be considered for funding. Unlike VCs, we look at every business plan that comes in - about 12,000 a year - and from those we select about 60 to take on as clients to help them raise funds.' In return, garage.com takes a small stake - much smaller than most VCs or incubators.

Does it work? Yes and no, says Kawasaki, who filed for an IPO in February, before the April stock market shake-out. Of the 50-odd companies garage.com has funded, to the tune of $130m, it has scored no runaway hits. On the other hand there have been two 'liquidity events', both acquisitions. And, '70 per cent of our companies are funded by VCs, and most are going on to further funding rounds' - not bad going, he thinks, for a year-and-a-half's work.

Unlike many start-up entrepreneur, Kawasaki admits that his job would be easier if the stock markets were riding high - at pre-April levels. But fortunately garage.com has another string to its financial bow: the 'bootcamp'. Bootcamp is a 48-hour primer for would-be entrepreneurs on how to start changing the world. In an atmosphere somewhere between a rock concert and a revivalist meeting, it brings together 500 to 700 would-be business revolutionaries eager to learn how to draw up a business plan (25 pages maximum), how to perfect an 'elevator pitch' (no more than the 30 seconds it takes to travel five floors), how to get venture capitalists to stump up the cash (ask for less rather than more so you can say 'I'm fully subscribed' - at which point others will demand to be let in).

A gifted performer, Kawasaki is by turns inspirational and self-deprecating. At a recent bootcamp in London, he harangued, cajoled and flattered his audience, his tales from the entrepreneurial front line striking a powerful chord. Revolution, he exhorts, is not a 20 per cent improvement in something that exists already, but a jump to the next curve - an eBay, Amazon or Yahoo!

But the revolution doesn't happen overnight. It's a process, not an event. So yes, ship a flawed product - like the Macintosh - but then test it and 'churn, baby, churn', migrating it to version 2.0, 3.0, 4.0 until it's good enough for the revolution to catch light.

Let a thousand flowers bloom. If people use your product for things you never intended, listen to what they are saying and adapt accordingly. Apple was delivered its saving niche not by its own efforts but by a strange new programme that did 'desktop publishing' - something Apple had never heard of.

Finally, pleads Kawasaki, don't let the bozos grind you down. The world is full of bozos, but they are not necessarily who you think. 'Often the bozos are successful in this revolution, but they're in denial about what will be successful in the next,' he says.

Tom Watson at IBM thought that the world market for the first generation of computers would be five; Digital's Ken Olsen opined: 'There is no reason why anyone would want a computer in their room'; and a certain successful PC revolutionary turned down the chance to interview for the job of CEO at an internet start-up called Yahoo!

That person, the speaker admits wryly, was Guy Kawasaki. Which is why he is now on the stump, urging his listeners in a Nineties reworking of Timothy Leary's Sixties mantra to 'get in, kick butt, cash out'. Be revolutionary, he tells them to thunderous applause: 'Get funded. Change the world.'

Kawasaki's 10 top lies told by entrepreneurs

1: Our projections are conservative.

2: Our market will be $50 billion by 2003.

3: Amazon.com will sign our contract next week.

4: Key employees will join us as soon as we are funded.

5: We have first-mover advantage.

6: We need you to sign a non-disclosure agreement.

7: Big retailers are too slow to be a threat.

8: We're glad the bubble has burst.

9: Our patents make our business defensible.

10: All we have to do is get 1 per cent of the market.

webTitle: My boss says I'm difficult at work

fields.headline: My boss says I'm difficult at work
fields.standfirst: My employer has been saying that I have been difficult to deal with and disruptive - allegations I firmly reject. As I am now seeking work elsewhere, I am worried this could affect my prospects. What can I do to get a retraction of these allegations? I am concerned about the attitude of my union, which also represents my manager.
fields.trailText: My employer has been saying that I have been difficult to deal with and disruptive - allegations I firmly reject. As I am now seeking work elsewhere, I am worried this could affect my prospects. What can I do to get a retraction of these allegations? I am concerned about the attitude of my union, which also represents my manager.
fields.body:
In disputes of this kind, it is often best to see how far you can go in sorting them out informally. The allegations are difficult to prove on both sides, and the situation can create more unhappiness if other employees are dragged in. It could be in your employer's interest to resolve the situation quietly.

Speak to your union and ask if they can do anything to mediate. If this is not possible, you could enter into formal grievance proceedings to air and resolve the issues.

Some employers do not ask for references, but you are right to be concerned.Your best way out may involve eating humble pie. When people are accused of being 'difficult', there is often a communications failure. If you could find out why these accusations have been made, you might be able to patch things up. A sensitive union official could play a role.

 Legal advice from HammondSuddardsEdge.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Wheels of fortune
fields.standfirst: What do you spend the most on in a year? Your home, or perhaps food? You're wrong, it's your car - and the costs are rising, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: What do you spend the most on in a year? Your home, or perhaps food? You're wrong, it's your car - and the costs are rising, says Maria Scott
fields.body:
Protests about petrol prices have dominated the headlines during the past week. But although motorists are outraged at the rise in fuel costs, few grasp the true impact these increases are having on their household budget.

A third of the UK's 23 million motorists have no idea what their cars cost them to run over a year, according to research by the AA. A further 53 per cent have unrealistic expectations of their outlay and tend to underestimate the cost by around half.

More than 50 per cent questioned in the AA survey thought that their motoring costs were less than £2,000, including 20 per cent who thought that they were less than £1,000. But in reality, the AA estimates that the British motorist spends an average of £3,600 a year to keep a car on the road - the last thing you will want to hear if you have just splashed out on an X registration car.

If anything, the AA's figures underestimate the full cost of running a car because they do not take into account the cost of financing the purchase. Interest on a £5,000 three-year loan will come to about £760 with even the cheapest of lenders adding another £250 a year to your costs in the first years.

The most recent figures from the Government's Family Expenditure Survey, the bible of personal and household spending in the UK, confirm that cars are taking a larger chunk out of our budgets. They are now costing more than food and housing. The survey says it costs an average of nearly £72 a week to keep a car on the road - which is almost identical to the AA's figure - up from £52 in 1996. Housing costs less than £68 a week and food less than £67.

Cars are becoming more expensive to run mainly because of the increasing costs of petrol and insurance. There were price increases of more than 17 per cent for petrol and 14 per cent for diesel in the year to March. Insurance has gone up by 14 per cent and is forecast by the AA and market research organisation Mintel to increase by up to 25 per cent again this year.

The AA's March report said that running costs for tyres, oil, servicing and other parts had remained fairly static, but the overall result was an increase of 3.11p in the cost per mile for a 1.4 litre car doing 10,000 miles a year. For an equivalent diesel car, the increase was 2.78p per mile.

And while servicing costs have remained static this is small consolation when set against the Office of Fair Trading's view that motorists are being horribly ripped off by garages.

Although motorists spend £9.5 billion a year on servicing and repairs, an extensive investigation by the OFT into the car repair business has found that poor workmanship has created 1.3 million problems a year, costing consumers £170 million.

However, the OFT says this could be just the tip of the iceberg and proposes setting up a task force of industry, consumer and government representatives to tackle the problem.

Amid the gloom there has been some good news for motorists recently. Prices of cars have been falling. This is partly because of competition from internet sales operations, many of which are ordering cars from the Continent where prices are up to 30 per cent lower. Motorists have also been travelling to the Continent to buy.

At the start of this month the Government imposed new regulations on car manufacturers aimed at forcing them to give the same discounts to dealers selling to individuals as those they offer to fleet buyers. This is one of the central planks in a Gov ernment campaign to force down the cost of cars in the UK.

There are doubts about how effective the move will be. The Consumers' Association has already criticised manufacturers for confusing buyers with an array of special offers and gimmicks rather than price cuts.

Nevertheless, there are signs that prices are coming down, even if only gradually. According to figures released by Alliance & Leicester bank at the end of last month, prices of new cars dropped by nearly 5 per cent in the year to the end of July, while one-year-old cars were down 17 per cent and three-year-old vehicles down an average of nearly 19 per cent.

While this is comforting for anyone planning to buy a new car, there is a sting. While prices continue to fall, depreciation adds to the costs of keeping a car. If you are borrowing a substantial amount of the purchase price, you may find that you owe more on the car when you sell it than it is actually worth.

Motorists' costs are now high enough to make people think about what sort of cars they buy, says Roger Higman, senior transport campaigner at Friends of the Earth.

A recent survey by Royal & Sun Alliance shows that 81 per cent of women and 68 per cent of men now rate fuel consumption as a significant factor when choosing a car (see table, page 4, for the most fuel efficient cars).

fields.headline: Two wheels cheap...
fields.trailText: Amid all the furore surrounding the costs of cars and trains, a third of us can afford to smile.
fields.body:
Amid all the furore surrounding the costs of cars and trains, a third of us can afford to smile.

Cyclists may be at greater risk of death and injury than other road users, but when it comes to cost, cycling wins hands down every time. Paula Smith used to commute by bus and tube to central London from Walthamstow at a cost of £21.70 a week. One day in July, the bus broke down. 'I'd had enough,' she says. In desperation she turned to her £150 runaround bicycle from her student days. After only a few weeks in the saddle, Smith has been converted. 'I worked out that I'm saving more than £85 a month.'

Peter Lewis, director of the London Cycling Campaign, estimates that, using a moderately priced £200 bike over four years, the cost of a 10-mile round trip Monday to Friday including maintenance and insurance is about £100 a year. This is equivalent to 4.2p a mile, compared with 46.87p per mile for cars of 1100cc and 79.94p per mile for those of 2000cc, doing 5,000 miles a year. Or about £2 a week compared with £21.70 for a weekly travel pass in Manchester, or £26.80 for a zone 1-4 travelcard on tube, train and bus in London.

Unfortunately bikes are easily stolen - half a million bikes are reported missing each year. For those wishing to avoid the risk of having to fork out for another bike, insurance is a must.

Your bike may be covered by your home contents policy. Steve Wilcox of Axa Insurance says bicycles are covered automatically under the company's home insurance policy up to a value of £400. 'This works out at £1.50 per £100 per year, including third-party liability,' he says.

While including your bicycle in the home contents insurance might initially be a cheap option, it could bump up your annual premium if you have to claim. The Cyclists' Touring Club offers standalone insurance, which works out, at most, slightly more than £10 a year for every £100 of replacement value. For those living in 'lower risk' areas premiums will generally be less - a bike with a £500 replacement value will cost £44 a year to insure. Call 0800 1695798 or visit www.cyclecover.co.uk to apply.

fields.headline: Rattle, dummy, pension
fields.standfirst: Now there's a new way to secure your baby's future, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Have you ever thought of buying a pension plan for your baby? No, don't turn the page. This might sound ridiculous but, if you have the money, it could be a very prudent move. And many parents and grandparents who have the available cash are likely to start doing it when it becomes possible for the first time next April.
fields.body:
Have you ever thought of buying a pension plan for your baby? No, don't turn the page. This might sound ridiculous but, if you have the money, it could be a very prudent move. And many parents and grandparents who have the available cash are likely to start doing it when it becomes possible for the first time next April.

The rules of the new stakeholder pension are 'great for your Highgate Socialists', says Charles Levett-Scrivener of independent financial adviser Towry Law. 'I'm expecting some parents who have some spare money and grandparents to do this.' Ian Johnson of Grant Thornton is also finding an 'enthusiastic' response.

Until now, such a move has not been possible. People have only been able to pay into a pension from their own earnings. But the stakeholder pension will allow people to contribute even if they are not in work. Although this relaxation is intended to help mature students, mothers on career breaks and other carers, it will also help the wealthy to provide for their non-working spouses, children, grandchildren and any other dependants. Stakeholder rules stipulate that a contract may only be opened for an under-18-year-old by a parent or guardian, but grandparents can pay for the contributions provided the parent/guardian knows about it.

The real benefit of a stakeholder pension is the tax break. There is tax relief, pegged at the basic rate (22 per cent), on contributions. The maximum annual contribution is to be set at £3,600. The way the system will work in practice, however, is that someone making a contribution will make the payment net of tax. So someone paying the maximum will pay in £2,808 (ie 78 per cent of £3,600) and the remaining 22 per cent (£792) will be added as a tax-relief top-up by the Government.

The ideal candidates to save for Baby George are the well-off. Johnson expects some clients will each year be putting money into pension plans for various non-working family members: 'If you are reasonably wealthy and have enough to pay your £7,000 into an ISA each year, you might also want to put in £3,600 for your non-working spouse or your children and grandchildren. You could end up with pretty substantial sums set aside.'

You certainly could. If you gave Baby George pension contributions, he could end up never having to make any himself. On the most modest estimations (assuming investment growth of just 1 per cent pa after inflation and charges), the 53-year old George would have accumulated £100,000 if you invested your £2,808 net each year for the first 18 years of his life.

And if you think George is likely to want to spend, spend, spend, you might decide that tying the money up in a pension was the best way of preserving your gift. If you took another possible route and used your annual ISA allowance to set aside the same sums, he might decide to blow the £71,000 (again assuming 1 per cent growth a year) which had accumulated for him at age 18 in, perhaps, three glorious years at university.

Of course, the irony is that the type of people likely to start pensions for children could be barred from the scheme themselves: people who earn more than £30,000 a year and who are already contributing to an occupational pension will not be allowed to take out stakeholder pensions.

On the most modest estimations (assuming investment growth of just 1 per cent pa after inflation and charges), the 53-year old George would have accumulated £100,000 if you invested your £2,808 net each year for the first 18 years of his life. And if you think George is likely to want to spend, spend, spend, you might decide that tying the money up in a pension was the best way of preserving your gift. If you took another possible route and used your annual ISA allowance to set aside the same sums, he might decide to blow the £71,000 (again assuming 1 per cent growth a year) which had accumulated for him at age 18 in, perhaps, three glorious years at university. Of course, the irony is that the type of people likely to start pensions for children could be barred from the scheme themselves: people who earn more than £30,000 a year and who are already contributing to an occupational pension will not be allowed to take out stakeholder pensions.

fields.headline: A world-class leap of faith
fields.standfirst: If you can invest for the long term, emerging markets may well pay dividends, says  Alexander Garrett
fields.trailText: The past few years have been frustrating for investors in emerging markets. First the Asian meltdown wiped out almost all the gains made in the Tiger economies during the previous few years, then the Russian crisis stuck the boot in. And last year, Brazil's devaluation threw a further spanner in the works.
fields.body:
The past few years have been frustrating for investors in emerging markets. First the Asian meltdown wiped out almost all the gains made in the Tiger economies during the previous few years, then the Russian crisis stuck the boot in. And last year, Brazil's devaluation threw a further spanner in the works.

To cap it all, the smart money was all being made in North America, on soaring hi-tech stocks. In the three years to 1 August the average emerging markets investment trust lost more than 20 per cent of its value; over seven years the return was a paltry 0.5 per cent. Among unit trusts the picture was not much better: an average loss of 16 per cent over three years and a 24 per cent gain over seven. But over the past 12 months, performance has improved greatly. With US and UK markets flat, and technology, media and telecoms shares heavily corrected, investors might be forgiven for thinking it could be timely to dip their toes back in the shark-infested waters of the world's developing economies.

To an outsider, investing in emerging markets must seem like buying a house in a grotty area in the hope it will come up in the world. It is not quite like that. Fund managers who do not focus solely on one country place their bets across a number of emerging economies, shifting the weight of their investment as progress speeds up in one corner of the world and slows down in another.

Ben Yearsley, investment manager at independent financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown, says emerging markets are for those with a long view. 'You should be planning to invest for at least five, probably 10 years or more,' he says. 'An ideal situation would be a grandparent who wants to make a monthly investment for a child towards an 18th birthday present.'

Probably not a good idea if you are about to retire, then, and most advisers would agree that you shouldn't tie up more than 5 per cent of your portfolio in these investments.

The fundamental reason for investing in emerging markets is that growth is expected to outstrip the developed markets. 'Everything points to the development of these regions,' says Yearsley. 'But it still takes a leap of faith. After all, 15 years ago who would have thought Taiwan would become the world's dominant microchip producer?'

Private investors should stick to vehicles with a global outlook, says Yearsley. In the year to 3 July, the best-performing stock market index was the Istanbul Composite, up 106 per cent; Manila on the other hand, was down a sobering 43 per cent.

Emerging markets in favour include the world's eighth largest economy, Brazil. Its 10 per cent devaluation in January last year sent shivers through the markets. But fund managers are bullish again. Jane Hakham at Beta Global Emerging Markets says: 'We have 15 per cent of our fund invested there, which is overweight. They are undergoing continuing reform. Interest rates are down strongly, and they have met all their International Monetary Fund targets. The currency is also quite stable. Foreign direct investment remained strong during the devaluation - a healthy sign.' Favoured sectors are telecoms, banks and retail.

With China's GDP up 8.2 per cent in the first half of the year, the country 'is looking better than at any time since the early Nineties', according to ABN Amro's chief global emerging markets strategist, Christopher Wood. By the end of the year, China is expected to be the world's largest market for mobile phones, with 70 million users. With a population of 1.25 billion, the potential is huge. Aberdeen Asset Management is reported to be planning to launch a China-only Isa later this year.

Investors are understandably cagey about Russia, given the way the market soared and crashed under the previous government. However, presi dent Vladimir Putin has been making encouraging noises. 'He's made a good start, particularly at reining in the oligarchies,' says F&C's McIlroy. 'There are companies there earning massive profits.'

Indian shares have had a good run, spurred by the booming software industry. Fleming Indian Investment Trust is the top performer in the emerging markets sector over one and three years, with a 77 per cent rise in the past 12 months alone. Be cautious though: some fund managers are still bearish about India.

This article is from the September issue of Money Observer, £3.50 from newsagents. For 12 issues at £31.97, a saving of £10, call 0870 1324 and quote reference MYIG002 .

webTitle: Renting pitfalls: lessons students must learn

fields.headline: Renting pitfalls: lessons students must learn
fields.standfirst: Rats in rooms and sharks in the high street can cause problems for the unwary.  Neasa MacErlean reports
fields.trailText: Over the next year, many students will get into difficulties over the rental agreements that they have recently signed. While moving into your own property for the first time can seem rather liberating, all too often it ends up feeling like a prison.
fields.body:
Over the next year, many students will get into difficulties over the rental agreements that they have recently signed. While moving into your own property for the first time can seem rather liberating, all too often it ends up feeling like a prison.

University housing officers can talk in their sleep about cases where students have not had their deposit back when the rental agreement is over. And there is a litany of other common problems for the 1 million students who each year sign on the dotted line: landlords who do not do the cleaning job that they agreed to do; the fellow student who drops out and leaves the other tenants to sort out the rent; the worries you may have because you have not seen your landlord's gas safety certificate; the huge electricity bill that arrives at the end of the year when no quarterly bills were received in the first 10 months; and then there are mites, bugs, mice and - if you are really unlucky - rats.

So what can you do to ensure that you do not come to rue the day that you moved in? You need to recognise that you are entering a potentially difficult world where you can minimise the likelihood of trouble if you do some homework first.

The rental market has long attracted the opportunistic and even the downright dodgy. If you sign up for the first property you see, you could find yourself paying over the odds. If you go to the first letting agency on the high street, you could find yourself in the hands of sharks. Signing a rental agreement is the first legal contract that many students enter into with such large financial repercussions. You need to read it, talk to family and other advisers about it and understand what you are agreeing to do.

'Students often don't realise what they are signing up to,' says an adviser in a university town. 'If you have a joint tenancy, signed by all the tenants, then they are all responsible for paying the money to the landlord even if - as happens frequently - one of them then pulls out.' The best practical solution is usually to find someone else to move in as quickly as possible.

Even parents and other members of the worldly wise do not always appreciate the legal ramifications. If a mother, for instance, signs her name as guarantor on her child's potential rental debts, she will usually find that she has thereby agreed to be guarantor on the debts of all the other people covered by that agreement.

The quality and pricing of the rental market varies hugely from town to town. In Leicester, for example, there is a glut of properties available and students are typically paying £35 a week for a room. In Brighton, where there is a shortage, students are more likely to pay £55 a week. Landlords in Leicester are so eager to market their properties that they often go to De Montfort University's student accommodation office to ask for advice. 'More and more landlords are trying to rent out properties,' says housing adviser Martin Clelow. 'The glut of properties available has meant that there has been very little increase in rents over the last couple of years.' Landlords will frequently provide a couple of fridges, a freezer, a microwave and a washing machine. They may be open to negotiation on issues such as individual contracts and how much students should pay in July and August.

In Brighton, the University of Sussex has seen rentals rise more than 10 per cent in the past couple of years as local house prices have pushed up rents. 'The sort of houses that students want are usually those with four or five bedrooms,' says Catherine Bancroft-Rimmer, a housing officer at the university. 'But there aren't enough to go round.' While letting agents in many other areas make their money by charging the landlords, agents in Brighton can usually squeeze something out of the students. Even the best known agencies are likely to charge more than £100 to each tenant they place and demand a 'holding deposit' of £200 on each property until the contracts are signed.

In places where there is intense competition for properties, students need to start looking well ahead. The University of Sussex starts making arrangements for autumn lets in February. Most universities run their own accommodation service, introducing landlords and tenants to each other. De Montfort is fairly typical in not visiting and vetting each property - but it does strike out landlords and letting agencies if it is disturbed by their behaviour. It recently blackballed a male landlord who kept turning up unannounced in a female household (where, under the regulations, he should have given at least 24 hours' notice). Another name struck off the list was the letting agency which would agree a rental premium with tenants but then start bartering with students over the deposit.

Deposits are a constant source of complaints. About half of all tenants say that some deposit money is unreasonably withheld, according to the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux (Nacab). The typical amount withheld in this 1998 piece of research was just over £300. A way to prevent this is to do a careful inventory with the landlord, since most deposits are withheld on the grounds that furniture has been damaged or cleaners have had to be brought in after the tenants leave. The University of Sussex recommends that students bring along a friend who can act as an independent witness when they inspect the property with the landlord just before moving out.

Many landlords often say at this stage that the property looks fine, but then write later to say that they need to pay to restore it to its previous condition. But if they have made their initial comment in front of a third party, they might then be less inclined to change their mind. Many students are now routinely withholding the final month of their rent because they expect their deposit to be withheld. As a result, many landlords are now asking for more than one month's rent as a deposit. In any case it is potentially a dangerous move to make since the tenants are in breach of contract.

Another major problem area is the landlord who does little to stop the fungus creeping up the kitchen wall or to fight off the rats. 'Put your request in writing,' says Bancroft-Rimmer. 'That normally gets the landlord to hurry up, and it is proof that you asked.' CABs will give help on this sort of issue and will, if requested, contact the local authority if it believes a property is 'unfit' for habitation. Landlords have to meet basic standards when they let out property. They are under legal obligations to get a gas safety certificate each year, for instance, and they also have to react quickly if they are told of other health-threatening developments.

But students also have to be wary of themselves. Many forget that they are, in most circumstances, directly liable to the electricity, gas and other utility suppliers. It is far better to sort a regular billing system at the start of the year rather than have a shock at the end. Running into trouble with the utilities may seem like a rather unimportant part of student life - but it assumes different proportions if it blights your credit rating at the start of your career.

webTitle: EMI to face the music on deal with Warner

fields.headline: EMI to face the music on deal with Warner
fields.trailText: UK music giant EMI will consider mounting legal action against the European Commission if its £14 billion merger with Warner Music is blocked, despite a series of eleventh-hour changes.
fields.body:
UK music giant EMI will consider mounting legal action against the European Commission if its £14 billion merger with Warner Music is blocked, despite a series of eleventh-hour changes.

Speculation was rife last week that the European Commission was going to block the deal on competition grounds. The Commission fears the deal would give the combined business, which itself is due to be folded into a new company formed by the merger of Time Warner and AOL, a dominant position in the recorded music market.

But both companies, having conducted lengthy legal audits about the consequences of the merger, believe they would have a strong case for appealing if the deal was blocked. The merger would mean there would be four instead of five major music companies but legal experts advising the two businesses suggest this would still allow sufficient competition to refute accusations that EMI/Time could collude over pricing.

They point to the legal challenge mounted by holiday giant Airtours after the Commission blocked its £950m bid for rival tour operator First Choice. If the deal had proceeded there would have been three powerful players in the European package holiday market.

However sources in both companies' camps believe that a series of last-minute amendments made over this weekend now present a much more compelling case for the proposed deal going through, albeit in a modified form. 'This is definitely not over. There's everything to play for,' one source said.

The two companies will submit their changes tomorrow before the Tuesday deadline. EMI and Warner's financial advisers were yesterday frantically putting together a number of revised proposals. The two have already tried to assuage the competition authorities' fears that they will attempt to dominate rival music companies by forcing them to sign exclusive carriage deals on AOL's networks.

EMI, meanwhile, has pledged that for three years it will not provide preferential access to its music to internet service providers allied to AOL/Time-Warner.

A draft document blocking the deal was circulated by the European Commission on Friday night, leading to speculation that the deal was dead. However EU Competition Commissioner Mario Monti later stated that no decision had yet been taken.

Experts said it was not unusual for the Commission to draft a negative decision which could then be used as a basis for negotiation.

fields.headline: How to  manage a crisis
fields.trailText: Look concerned, take action and make sure it looks like someone else's fault
fields.body:
1: Look concerned. Prime Minister Tony Blair adopted a suitably po-faced demeanour last week to demonstrate his understanding of the oil crisis. He avoided the mistake of one of his predecessors: a nonchalant Jim Callaghan, seemingly unruffled by a previous oil crisis, provoked the famous Sun headline 'Crisis? What crisis?' Similarly, Vladimir Putin has been slated by the Russian press for continuing his holiday during the failed Kursk rescue attempts last month.

2: Make sure it is somebody else's fault, advises James, a former civil servant. A long list of people are being blamed for the various Dome fiascos. A major leading the soldiers who were rescued this month in Sierra Leone is being disciplined for letting them be taken hostage in the first place. 'It's usually best to have one person to blame,' James adds, 'preferably someone who is intrinsically unpopular anyway.' This is why, for instance, politicians launch the occasional attack on fat cat barristers, suggesting that their greed is the reason why people cannot afford to go to law.

3: Take action and appoint people to carry it out. People will usually feel better trying to fight their way out of a situation than simply waiting for doom. One of the worst aspects of the Kursk disaster was the dithering that occurred before the Russians decided to ask for help from Norway and Britain.

In most crises, people will be reassured if the head of operations seems to have a clear action plan and sense of direction. You will usually help calm nerves if you keep others busy, too. This can create a positive feeling of teamwork - a far better background hum than frustration and hand-wringing.

4: Understand the huge impact of any information you give out. Panic buying and runs on banks are caused by a sudden eruption of fear among consumers. Last week's queues at petrol stations showed how quickly millions of people will act if they suspect a shortage of a necessity.

Information management was another grossly inept aspect of the Kursk story. Hopes were raised and then dashed when it was wrongly suggested that most of the crew could have survived after the first few minutes.

5: Learn as much as you can from the episode to prevent it happening again. Catastrophes often have the side-effect of increasing people's productivity and ingenuity.

webTitle: Great job - shame about the company ployer

fields.headline: Great job - shame about the company ployer
fields.standfirst: Finding out how employees feel is a case of asking the right questions - in the right way, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Finding out how employees feel is a case of asking the right questions - in the right way, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
More than a third of us would like to work flexible hours, and more than a quarter would like to work from home, according to a new survey on work-life balance published by the Department for Education and Employment earlier this month. Research from the TUC last week comes to similar conclusions: five out of six of us enjoy the job we do, but as a nation we are working long hours and feeling the strain.

The idea that a happy worker is a better worker may not exactly be novel, but it has been gaining currency of late. An increasing number of companies are endeavouring to measure and improve the satisfaction of their employees on an ongoing basis through that annual paper-filling exercise, the staff survey.

It may seem an obvious question, but why do employers want to know how satisfied we are at work? For service-oriented organisations, one answer is that there is a direct link between employee satisfaction and customer satisfaction, according to John Hughes, principal of the Customer Service Network. He says: 'When I worked at Birmingham Midshires building society, we had Mori survey every member of staff anonymously, and independently we had a programme measuring customer satisfaction. When we looked at the two sets of scores, we found there was a direct correlation: branches with happy staff scored well with customers, and vice versa.'

According to Mike Emmott, an adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, most large organisations routinely conduct a staff survey every year; small companies are far less likely to bother as they have a greater level of face to face contact. 'Managers may think they know what employees feel about their jobs, but in practice they don't ask these sorts of questions on a daily basis. So it's a way of deepening their understanding of employees.'

There is no prescribed formula for what an employer should ask. 'Are you satisfied with your work?' is a pretty obvious question, but others range from 'Do you feel secure?' to 'Do you understand the company's objectives?' and even 'How do you rate the level of clean liness in the washroom?'. Employers may well have an agenda of their own, for example to find out whether particular initiatives are working, or whether specific messages are getting through.

Karen Wisdom, associate director at Mori Employee Research, says one of her first steps when brought in by an employer is often to talk to employees and find out which issues should be included in the survey.

Nevertheless, workers faced with a questionnaire for the first time are often apprehensive. Wisdom says: 'You encounter a lot of suspicion and cynicism from staff. Mainly it is a fear of their anonymity being lost, and a suspicion as to the company's motives.' She has seen questionnaires deliberately defaced - in one instance a banana skin was sent through the post. Wisdom says that to allay any suspicions, it is vital for management to communicate what the survey is about from the outset. She believes that using an independent company such as Mori also removes fears about anonymity not being respected.

The most common failure with staff surveys, it is generally agreed, occurs when expectations are raised but the results are not acted upon. That may be because senior managers didn't buy in to the survey in the first place. If follow-up is minimal, it is much harder to get employees to take the survey seriously in subsequent years.

'If no action is taken, a survey can actually be counterproductive,' says David Tong, senior project director at International Survey Research. He says employers must also be prepared to share the main results with employees, although they may want to put some of the figures in context. For example, around 60-70 per cent of employees will typically say that they are satisfied with their job; but the number saying they are satisfied with their pay is generally around 40 per cent.

One reason for this may be tactical. If everybody says they are happy with their pay, it will not help when the annual pay rise is negotiated. But Mike Emmott says that evidence from national surveys, which are not com missioned by employers, is that long hours and the work-life balance are the biggest causes of dissatisfaction.

The rate of response to an employee survey may depend on the method used. Once, questionnaires would have been handed out in the workplace, or distributed in pigeonholes, but some employers now post them to home addresses. As well as ensuring that they receive it, this gives them a more relaxed opportunity to fill it in.

Electronic surveys are also gaining ground, mainly as a cost-saving mea sure. Usually this involves filling in a questionnaire on a website. But here employees may worry that their contribution is not anonymous: one way Mori has countered this is by allowing employees to take a randomly generated password before they enter the site.

But staff surveys do not always have to be anonymous. TNT Express Services offers employees a choice over whether to put their name on the questionnaire. Those who do are promised a meeting with a manager to discuss their feedback, which is a huge commitment for the company, but is regarded as a way of ensuring the process is taken seriously.

Chris Fowkes, TNT's director of quality, says: 'There are only a small minority who don't put down their names, and that may be because we have a very open culture here. Most of us have come up through the depots, and we don't have a blame culture.'

Last year, TNT received a 75 per cent response to its staff survey, with a remarkable 76 per cent of employees saying they were 'completely contented'. Some cynics will continue to believe that staff surveys owe more to public relations than to a genuine desire to improve things but unions, once hostile to the idea, are among those who have been won over. Ultimately, any voice, even an imperfect one, is better than no voice at all.

As Wisdom puts it: 'I still occasionally come across people who say: "I've been working here for 10 years, and nobody has ever asked me what I think of it".'

fields.headline: No headline
fields.trailText: Welcoming Kurt Masur to his post as its principal conductor, the London Philharmonic staged a day of events at the South Bank Centre. The Saturday concerts featured the London premiere of Thomas Adès's America alongside a performance by Alex Wilson's Latin funk-fusion octet, and collaborations with jazz pianist Herbie Hancock and world music supremo Youssou N'Dour.
fields.body:
Welcoming Kurt Masur to his post as its principal conductor, the London Philharmonic staged a day of events at the South Bank Centre. The Saturday concerts featured the London premiere of Thomas Adès's America alongside a performance by Alex Wilson's Latin funk-fusion octet, and collaborations with jazz pianist Herbie Hancock and world music supremo Youssou N'Dour.

This was a bizarre way to mark Masur's appointment. Masur is renowned as an interpreter of the central German tradition rather than as an aficionado of the acid-jazz scene. More to the point, the LPO is hardly known as a great exponent of world music or funk. It is famous, like Masur, for its performances of the standard orchestral repertoire.

Serge Dorny, the orchestra's artistic director, explained the musical melange as a reflection of the breadth of the LPO and Masur's tastes. However, a glance at the forthcoming season reveals programmes rigorously focused on the classical and romantic canons, especially those with Masur.

Still, as Dorny said, the LPO was in party mood. This presumably accounts for the alarming costume changes: penguin suits for "classical" Adès, faux-African shirts for N'Dour, and open shirts for Hancock. Sadly, this reflected the level of the orchestra's engagement with each musical style. The brilliant artistry of Hancock and N'Dour was reduced to a colourful parade.

There's a patronising side to this kind of eclecticism. Jazz and world music provided party numbers, unlike the "serious" work the orchestra usually carries out. This indifference to the integrity of other musical forms also backfired on the "classical" music on the programme. Adès's America - a terrifying vision of the violence underlying the American dream - was programmed next to a selection of Gershwin songs, featuring Willard White as soloist. So the power of America, representing contemporary classical music, was massively diminished, treated as a nasty, difficult piece to be got out the way before the popularity of Gershwin.

webTitle: Throwing away the car keys is no loss of freedom

fields.headline: Throwing away the car keys is no loss of freedom
fields.trailText: It is possible to live without a car - and prosper. When David Cresswell and his partner Gary Hall moved to Brighton three years ago from Reading they quickly realised that traffic jams and parking restrictions would be a regular feature of their lives unless they gave up their car.
fields.body:
It is possible to live without a car - and prosper. When David Cresswell and his partner Gary Hall moved to Brighton three years ago from Reading they quickly realised that traffic jams and parking restrictions would be a regular feature of their lives unless they gave up their car.

David says: 'When you arrive in Brighton you find that it can take an hour and a half to get to the centre. I applied for a parking permit, but it didn't guarantee a space. There were more people with permits than spaces. Three years later we still haven't heard about a permit.'

The fate of the couple's car was sealed when they bought a house in the centre of Brighton - within walking distance of both their offices.

David has since taken a new job as head of communications with the Financial Ombudsman Service and commutes by train to London.

But they have no desire to become car owners again and have been surprised at their savings. 'We thought we would be no worse off. We hadn't expected to be better off,' says David.

They lost money on the sale of their Volvo estate, but David says: 'The cost of servicing was enormous. Once or twice a year it would be vandalised in Reading so the cost of keeping it on the road was considerable.

'We made the assumption that travelling on public transport and hiring cars occasionally would be the same as owning a car but it is cheaper.'

They have calculated that their car was costing £2,500 to run, even though they had no financing costs. Now they spend £1,500 a year on trains, cars, buses and hire cars. This figure excludes David's season ticket, but he says he would have needed this even if they still had a car.

When Gary and David lived in Reading they drove to a supermarket to shop. 'There would be 20 bags in the boot,' says David. Now they shop as they need to, locally.

There are disadvantages. If they need to have large items delivered they are reliant on the retailer's delivery services.

David, however, has been unimpressed with the service from large DIY stores. They are expensive and inflexible, and David recalls the time he had to carry16 fencing posts back from Wickes up a hill.

webTitle: Tax aid for clean-up to revive the cities

fields.headline: Tax aid for clean-up to revive the cities
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is preparing a series of tax incentives to turn the tide against green field building and revive run down inner cities.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is preparing a series of tax incentives to turn the tide against green field building and revive run down inner cities.

Developers could be offered special allowances to clean up derelict land and renovate an estimated 1.3m empty buildings such as warehouses, it was revealed yesterday.

The regeneration package, being finalised by John Prescott's Department of the Environment and the Treasury, is the government's answer to recommendations by a task force led by the architect Lord Rogers of Riverside, which last year urged ministers to provide tax incentives for developers and councils in special urban priority areas to encourage the rebirth of cities.

The chancellor this week met Lord Rogers to outline his plans after the architect called for the government to move "faster and further" towards an urban renaissance.

Yesterday Ed Balls, chief economic adviser to the Treasury and Mr Brown's chief aide, told leaders of England's seven main cities at their annual conference that November's pre-budget statement would herald a big urban initiative.

Mr Balls said in Sheffield that the government would go further than the Rogers recommendations in promoting better land use and regeneration.

With an urban white paper due to be published alongside the statement, and Mr Prescott's officials working on new measures to reform town hall finances, ministers could offer special zones, free of business rates, to bring developers into depressed urban areas. Cuts in corporation tax, capital allowances and bolder measures to recycle old industrial, or brown field, land are also being considered.

The Treasury's announcement yesterday coincided with a report from academics in Cardiff which revealed that England's main cities are badly under-performing on the economic and jobs front.

Analysing the economic competitiveness of cities with a single index measuring the wealth of individuals, average earnings, unemployment rates and "knowledge based" business the report by consultants Newidiem says none of the cities - Birmingham, Liverpool, Leeds, Manchester, Newcastle, Sheffield - or their surrounding boroughs are performing above the UK average. Only one, Bristol, is doing relatively well.

Robert Huggins, director of research at Newidiem said: "Our findings provide further proof of the existence of a north-south divide in economic competitiveness in the UK. It is clear that the majority of the urban areas of northern England do not possess the competitive advantage of their southern counterpart."

London and the south is at the top of Dr Huggins's "city competitiveness index" alongside Aberdeen and Edinburgh. Many northern cities languish at the bottom of the list of 42 cities.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, speaking after the conference, maintained that the north-south divide remained "stark".

Parting company with the standard government line that differences within regions are wider than any north-south divide, Mr Blunkett said: "You have got major areas of deprivation in every part of the country ... some London authorities are very badly off ... but the scale of the problem in the major cities is very different."

While in his home city of Sheffield one area was very affluent "two thirds are not and that is the problem ... the scale, the number of people affected is such that you have to have special measures".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: MInd the bump | Northern chain | Into the woods
fields.body:
MInd the bump
One in 10 passengers have been bumped off flights in the past 12 months, including a third of regular travellers who have made five or more trips abroad, according to a new survey by American Express. Almost half of those bumped were not satisfied with the level of compensation they received. American Express has launched a new look Green Charge card which includes "Bump Insurance". Customers can charge £100 for meals and refreshments to their Green Card if they are taken off a flight. After six hours, they will be given the option to stay in a hotel of their choice up to the value of £300.

Northern chain
The latest section of the National Cycle Network to open is a 135-mile stretch connecting the Tyne, Wear and Tees Valleys, known as the Three Rivers Cycle Route. Starting in Middlesborough, the route takes in Durham and Newcastle. Maps are available for £5.99 plus £2 p&p by calling 0117 9290888.

Into the woods
The Woodland Trust, the UK's leading woodland-conservation charity, has launched a project to encourage people to visit and appreciate ancient woodland. Information on 01476 581135 (www.wildaboutwoods.org.uk ).

Portland bill
Portland Direct is publishing its competitors' prices in its own brochure. Airtours, First Choice, JMC and Direct Holidays are included. Portland claims to have the lowest prices. Phone 0845 7951000 for a brochure.

Marrakech express
Royal Air Maroc is adding a third weekly flight from Stansted to Marrakech from November 3. There will now be flights on Thursday, Friday and Sunday. For details, phone 020-7439 4361.

Fire warning
Fire safety in hotels has improved but there is still some way to go before holidaymakers can rest easy, according to the latest investigation by Holiday Which? out this week. Experts were sent to inspect 60 hotels in Majorca, Rhodes, and Rome and only five failed. These were the Napoleon and the Venezia in Rome and the Dionysos, the Grand and the Esperides Beach in Rhodes.

Channel giant
Brittany Ferries is building a giant £70m cruise ferry capable of carrying up to 2,200 passengers and nearly 800 cars, and with 2,250 metres of lane space for freight. It will operate on the Portsmouth-Caen route from spring 2002.

fields.standfirst: Your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.trailText: Hong Kong | New York | Paris
fields.body:

fields.headline: Aesthetic pursuits
fields.standfirst: Art connoisseur  Sir Roy Strong keeps fit by jogging along the byways of Herefordshire
fields.trailText: Art connoisseur Sir Roy Strong keeps fit by jogging along the byways of Herefordshire.
fields.body:
Every day at 10 minutes past noon a lean, lugubrious-looking man in his 60s with long hair and a moustache emerges in running clothes from his formal, well-clipped garden near the village of Much Birch and sets off on a steady jog through the rolling countryside of Herefordshire.

This is Sir Roy Strong, aesthete and author, escaping from the cocoon of work and study to immerse himself for three quarters of an hour in a bigger world of sky and hills, woodland and streams and time-worn buildings. Without it, he says, he'd turn into a complete toadstool.

"I just put my jogging things on and do the circuit, and then I can feel my body move, I'm breathing, I'm looking at the countryside, and I just feel everything fall away," he says. "It's wonderful because one's subconscious takes over. You switch to another part of your mental make-up.

"I find I'm just looking and observing and absorbing the air and the landscape. And I don't ever regard it as irksome - if I don't do it, I miss it terribly."

The circuit begins along a hedged lane, then forks left for a dramatic descent into the valley of Wriggles Brook, which runs into the nearby River Wye. Here Sir Roy takes the brakes off and hurtles down towards the cottages and gardens at the bottom.

The road then climbs over the shoulder of a hill which gives dazzling views across the rugged landscape, crosses a rushing stream, passes an old black-and-white timbered farmhouse and comes to the pièce de résistance - the church at Hoarwithy, sitting high on a knoll.

"It's like a little bit of Sicily, with a kind of cloister and a tower - this extraordinary late 19th-century church up on the heights with a wonderful little rectory next to it. Some local worthy obviously had an enormous amount of money and lavished it on this magnificent building, almost in the middle of nowhere."

In the chancel, white marble columns support a dome with a golden apse and a mosaic depiction of Christ as the ruler of the world. The pulpit and altar are also white marble, inlaid with green marble, porphyry, lapis lazuli and tiger's-eye.

After this treat, he might detour for a look at the River Wye, but usually he takes a right turn and heads for home. The lane climbs, falls and climbs again through the cider apple orchards, and goes near a battery chicken farm to which Sir Roy objects because he's virtually vegetarian - "although I still eat Parma ham".

Sometimes he gets home without seeing anyone, but more often he meets cyclists or people on horseback, and occasionally has to jump out of the way of outsize farm machinery. His most regular encounter is with an elderly lady out for her daily walk, with whom he exchanges smiles and greetings.

"I've seen this circuit in every season because I do it all year, and you see the leaves come and go, and the hips on the wild roses and the berries on the honeysuckle, the primroses and the lilies and the whole cycle of the wild flowers, if they haven't been massacred by the local authority.

"I love doing it, and I may just pause and walk a bit if I see something in the hedge. If I see blackberries, I can't resist stopping and picking a handful and popping them in my mouth. Or if a dog rose or the honeysuckle is particularly beautiful, I like to poke my nose into it and smell it."

Spring is his favourite season, when he can shed his tracksuit and watch the lambs bouncing around in the fields.

"But I do it all through the winter, I don't mind going out in the rain, and I just observe it as a disclpline of life. I have this firm belief that you have to make a own contribution to your own health."

Sir Roy first started doing regular exercise at the age of 43, and now regards himself as "the master of the eight-minute mile".

His own parents could hardly get out of their chairs at his age, he says, but he's hoping to run for at least another 10 years: "My father-in-law was a great example to me - even when he was 83 or 84, he would always put on his coat every day and go out for a walk."

The practicals

Principal rail stations in Herefordshire are at Hereford, Leominster and Ledbury: National Rail Enquiries 08457 484950. For information about accommodation, transport and local walks, ring Herefordshire Tourism on 01432 26062. Long-distance walks include the Marches Way (204 miles) and the Wye Valley Walk (111 miles). Best map for Roy Strong's route is OS Explorer (approx 2 inches to 1 mile) 189 (Hereford and Ross-on-Wye), £5.50. See also OS Landranger (approx 1 inch to 1 mile) 149 (Hereford and Leominster), £5.25.

 The Artist and the Garden, by Roy Strong, is published by Yale University Press, £29.95.

fields.headline: Roving reports
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor looks for more in-depth articles on the web
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor looks for more in-depth articles on the web
fields.body:
Writing about travel for the web is a difficult matter. There's little time to evoke a sense of place and many of your readers are more interested in finding restaurant and hotel recommendations than engaging with an essay, however compelling. Some of the sites below reproduce print articles, while others are special to the web; they tend not to list the practicalities, but look at places in a slightly oblique fashion.

Salon
The online magazine Salon used to host the best travel journalism on the web. Sadly, the Wanderlust section is no more and visitors have to content themselves with an archive search. It's still the best place to look for this particular brand of impressionistic reportag though.

Al Mashriq - the Levant
Probably the most fascinating collection of travel writing, history and background information anywhere on the web, Al Mashriq is a celebration of the Levant region - Turkey, Syria, Jordan, Israel, Palestine and especially Lebanon.

New York Times
Readers of the NY Times online must register. It's worth the trouble in order to access some well written and solid - if slightly unadventurous - travel writing.

Time Photo Essays
World events as seen by the US. Although pictures of the presidential candidates dominate these essays, others - such as Anthony Suau's tour of the former Soviet bloc - look further afield.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Tepoztlán

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Tepoztlán
fields.standfirst: Judith Miller
fields.trailText: Judith Miller
fields.body:
Why: Tepoztlán is an ancient town north of Mexico City, on a plateau surrounded by mountains. It only has one main street, but it is the most magical place because it has 600-year-old pyramids dotted on the mountains - apparently, they have perfectly equal sides, down to a millimetre. In Mexico, there is a wonderful juxtaposition between ancient civilisation and modernity. You are constantly reminded of the past but also of the present and the future. So, as well as these pre-conquest pyramids and a 16th-century monastery, there is some brilliant modern architecture. In short, it is a distillation of Mexico's past, present and future with beautiful shapes and pink and orange colours.

I went last year and stayed in a little parador. It was incredibly still and I had the most amazingly vivid dreams. The indians say that it is due to the mineral wealth of the mountains, but I think it might either be because you are high up or because of the contrast between the pollution of Mexico City, the clean air and being so stimulated by the colours.

What's the best thing? Sitting in the town, you can look up to the pyramids on the mountain and take in the old from the new.

My advice: Stay in a local parador. Walk through the streets at dusk. The shapes, the sounds and the colours are so vivid against the presence of the mountains.

How do I get there? Journey Latin America (020-8747 3108) offers return flights with American Airlines to Mexico for £309 plus taxes from October through to the end of November.

 Colour by Judith Miller is published by Marshall at £25. Founder of Miller's Antiques Price Guide, she appears on BBC2's The House Detectives in November.

webTitle: Bookshop of the week: Inntravel T-Shop

fields.headline: Bookshop of the week
fields.standfirst: Inntravel T-Shop
fields.trailText: Inntravel T-Shop
fields.body:
Hovingham, York
YO6 4JZ
01653 629000
www.inntravel.co.uk

Not a book, this week, but a whole stack of them, and in a most unusual setting. Going on holiday in order to plan your holiday might seem like an indulgence too far, but a cappuccino or two at the Inntravel T-Shop - a travel bookshop, travel agency and coffee shop in a picturesque village outside York - should change your mind.

The specialist tour operator has been based at Hovingham, 20km north of York, for 15 years. Now they have converted a swish coffee-house and bookstore into the T-Shop that would not look out of place in downtown San Francisco.

A wide collection of travel guides, maps, travel writings and novels is available for browsing, alongside a lunch menu inspired by the cuisine of France, Catalonia, Norway and other areas covered by the travel agency.

With easy access to the North York Moors and Castle Howard, the T-Shop is probably best visited during a walking holiday or daytrip, though it's also a brief drive from the tourist honeypot of York itself. You can book an international holiday with the help of the specialist staff on hand. But, then again, you could just sip your coffee, peruse a book and fantasise. If only all bookshops, coffee houses and travel agencies were like this.

fields.headline: Leatherman
fields.trailText: It's a multi-tool, with everything from pliers to a ruler in a single pocket-sized implement.
fields.body:
Something to do with motorbikes? No, it's a multi-tool, with everything from pliers to a ruler in a single pocket-sized implement.

What's it got to do with leather? Nothing. Except that it was conceived by Tim Leatherman from Portland, Oregon, after a European backpacking trip in 1975.

What was his problem? Frustration with ordinary pocket knives - even the ones with built-in tools.

Why? Not strong or versatile enough - and nothing you can really get a grip with.

Hence the pliers? They're the heart of it: full-strength, stainless steel, needlenose jobs. It took him eight years and dozens of prototypes before he launched the Pocket Survival Tool.

And since then? Lots of different versions, many imitations and a steady growth of multitool sales. Even the makers of Swiss Army knives now do them.

The most popular Leatherman? The Wave. It's got the pliers, two knives, five screw drivers, and eight other fold-out features including the vital can opener.

Pricey though? £89.95. Cheapest is the Micra at £26.95, built round scissors. For stockists call 01539 721032.

What's the alternative? A full-sized tool kit; wrecking the cutlery on that loose screw.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: * Tina Woods and her husband are looking for seasonal work in Greece, Spain or anywhere hot.
fields.body:
* Tina Woods and her husband are looking for seasonal work in Greece, Spain or anywhere hot.

My brother found a job in Spain working at an adventure holiday resort. He got the information from a site called www.workandtravel.com. They have information about jobs all over Europe and specialise in seasonal and temporary work. You can apply online for as many jobs as you like using one application form in the Back Pack section.

fields.headline: Unchartered territory
fields.standfirst: Where will be big next year? Brazil because major tour operators are moving in, Bali because it is a safe haven in a turbulent region, and the Languedoc because it is the latest new Provence.  Paul Masters  takes a look at what's happening in Brazil
fields.trailText: Where will be big next year? Brazil because major tour operators are moving in, Bali because it is a safe haven in a turbulent region, and the Languedoc because it is the latest new Provence. Paul Masters begins a six-page special with a look at what's happening in Brazil.
fields.body:
Brazil is the sleeping giant of global tourism. It is the world's fifth largest country, has the world's largest rainforest (the Amazon), the world's largest swampland (the Pantanal), thousands of miles of tropical beaches, and an enviably rich musical, culinary and architectural heritage.

Just the sort of place, you might think, to go on holiday.

But Brazil has never fulfilled its potential. It is a baffling statistic that tourists travel in far greater numbers to Argentina, which is several hours further away by plane and offers arguably less variety of activity.

The last available figures show that in 1998 4.8 million visited Argentina, compared to 3.1m for Brazil. Britons, too, prefer Argentina to its larger, northern neighbour.

Brazil's consistent state of underachievement can, in part, be explained by its poor infrastructure, itself partly the result of its own vastness. There is also the perceived threat of violence in cities such as Rio de Janeiro. And it doesn't help that in Brazil people speak Portuguese instead of the more visitor-friendly Spanish.

However, this year the giant has begun to stir. A mixture of unconnected factors, such as the country's 500th anniversary of its sighting by Portuguese sailors and the rise of the supermodel Giselle Bundchen, have generated a new wave of international interest.

This month sees the launch of a tourist resort near the north-eastern city of Salvador that aims to be the first major package destination for European and north American travellers. Tour operator Unijet is offering packages to Brazil for the first time next year.

Without a doubt, the Costa do Sauípe resort is causing travel companies to look at Brazil through different eyes. Airtours will next year begin direct flights to Salvador from Gatwick in order to service the resort. At present, all scheduled flights come into the country via the business centre São Paulo, adding several hours to most tourists' journeys, so the Airtours flight will be opening up a part of Brazil previously only known to committed travellers.

Salvador and the Costa do Sauípe are both in Bahia, a state the size of France that has a diversity of attractions - from colonial cities to fishing villages, from deserted beaches to spectacular canyons. It is waiting to be explored.

An hour's drive north of Salvador's international airport, Costa do Sauípe is an ambitious attempt to build a Cancun-style resort.

The builders claim it is the largest tourism development in South America. So far it has cost more than £120m and includes two five-star and three four-star hotels. Capacity is 4,000 rooms, although this will be expanded to 10,000.

Costa do Sauípe is situated in a beautiful and hitherto-undeveloped stretch of coastline. The emphasis from the beginning has been on pre serving the ecosystem as much as possible. During construction, the builders relocated 32,000 plants and 586 animals, including a rare sloth.

One part of the resort is designed in the colonial style of the old town in Salvador. Special hybrid grass was developed for a golf course that the managers hope will eventually attract a leg of the PGA tour.

The resort offers sports such as tennis, beach activities, nightlife and shopping facilities. There will also be concerts of Bahian music and other demonstrations of Brazilian culture.

The Costa do Sauípe information line is on 00 55 71 354 9696. English is spoken.

Salvador was the first capital of Brazil. It was also the main arrival port for slaves being imported from the Portuguese colonies in Africa. As a result, it has the highest proportion of black people in Brazil and, not unnaturally, is the centre of Afro-Brazilian culture.

The old town is a square mile of cobbled streets, colonial buildings and baroque churches. At night, restaurants spill out on to the pavement, bands play live music and groups of drummers march through the streets. Every night is good, although Tuesday nights and weekends are busiest.

During one week at the end of February, Salvador is home to the most exciting carnival in Brazil. Millions of people follow floats around three circuits all through the day and night. The atmos phere is so hedonistic that it is virtually impossible not to have a passing amorous fling.

Salvador is also the best place to sample Afro-Brazilian cuisine. The fish and seafood stews should be gulped down with a ice-cold rum-and-coconut cocktail.

A popular and cheap hotel is the Hotel Pelourinho (00 55 71 243 2324), which is in the centre of the old town. An option near the centre but by a beach is the Marazul (00 55 71 264 8200).

Traditional restaurants for Bahian food include Bargaço (00 55 71 231 5141) and Yemanjá (00 55 71 231 5770)

A 20-minute flight in a tiny plane from Salvador airport takes you over the Bay of All Saints to the island of Tinharé. The only real settlement is Morro de São Paulo, a small village that is the favoured destination for Bahia's monied classes. The beaches at Morro de São Paulo can get quite crowded but a short boatride away you can find miles of deserted sand.

The only means of transport on the island is by tractor, which will meet you off the plane and trundle you along the beach to your hotel.

If you prefer to avoid the crowds altogether, half an hour away on a motorboat is Boipeba, which has a handful of places to stay and is blissfully tranquil. Like most of the other beaches in Bahia, the sea at Boipeba is particularly warm and clear.

At Morro de São Paulo, the best equipped place to stay is the Villegaignon Resort (00 55 75 783 1010). On Boipeba, try the Pousada do Outeiro (00 55 74 9972 1535).

Flights can be booked with AeroStar at Salvador airport (00 55 71 204 1335). The return fare is about £60.

Ilhéus is the town that chocolate built. The centre of Brazil's cocoa-growing region, it used to be one of the most prosperous cities in South America. Its residents built themselves a belle-époque town hall and a neo-classical cathedral.

It still produces cocoa but has been overtaken by Africa in terms of the level of production and the city is inhabited by poor workers rather than chocolate barons. Yet it maintains a decadent charm and is worth a visit.

There are nice beaches in the city and nearby, but chocolate remains the reason to come here: for the Cocoa Museum or the chance to see a cocoa plantation in the surrounding countryside.

Porto Seguro means "safe port", and it was here that the Portuguese dropped anchor in April 1500. As a result, it became the focus this year for Brazil's 500th birthday celebrations, together with demonstrations by indians who, for obvious reasons, claimed it was anything but a reason for rejoicing.

The first place where the Portuguese stepped ashore was at Coroa Vermelha, around 10 miles north of Porto Seguro. The area is now owned by the Pataxó indians but can be entered without permission. A metal cross stands a few metres from the shore to mark the place where the first mass is reputed to have been held on the South American continent.

Between Porto Seguro and Coroa Vermelha, the coast road is lined with cheap hotels. Driving south from Porto Seguro, the road turns into a dirt track and leads to Arraial d'Ajuda and Trancoso, which hip and hippyish travellers have turned into Brazil's equivalent of Thailand.

Slightly further south, the impressive Monte Pascaol completes the sights of the heavily-marketed "Discovery Coast" - history records that the mountain was the first piece of land spotted by the sailors when they stum bled upon Brazil.

There is no shortage of places to say in Trancoso and Arraial d'Ajuda, both of which are more laid-back than Porto Seguro. Try the Pousada Verde Agua (00 55 73 875 1453) on the beach at Arraial.

Bahia, like Brazil in general, has its population and industry concentrated along a thin coastal strip. Inland, you get a completely different picture: much less developed and full of open spaces. If you only go to one place away from the coast, go to the Chapada Diamantina national park, a stunning area of canyons, caves and waterfalls. It is one of Brazil's main adventure tourism destinations and offers mountain-biking, horse-riding, caving, abseiling and trekking.

The scenery is untouched and the small colonial towns are not as yet overrun by karabiner-wielding athletes, so one can enjoy the natural beauty and tranquility at ease.

The Chapada has a reputation as a magical place that has enchanted many foreign visitors. Jimmy Page, the former Led Zeppelin guitarist, has a house in Lençóis and his image adds to the laid-back, tree-hugging vibe.

Flights to Lençóis go from Salvador and cost from £60 return (Nordeste 00 55 21 507 4488). A good option for a hotel is the Canto das Águas (00 55 75 334 1154). There are several agencies offering guides and equipment.

The practicals

Airtours (0870 9008639) flies direct to Salvador from Gatwick in nine hours. Packages start from £599 per person. Unijet (08705 336336) offers flights from £399 and two-week holidays from £669. Other tour operators that feature Brazil include:

Cox & Kings (020-7873 5000)

Exodus Travel (020-8675 5550)

Explore Worldwide (01252 760000)

Guerba Expeditions (01373 826 611)

Journey Latin America (020-8747 8315)

Last Frontiers (01296 658 650)

Nomadic Thoughts (020 7604 4408)

Trips Worldwide(0117 9872626).
