fields.headline: Experience of a lifetime
fields.standfirst: Every music legend deserves a good pilgrimage. Kicking off our three-week series, Jimi Hendrix fan  Hugh Clench  visits the state-of-the-art museum inspired by the guitar hero who died 30 years ago
fields.trailText: Every music legend deserves a good pilgrimage. Kicking off our three-week series, Jimi Hendrix fan Hugh Clench visits the state-of-the-art museum inspired by the guitar hero who died 30 years ago.
fields.body:
If, like me, you are old enough, and committed enough, to have seen Jimi Hendrix play live more than once, then you'll know the significance of September 18 1970. It was 30 years ago on Monday that Jimi was found dead by his girlfriend, Monika Dannemann, in their London flat.

If, unlike me, you are one of the world's richest men, then you might indulge one of your adolescent interests in middle-age with a few spare bob that you have in the bank, and create what must be one of the most extraordinary museums in the world.

That, at least, is what Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, and his partner Joe Patton, have done in creating the Experience Music Project. Designed by Canadian architect Frank Gehry, the building looks like half a dozen balls of brightly-coloured Playdough shaped by a giant's hands, with a few broken guitar fretboards thrown on the top for good measure.

Straddling the Seattle monorail, which clatters between the Seattle Center and the downtown Westlake Center (an early prototype for the ubiquitous shopping mall), the Project opened in June and demonstrates what can be achieved by a consuming passion and seemingly-unlimited resources.

Seattle is an appropriate setting for such an imaginative and ambitious project. The home of Starbucks, Boeing and Microsoft and the setting for Frasier and Free Willy, it has become the most desirable alternative location for Californians fed up with increasing pollution. It was also the birthplace of one James Marshall Hendrix on November 27 1942.

Not surprisingly then, large portions of the museum are devoted to Hendrix's life, work and ideas. On entering, you are equipped with a shoulder-slung guide, consisting of a CD-Rom player and a hand-held LCD display and keypad which you point at exhibits to hear more information about them through the headphone set. As my 11-year-old son discovered, this is enough to sustain the interest of those who have never even heard of Jimi Hendrix.

The state-of-the-art guide is handed to you in the main entrance area, which is called the Sky Church, a name coined by Jimi to describe an area where people come together to share a sense of communion through music. It is a performance area capable of holding 650 people with the largest indoor LCD screen in the world.

One whole gallery is devoted to artefacts associated with his band, the Jimi Hendrix Experience, including Jimi's favourite guitar, the white Fender Stratocaster he played at Woodstock, Noel Redding's bass, and Mitch Mitchell's drum-kit.

The only exhibit visitors have any hope of physically touching is the guitar and, if like me you are over 6ft tall, you can just reach over the plexiglass barrier and touch it. As I discovered, this immediately sets off the alarm, but if you stay cool and pretend it has nothing to do with you, then you should get away with it. In any event, I know Jimi would have approved.

In another gallery covering the history of rock music, a stage outfit worn by Janis Joplin is on display, along with one of Elvis's leather biking jackets. All of this raises questions about the concept of a museum like this - rock music is, after all, about living now and to hell with the future or the past. However, the Experience Project is redeemed by the interactive elements, where it is possible to try to create your own music.

In the Sound Lab you can learn the basics of playing the drums, keyboards, guitar and bass, or jam in soundproof booths with your family, friends, or other visitors.

Those with a more egotistical streak can go on stage at a virtual concert with a full set of stadium rock equipment, bright lights, smoke machines and thousands of screaming virtual fans.

The Project also features a new twist on the simulator ride, where you can go on the Artist's Journey through a variety of musical experiences. The first of these, Funk Blast, is, not surprisingly, a journey through the world of funk music. You begin by watching a short video describing the basics of funk, before moving up a ramp around a giant multi-coloured boot signed by funk stars and surrounded by video screens preparing you for your ride.

The ride is a standard flight simulator with a very non-standard visual experience that takes you through tunnels of funk, on stage, and out into the street with a range of ridiculously dressed musicians. You come to the end by almost disappearing down the gap between James Brown's front teeth.

There's no doubt that this is a museum with a difference, and whether or not you are a fan of Jimi Hendrix, it more than deserves a visit for the imagination that has gone into it. Be warned, however, that some preciously-held beliefs might be shattered. I always thought Purple Haze was a song about a psychedelic drug experience, but driving around I realised that it refers to the lavender farms that abound in the Seattle area and advertise their purple haze on roadside billboards.

You can also visit Jimi's grave in Greenwood Memor ial Park, Renton, a suburb of Seattle, which you can reach in half an hour by car. Some 50,000 people a year make the pilgrimage, many taking rubbings of Jimi's modest grave stone.

 For details of the Experience Music Project, call 001 206 233 3989 - adults $19.95, over 65s and 13-17s $15.95, 7-12 s $14.95, 6 and under free.

What else to do

Americans of all generations frequently use three adjectives - "awesome", "really neat", and "cool" - to describe things they like. So the following Seattle attractions are grouped under these headings.

Awesome: Mount Rainier, a 14,400ft volcano, is visible to the south of Seattle about 80 days a year, and its appearance constantly changes. For a better view of the volcano, and of the spectacular Seattle skyline, take a return trip (30 minutes each way) on the Washington State Ferry from pier 52 on the waterfront to Bainbridge Island. A return ticket costs $6.50 per car and driver, and $3.70 per person, 30% reduction for 5-18s, under 5s go free.

Mount St Helens, which exploded in 1980, is about 100 miles south. You can visit both mountains in a day. The devastated area around Mt St Helens is only just beginning to regenerate, so you are still able to get an idea of the power of the explosion. There is a $10 fee to enter either of these national parks.

The Olympic National Park, to the west, includes the Hoh rainforest with giant trees and mosses, and the Pacific wilderness beaches, where you might spot seals, sea otters and, in spring and autumn, migrating grey whales. In winter, you can ski on Hurricane Ridge. Again there is a $10 entrance fee.

More information about all three parks is available on the National Park Service website.

If you fancy fishing for salmon from Westport, try booking with Deep Sea Charters, (001 360 268 9300)

From the San Juan Islands to the north, you are almost certain to see killer whales. Three pods are resident all year round. You can go direct from Seattle to Friday Harbour on San Juan Island, or, if you drive to Bainbridge Island and then go via Port Townsend to Whidbey Island, you can cross the spectacular Deception Pass.

The San Juan Islands were the setting for the book Snow Falling on Cedars and for the films Free Willy and Practical Magic. Check ferry times with Washington State Ferries (001 206 464 6400).

Really neat: Pike Place Market, in downtown Seattle, is famous for the stalls where the traders throw fish and chorus in operatic style if you have the courage to buy anything. The Athenian Inn, located in the market, is one of Seattle's oldest places to eat.

In the Seattle Center, the Space Needle (001 206 905 2100), adults $11, over 65s $9, 5-12, $5, under 5s free) provides spectacular views of the city and surrounding area. You can almost see the houseboat from Sleepless in Seattle.

Also in the Seattle Center is the International Fountain. Make sure you visit on a hot day, unless you don't mind getting cold and wet. Even grandparents can't resist running the gauntlet of the fountain, which sleeps for a few minutes before bursting into life in response to music by Bach or Kurt Cobain.

The Seattle Center, built to house the 1962 World Fair, contains much more. Details on 001 206 684 7200.

Cool: Nordstrom is a department store for serious shoppers, or those who just want to know what real service is. You can walk up Pine Street from Pike Place Market to 5th Avenue, or get the monorail from the Seattle Center. There are many other wonderful shops.

The Gorge is a natural amphitheatre that has become a semi-permanent outdoor rock venue . It operates June-September. Located in the town of George, about 100 miles east of Seattle, you can lie back and spot meteorites while listening to the likes of Bob Dylan, Jimmy Page and the Black Crowes, Sting, Steely Dan, The Who and Neil Young. Events are advertised in the Seattle Weekly, a free local newspaper, or www.barstop.com/gorge.

The practicals

Northwest Airlines (0870 507407) flies to Seattle via Detroit from £332 return plus taxes. British Airways (0345 222111) flies direct from £321pp plus £57 taxes.

You begin by watching a short video describing the basics of funk, before moving up a ramp around a giant multi-coloured boot signed by funk stars and surrounded by video screens preparing you for your ride. The ride is a standard flight simulator with a very non-standard visual experience that takes you through tunnels of funk, on stage, and out into the street with a range of ridiculously dressed musicians. You come to the end by almost disappearing down the gap between James Brown's front teeth. There's no doubt that this is a museum with a difference, and whether or not you are a fan of Jimi Hendrix, it more than deserves a visit for the imagination that has gone into it. Be warned, however, that some preciously-held beliefs might be shattered. I always thought Purple Haze was a song about a psychedelic drug experience, but driving around I realised that it refers to the lavender farms that abound in the Seattle area and advertise their purple haze on roadside billboards. You can also visit Jimi's grave in Greenwood Memor ial Park, Renton, a suburb of Seattle, which you can reach in half an hour by car. Some 50,000 people a year make the pilgrimage, many taking rubbings of Jimi's modest grave stone.  For details of the Experience Music Project, call 001 206 233 3989 - adults $19.95, over 65s and 13-17s $15.95, 7-12 s $14.95, 6 and under free. What else to do Americans of all generations frequently use three adjectives - "awesome", "really neat", and "cool" - to describe things they like. So the following Seattle attractions are grouped under these headings. Awesome: Mount Rainier, a 14,400ft volcano, is visible to the south of Seattle about 80 days a year, and its appearance constantly changes. For a better view of the volcano, and of the spectacular Seattle skyline, take a return trip (30 minutes each way) on the Washington State Ferry from pier 52 on the waterfront to Bainbridge Island. A return ticket costs $6.50 per car and driver, and $3.70 per person, 30% reduction for 5-18s, under 5s go free. Mount St Helens, which exploded in 1980, is about 100 miles south. You can visit both mountains in a day. The devastated area around Mt St Helens is only just beginning to regenerate, so you are still able to get an idea of the power of the explosion. There is a $10 fee to enter either of these national parks. The Olympic National Park, to the west, includes the Hoh rainforest with giant trees and mosses, and the Pacific wilderness beaches, where you might spot seals, sea otters and, in spring and autumn, migrating grey whales. In winter, you can ski on Hurricane Ridge. Again there is a $10 entrance fee. More information about all three parks is available on the National Park Service website. If you fancy fishing for salmon from Westport, try booking with Deep Sea Charters, (001 360 268 9300) From the San Juan Islands to the north, you are almost certain to see killer whales. Three pods are resident all year round. You can go direct from Seattle to Friday Harbour on San Juan Island, or, if you drive to Bainbridge Island and then go via Port Townsend to Whidbey Island, you can cross the spectacular Deception Pass. The San Juan Islands were the setting for the book Snow Falling on Cedars and for the films Free Willy and Practical Magic. Check ferry times with Washington State Ferries (001 206 464 6400). Really neat: Pike Place Market, in downtown Seattle, is famous for the stalls where the traders throw fish and chorus in operatic style if you have the courage to buy anything. The Athenian Inn, located in the market, is one of Seattle's oldest places to eat. In the Seattle Center, the Space Needle (001 206 905 2100), adults $11, over 65s $9, 5-12, $5, under 5s free) provides spectacular views of the city and surrounding area. You can almost see the houseboat from Sleepless in Seattle. Also in the Seattle Center is the International Fountain. Make sure you visit on a hot day, unless you don't mind getting cold and wet. Even grandparents can't resist running the gauntlet of the fountain, which sleeps for a few minutes before bursting into life in response to music by Bach or Kurt Cobain. The Seattle Center, built to house the 1962 World Fair, contains much more. Details on 001 206 684 7200. Cool: Nordstrom is a department store for serious shoppers, or those who just want to know what real service is. You can walk up Pine Street from Pike Place Market to 5th Avenue, or get the monorail from the Seattle Center. There are many other wonderful shops. The Gorge is a natural amphitheatre that has become a semi-permanent outdoor rock venue . It operates June-September. Located in the town of George, about 100 miles east of Seattle, you can lie back and spot meteorites while listening to the likes of Bob Dylan, Jimmy Page and the Black Crowes, Sting, Steely Dan, The Who and Neil Young. Events are advertised in the Seattle Weekly, a free local newspaper, or www.barstop.com/gorge. The practicals Northwest Airlines (0870 507407) flies to Seattle via Detroit from £332 return plus taxes. British Airways (0345 222111) flies direct from £321pp plus £57 taxes.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: York bars | Wearing well | At easel
fields.body:
York bars
York's fourth annual Food and Drink Festival begins next Friday, with celebrity cookery demonstrations, speciality food markets, themed dinners and tutored wine and ale tastings. Daily September 22 - October 1. Most events free. Various venues, primarily the Nestlé Festival Food Theatre, St Samson's Square, York. Festival guide and info: 01904 554430.

Wearing well
What is the well-dressed well wearing this season? Chesterfield embraces the ancient custom of decorating wells with pictures made from petals. Chesterfield tourist information centre: 01246 345777/8.

At easel
St Ives' heritage as an artists' colony, accentuated since the arrival of the Tate, is celebrated in the town's annual art festival. Daily until September 23. Tickets: 01736 796888. St Ives, Cornwall.

Bank holiday
Fireworks, theatrical shows, sculptures, art exhibitions, children's treasure hunts and a torchlit procession spill over London's river and on to its banks as part of the 2000 Thames Festival. Sunday noon-9.30pm. Free. Between Blackfriars and Waterloo Bridges.

Volume sales
Scotland's 18th International Antiquarian Book Fair is an opportunity to see and buy rare, valuable books, manuscripts, maps, art and illustrated children's editions, displayed by booksellers from all over the world. September 21-23. £5 (£10 for Thursday preview). Assembly Rooms, 54 George Street, Edinburgh (0131-220 4348/9).

Old favourites
The Collectors' Day at Snowshill Manor brings flags, miniature steam engines, old agricultural implements and 18th-century glass from local enthusiasts to a Cotswold home already crowded with toys, musical instruments and bicycles. Saturday noon - 5pm. £6/£3/family £15. Snowshill, Nr Broadway, Worcestershire (01386 852410).

On the beat
Take a picnic to Audley End House and Gardens and listen to classical pieces, music from modern shows, traditional marches and jazz from the Essex Police Band. Sunday (performances 2pm and 3.15pm). £4.50/£2.50 (house extra). Nr Saffron Walden, Essex (01799 522399).

Claws for thought
The Egremont Crab Fair features neither crabs nor fairs, but sports such as the greasy pole, Cumbrian wrestling, a pipe-smoking contest, track events, terrier racing and an apple-cart parade. The world-renowned gurning (face-pulling) competition in the town hall rounds it all off. Sat. 8.30am to evening. £2.50 entry to sports field, otherwise free. Baybarrow Road, Egremont (01946 821554).

fields.headline: Island of dreams
fields.standfirst: Rumours of the island's ruination by tourists have been greatly exaggerated, finds  John Aglionby
fields.trailText: Rumours of the island's ruination by tourists have been greatly exaggerated, finds John Aglionby.
fields.body:
The glorious white-sand beach was deserted except for a smiling waiter bringing a refreshing glass of freshly-squeezed mango juice. Could this really be Bali? Its popular image is of a fading tropical paradise ruined by legions of young surfers, its roads clogged with coaches in search of the last remnants of local culture.

But last weekend at opposite ends of the island, I twice experienced that kind of laid-back luxury (the second time, the waiter was bringing a mixture of pineapple juice, banana and fresh coconut milk). With a little searching, you will find that Bali still has oodles of magical charm unspoilt by mass tourism.

My first stop was the 19,000-hectare West Bali National Park. Until recently, its distance from the tourist centres in the south (four hours along winding roads) and lack of upmarket accommodation has deterred all but a handful of wildlife lovers, divers and backpackers who don't mind roughing it.

The good news for people who require a little more comfort is that the first hotel has now opened. At first glance, Waka Shorea seems nothing special as far as upper-end Asian resorts go. A bungalow with only a shower and no bath or air-conditioning costs £100 a night with breakfast. Nightlife in non-existent. But although the price is hardly justified by the facilities, this is more than made up for by the surroundings.

There is no road to the resort. Visitors are brought in by motorboat unless the sea is very rough, when the choice is a bumpy 20-minute ride on the back of a motorbike or a one-hour walk.

Thirty seconds after leaving my bungalow, I was ambling down a trail engulfed in a cloud of butterflies. Most were white with black tips to their wings but there were occasional splashes of brown, red, orange and blue.

Within half an hour, I had also seen two of the three local species of deer and two types of monkey, and had almost been decapitated by an over-enthusiastic sea eagle. The only prize I missed was the Bali starling, one of the world's most endangered birds - at the last count, only 14 were found living in the wild, all in the national park.

The following morning, it was time to go scuba diving. Manjangan island, widely agreed to be Bali's best dive site, is less than 10 minutes away by boat. Being part of the national park, its coral and marine life have been protected from the cyanide and bombs that have wrecked many other parts of Indonesia. Visibility at 90ft below the surface was well over 100ft, the coral formations were up to 10ft high and the fish numerous and colourful. The snorkelling was also great and a lot cheaper.

While Waka Shorea is the only hotel actually in the park, there are cheaper alternatives just beyond the boundaries of the protected area. Several losmen (Indonesian guesthouses) can be found in Gilimanuk, which is where the informative park headquarters is located. These range from £2.50 a night for a spartan room to about £13 for something a little more comfortable.

At the other end of the scale, the Mimpi Manjangan (which claims to be in the heart of the park but is actually a couple of miles beyond the eastern boundary) has rooms ranging from £76 to £275.

It was impossible to hurry from the national park to my next destination, Bunutan, on the far eastern tip of the island. For starters, the northern coast road is not great, and, for £13 a day, I had not hired the best car on the road.

Also, there were so many distractions in the form of traditional ceremonies. No one minded in Air Sanih that the road was blocked for 20 minutes as a bridal party made its way through the village to the temple. A couple of miles down the road the whole village was on the black-sand beach giving offerings to their local deity. I could only stare in awe at how the women walked with 4ft-high arrangements of fruit, bougainvillea and coconut palms stacked on their heads.

In the seven places I stopped, I met only two other tourists. Clearly, these villagers had not decked themselves up in their finery and built amazingly elaborate wooden models of fish, bulls and other animals on the offchance that a busload of tourists would turn up and give them some money. This was true Balinese culture.

Bunutan is not as remote or deserted as West Bali National Park - there are about four places to stay along the mile-long beach - but its pace of life is as sedate as the rate of evaporation from the ranks of salt pans laid out on the sand. Its lack of development can be measured by the fact that it is still a spa-free zone - now a rarity on Bali (see sidebar).

Again, there is no nightlife, but then you need a clear head to enjoy the best time of day, namely early morning when you can watch the sun rise over the silhouette of Mount Rinjani on the neighbouring island of Lombok while an armada of outrigger canoes return from the night's fishing.

Budget travellers should head for Hidden Paradise, where rooms cost about £30 a night, or Coral View next door, which is a little pricier. The only proper hotel is the Indra Udhyana, which is a little overpriced at up to £110 for a beachfront cottage, although these are spacious enough to pack in a crowd.

You can go trekking among the salt pans and rice terraces or hire a car for half an hour's drive to the water palace at Tirtagangga on the lower slopes of Mount Agung. There, I met a few tourists who had paid 30 pence to splash in the cool mountain spring water, but most of the bathers were Balinese who had just completed a pilgrimage to the local temples.

There are also several traditional villages nearby, although it is worth getting to them early to avoid the tourists who come from their hotels in Candi Dasa to the south.

But however you choose to fill your day, it is worth going back to your bungalow to enjoy the freshly-squeezed juice on the deserted beach as the sun sets. Who said Bali was ruined?

Pamper central

Spas are not quite as ubiquitous as Hindu temples in Bali - yet - but these monuments to undiluted hedonism are being built at such a rapid rate it seems they are not far behind.

With more than 500 body-treatment centres dotted all over an island 140km by 80km, Bali must surely be "pamper central" of south-east Asia, if not the world.

Most are attached to hotels - they are now de rigueur for any resort claiming to be upmarket. But demand is so great that entrepreneurs are setting up stand-alone spas to cash in on tourists' seemingly-inexhaustible desire to have their bodies rubbed, scrubbed, stretched, prodded, steamed, soaked and caressed.

Puri Esthetic (Jalan Bypass Ngurah Rai, No 81, Sanur, Bali, 80228, phone +62 361 286 542) is typical of the new breed of spas. Its owner, Lili Herawati, used to run a garment factory. But two years ago she turned it into a treatment centre. "Clothes were so getting so boring, I wanted to do something more fun," she said.

It is almost impossible not to have fun at Puri Esthetic. The most basic treatment offered is an 80-minute massage that combines Balinese, Swedish, Thai, shiatsu and acupressure and costs £30. At the other end of the spectrum, the six-hour Puri Esthetic Luxury will leave you more than £125 out of pocket.

But after any spa session, you feel like a million pounds. The snag is that the feeling wears off as soon as you jump into a swimming pool or the sea, which means the only solution is to go back for even more pampering.

The practicals

Singapore Airlines (0870 6088886) flies Heathrow to Bali return from £595. Royal Brunei has a special offer from Heathrow to Bali via Brunei for £378 return. You need to book by October 31, for departures from November 1 - 30, and all travel must be completed by December 9. Details from Bridge The World (020-7911 0990).

Tour operators organising trips to Bali include:

Asian Journeys (01869 276200, ).

Exodus Travels (020-8675 5550) - a 17-day Java, Bali and Lombok trip costs from £1,340pp including flights, transport and accommodation with breakfast.

Magic of the Orient (01293 537700) - a 5-night stay at the Griya Santrian Hotel in Sanur Beach costs from £677pp including flights and B&B accommodation.

Nomadic Thoughts (020- 7604 4408).

Silverbird (020-8875 9090).

AsiaWorld (08700 799 788).

webTitle: SNP contenders fight for party's soul

fields.headline: SNP contenders fight for party's soul
fields.standfirst: Next week's contest to succeed Alex           Salmond will also decide whether Scotland's independence is still a priority
fields.trailText: Next week's contest to succeed Alex           Salmond will also decide whether Scotland's independence is still a priority.
fields.body:
The Scottish National party chooses a new leader next week and in doing so looks set to decide that Scotland's independence is not its top priority.

Two men are vying to replace Alex Salmond, who is standing down after 10 years, having grown weary of the fight. One is a gradualist, the other a fundamentalist and their contest has prompted a battle for the party's soul should the SNP go all out for independence or work within the Scottish parliament to push for greater powers?

Mr Salmond's deputy, John Swinney, 36, is the favourite to succeed him. He follows the line adopted by Mr Salmond that Holyrood should be championed as a stepping stone to full autonomy, and he helped in a recent strategy shift on how to approach independence that had some in the party talking of betrayal.

Under Mr Swinney's plan the SNP would hold a referendum immediately after a successful election, before any negotiations for independence were started. Previously, the party would have begun negotiations for independence as soon as they won an election in Scotland, before putting the final deal to voters in a referendum. Analysts say it is a significant shift which makes the party's aims unclear. Mr Swinney says it was simply realistic.

"What I am interested in is finding the quickest and most credible route towards independence," he said. "That comes from building on the Scottish parliament. My campaign is about Scottish independence and about building the SNP into a political organisation that would be capable of doing that."

His opponent, Alex Neil, a 49-year-old former Labour activist, wants the SNP to restate immediately its commitment to independence and is still angry that it came 10th on a list of pledges produced by the party for last year's Scottish elections. If elected, he would push for a return to the old strategy.

"The party needs to make independence its number one priority. If we don't make it our first priority then we can't persuade the Scottish people to make it theirs," he said.

Both men play down the differences between them, but observers of Scottish politics say they represent a deep split within the SNP over which direction to take.

"This is not just a leadership contest. It is an internal SNP battle," said John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "We are seeing here a choice between the gradualists and the fundamentalists. If Alex Neil becomes leader the strategic position of the SNP will change. Meanwhile, the aim of the gradualists is to get into government, not necessarily to achieve independence."

But whoever wins, the party has a separate battle on its hands - trying to convince the Scottish public, and more than half of their own voters, that independence, in whatever form, is a real possibility.

Last week a System Three poll found that 60% of Scots and 51% of SNP voters did not think Scotland would become independent in their lifetime.

"At the moment Scots don't think independence is going to happen," said Mr Curtice.

"There is an underlying case to be won. There is plenty of polling evidence that Scots want the Scottish parliament to be more powerful than it is. At the moment Scots don't want it to go all the way to something that might be called independence, but they want a parliament that can actually do something."

Mr Swinney agrees that the country needs convincing.

"It is quite clear that Scotland is not yet persuaded that our country should become an independent country. We need to put together the strongest possible argument to persuade the public of the merits of our case. What's important is that we relate independence to everyday concerns schools, hospitals, pensions, poverty, fuel and job creation."

Mr Neil says the party must be seen to go for Labour's jugular.

"Unless we succeed in Labour's heartlands then we won't win the fight for independence," he said. "We need a more combative role. We have to really go for them."

The decision will be made next Saturday. Mr Salmond will push his party off into uncharted waters and return to the lower rungs of the SNP executive. Many observers say the party will suffer from his leaving.

Professor James Kellas, an expert on nationalism at Glasgow University, said: "Alex Salmond did very well in projecting the image of the SNP . He sounds more authoritative he looks better on TV."

His opponent, Alex Neil, a 49-year-old former Labour activist, wants the SNP to restate immediately its commitment to independence and is still angry that it came 10th on a list of pledges produced by the party for last year's Scottish elections. If elected, he would push for a return to the old strategy. "The party needs to make independence its number one priority. If we don't make it our first priority then we can't persuade the Scottish people to make it theirs," he said. Both men play down the differences between them, but observers of Scottish politics say they represent a deep split within the SNP over which direction to take. "This is not just a leadership contest. It is an internal SNP battle," said John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "We are seeing here a choice between the gradualists and the fundamentalists. If Alex Neil becomes leader the strategic position of the SNP will change. Meanwhile, the aim of the gradualists is to get into government, not necessarily to achieve independence." But whoever wins, the party has a separate battle on its hands - trying to convince the Scottish public, and more than half of their own voters, that independence, in whatever form, is a real possibility. Last week a System Three poll found that 60% of Scots and 51% of SNP voters did not think Scotland would become independent in their lifetime. "At the moment Scots don't think independence is going to happen," said Mr Curtice. "There is an underlying case to be won. There is plenty of polling evidence that Scots want the Scottish parliament to be more powerful than it is. At the moment Scots don't want it to go all the way to something that might be called independence, but they want a parliament that can actually do something." Mr Swinney agrees that the country needs convincing. "It is quite clear that Scotland is not yet persuaded that our country should become an independent country. We need to put together the strongest possible argument to persuade the public of the merits of our case. What's important is that we relate independence to everyday concerns schools, hospitals, pensions, poverty, fuel and job creation." Mr Neil says the party must be seen to go for Labour's jugular. "Unless we succeed in Labour's heartlands then we won't win the fight for independence," he said. "We need a more combative role. We have to really go for them." The decision will be made next Saturday. Mr Salmond will push his party off into uncharted waters and return to the lower rungs of the SNP executive. Many observers say the party will suffer from his leaving. Professor James Kellas, an expert on nationalism at Glasgow University, said: "Alex Salmond did very well in projecting the image of the SNP . He sounds more authoritative he looks better on TV."

webTitle: Teepees and Bee Gees in a walk on the Wild West side

fields.headline: Teepees and Bee Gees in a walk on the Wild West side
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: Ron the Manager has fond memories of last week's thriller between Derby and Charlton.
fields.body:
Hmm ... isn't it? Well, no it isn't actually! Last week's column seems to have been grossly misinterpreted ... Homophobic? ... ask the wife! ... Ron Manager has always been fiercely heterosexual! ... Some of the gutter press even sinking so low as to quote the old terrace anthem ... "Ron Manager ... Superstar ..."

I, in fact, walk like a man ... much in the manner of Frankie Valli ... and as for "wearing a bra"...!

Well, I've got that off my chest!...On with the football! Sunday afternoon ... after some stick from the wife ... understandably concerned about my gallivanting around ... what with my reputation as a bit of a ladies' man! ... Me and Big Norm walked ... and let me tell you, Ron Manager "uses" his walk much in the manner of Barry Gibb of the beat-group The Bee-Gees ... walked back from the pub to watch the top Premiership action on Super-Sunday! ... on cable TV! ... drooling in anticipation!

Hot-dog before the game? ... bucket-seat? ... hot-dog after? ... Ho ho! ... not today! ... Three-seater sofa from Kingdom of Leather! ... cushions all plumped up! ... and manly roast beef ... from England! ... Yorkshires! ... swimming in gravy! ... and it's ... er ... Derby County against mighty Charlton Athletic ... and a packed house! ... every seat taken ... thanks to the unexpected arrival of the in-laws ... bigger turn-out than Pride Park!

Mrs Manager's rather effete cousin offers his knee to sit on ... "No thanks chum!" ... Mad dash for the emergency seating! ... But dammit! ... Norm's bagged the bean-bag ... and I've ended up on the leathery old pouffe!

And the gossip! ... Couldn't even hear the commentary! ... big fellow in white passes to a little fellow ... little fellow in red makes an interception ... how do they get those circles on the pitch? ... Where's the volume? ... Ah!

Tiler! ... Rufus ... men you'd turn to in an emergency! ... Poom! ... ho ho ... Higginbotham! ... takes broad shoulders to wear that on your back ... Schnoor ... Ho ho! ... me too! ... Valakiri rides the tackle ... Baldy chap hoofs it into a hoarding advertising "Wash n Go!" ...

Little chap with a bald head ... familiar faces ... er ... Oh! Jim Smith ... Derby Manager! ... Me and Jim go back a long way! ... Bryan Robson called him a cheat the other week ... slight discrepancy in their reading of the "unwritten rules" ... but "daylight robbery!" ... bit strong Bryan! ... not Honest Jim Smith ... integrity personified! ... Honest Injun! ... Bald Eagle! ... the only one who's retained his nickname from the old "Cherokee club!" ... Ho ho! ... not so much a celebration of indigenous culture ... Just a bunch of red-blooded braves ... in the wild wild West-end! ... blowing all our wampum on firewater ... and er ... back to squaw one! ... Um, marvellous!

"Heap Big" Ron Atkinson! ... Ken "Sioux" Bates! ... one by one ... they all rode off into the sunset!

Even myself! ... Ron "Passing Water" Manager" ... flung out actually ... shortly after inheriting a cowboy suit ... The rest of the lads initially tolerated the 10-gallon hat ... but they drew the line at my fondness for the leather chaps!

Cowboys and indians ... wasn't it? ... hmm? ... Younger readers might be a bit lost ... but ask your father! ... That was lad culture in the days before Pokémon and Playstation! ... and not just among football folk ... correct me if I'm wrong ... didn't Alan Sugar once have a cowboy outfit? ... bought one of his computers a while back ... wonder if it still works?

Half-time ... lunch on the back-burner ... they've all turned over to Eastenders! ... Me and Norm ... football men through and through ... sloped off to the pub for the second half ... and for crying out loud! ... they're all watching Eastenders there!

But ... pub grub! ... isn't it? ... Man-size steaks ... smothered in onions ... spuds! and lashings of gravy ... Great stuff!

And this week's big news? ... Arrividerci Gianluca! ... I'm surprised he and Ken lasted so long ... totally different personalities! ... Chalk and cheese!

Vialli ... cultured ... urbane ... decent ... unselfish! ... a man you'd trust with your life! ... er ... and a reader's letter!

Mr Mark Pitts of Chiswick writes with a suggestion as to how to rid myself of the unwelcome attentions of my whiskery stalker ... Ken Bates lookalike ... Captain Birdseye! ... Ho ho! ... unprintable!

Well, Mark ... funnily enough ... and in case readers don't know ... the Old Captain Birdseye ... not the new one favoured by Mrs Manager ... had been hounding me ... doggedly! ... since our little "misunderstanding" in Amsterdam ... until an odd incident midweek ...

I'd phoned old "Bald Eagle" ... just to say "How!" and Blow me! ... the Cherokee Club's still going! So off to a "pow-wow!" ... on the scooter! ... what petrol crisis? ... and there's the Villa supremo ... John "Crazy Horse" Gregory!

After all the speculation about John's mental health ... everybody thinks John's nuts! ... But oh no! ... sane as you or me ... calm ... articulate ... relaxed ... chatting away ... Suddenly he's hit the warpath! ... eyes bulging ... veins popping ...

He's spotted Captain Birdseye! ... Down the street after him whooping dementedly! ... joined in the chase by some bald fellow in a V-neck sporting an odd goatee ... "Porco! ... Persona non-grata!" ... eh?

What a kerfuffle! ... baffling ... I turned round and now Jim Smith's flying off down the pavement ... on my scooter! ... the thieving bastard!

... and Captain Birdseye? ... hmm? ... harmless old bird really ... Haven't seen him since! ... it's not quite the same without him ...

And today's One to watch! ... Graham Rix! ... er ....

fields.headline: Next year's bombshell
fields.standfirst: A strong dollar and rising oil prices mean bad news for travellers, warns  Roger Bray
fields.trailText: A strong dollar and rising oil prices mean bad news for travellers, warns Roger Bray.
fields.body:
Soaring fuel prices and the strength of the US dollar are threatening increases of up to 10% in the price of many of next summer's holidays.

Long-haul travellers will be worst affected. The longer the flight, the more important fuel becomes as a proportion of overall costs. Airlines pay for that fuel in dollars. And hoteliers and other suppliers in other countries besides the US - notably in the Caribbean and Latin America - set their rates in dollars. It all adds up to a very nasty combination of economic punches.

But its impact on tour operators is mixed. Those yet to publish long-haul programmes for next summer may have to up their prices by around 10%. The response of those with brochures already out will depend on whether they offer no surcharge guarantees - and on the extent to which they have bought dollars at a fixed rate in the forward market and their agreements with airlines.

Some firms whose booking conditions allow them the option of surcharging are struggling to avoid doing so by swallowing the extra costs. In any case, operators are forbidden by law from doing so less than 30 days before the customer departs. They must absorb extra costs up to 2% of the holiday price, and clients may cancel without penalty if the extra charge exceeds 10%.

Most big operators promise not to surcharge - but that may not stop them issuing updated editions of their programmes, with higher prices.

They could also follow the course adopted by long-haul specialist Kuoni, which, when customers telephone to book, is quoting higher prices on some packages than those shown in the brochure. For example, it is adding £68 per couple to the all-inclusive brochure price of £1,033 in late January at the Rex Turtle Beach on Tobago. The firm will not surcharge customers after a booking has been made, however, and a spokeswoman adds: "We are trying to offset these cost increases by re-negotiating our deals with suppliers."

Noel Josephides, managing director of Sunvil, says price rises in Europe will be offset by an 8-10% strengthening of sterling against key currencies such as the Greek drachma. But this will not be enough to balance rate increases imposed by hoteliers and higher flying costs. The net result could be an increase of 5-6 % in next summer's package prices, adding about £22 to a £450 holiday.

But it is the firm's long-haul customers who will bear the brunt. "Our Namibian programme won't be as badly hit because we pay hotels in rand. But in Central and South America and Zambia we are charged in dollars. I reckon we'll have to raise our prices to those countries by about 10%."

Journey Latin America warns that its prices in its latest escorted-tours brochure, which is about to be published, will have to rise "significantly".

Director Brian Williams says: "So far the problem is the strength of the dollar. Fuel price rises haven't fed through yet."

Some US airlines have already slapped a $20 per round trip fuel surcharge on domestic fares. But carriers flying to South America are in a bind. Their costs are rocketing but over-capacity, particularly in winter, continues to produce a flow of bargain fares.

webTitle: How much do holidays really cost?

fields.headline: Where did all the money go?
fields.standfirst: You think you've kept to a reasonable budget, but when you get back your credit-card bill tells a different story. So what did you really spend? We asked five Guardian holidaymakers to cost it out
fields.trailText: You think you've kept to a reasonable budget, but when you get back your credit-card bill tells a different story. So what did you really spend? We asked five Guardian holidaymakers to cost it out.
fields.body:
Katharine Viner

Estimated total: £600

I was in need of a quiet, beachy holiday with as little activity as possible, so went to stay with my friend Jack in his family's apartment in Gozo, a small, beautiful island off Malta. Thanks to Jack's generosity, this was not a holiday that broke the bank, but I do get a bit carried away when faced with the two words "duty-free".

What I spent

Flights: BA to Malta £260.

Clothes: Three summer dresses (Selfridges, Top Shop) £150; new bikini (Selfridges, didn't wear) £40.

Books: Philip Roth, Janis Joplin biography, Anita Desai £40.

Extras: Legs and bikini wax £30; suntan lotions (Nivea, Factor 15, 12, 8, plus after-sun) £35; sun-protecting shampoo and conditioner (Kerastase) £15; mosquito repellent and cream (Superdrug) £10; breakfast at airport £4.

Duty-free on the way out: CDs (inc Craig David with free video, Bob Dylan, Beach Boys, Cardigans, UK Garage and Ibiza compilations) £80; perfume (Armani) £40; vodka and cointreau for holiday £20.

Transport: Cab to airport £26; cab from Malta airport to ferry £12; share of jeep hire, plus petrol £54; cab from ferry to Malta airport £12; cab home £28.

Accommodation: £0.

Basics: Kitty for the week £150; share of utilities £29.

Entertainment: Dinner for three £30; entry and drinks in the Grotta nightclub £15; beers out (total for week, rounds at 30p a bottle) £15.

What I bought on the way home: Presents (wine, nougat, sarong for Mum) £40; British newspapers at airport £5; duty-free moisturiser (Clarins) £30; duty-free kalhua and rum £20.

Real total: £1,190

Verdict: It was more than I thought I'd spent, but worth every penny. And I still have the Craig David CD to dance to in my bikini.

Will Woodward and Rachel Cooke

Estimated total: £2,000

It felt expensive before we left, mainly because of £680 for a week's stay in an (admittedly delightful) house overlooking Meloi beach in Patmos. But we spent money like Greek mineral water, and usually can't be bothered to check it. Was it a cheap holiday? No. Did we need it? Yes.

What we spent

Flights: Heathrow-Athens-Rhodes, Olympic Airways, £646 for two.

Clothes: Two swimsuits £24, three T-shirts £15, new beach towel £10.

Books: Rough Guide to Greek Islands, Carol Shields, Raymond Chandler, Adhaf Soueif, Sybil Bedford, JK Rowling, Martin Amis £48.93.

Extras: Insect repellent £4; copy of the Guardian at airport £0.45.

Transport: Early-morning mini-cab Hackney-Heathrow £30; Heathrow Express to Paddington x 2 £24; cab Paddington-Hackney £16.

Accommodation: House in Patmos for seven days, £680.

Paid on credit card: Meal in Rhodes £48.86; unnecessary tip £7.58.

Money taken out of cash machines: Heathrow £202.61; Rhodes £187.02; Patmos £357.03. This was spent on:

Accommodation: Four nights in hotels in Rhodes £185; three nights in hotels in Patmos £140.

Transport: Taxis in Rhodes £10; taxis in Patmos £3; hydrofoil, Rhodes-Patmos, Patmos-Rhodes £80.

What we bought out there:

Hat and swimming trunks £20; after-sun cream £3.

Activities: Entrance to Patmos monasteries £15; opera tickets £14, sun lounger rental £16; internet access £2.

The rest was pretty much food and restaurant bills - we ate out every night save for about three nights at our house in Patmos; there we had breakfast in every day and lunch in about five days.

Real total: £2,301.48

Verdict: Cost-wise, it was on the high side for a holiday with very little sightseeing action. But it was worth it.

Andrew Gilchrist

Estimated cost: £1,600

I spent two weeks in Thailand (trekking round the hills up north, scuba-diving off the southern islands, boozing in Bangkok) then a week-long bender in Hong Kong staying at a mate's. So, it was never going to be cheap.

What I spent

Flights: London-Bangkok return £693; Bangkok- Chiang Mai rtn £60; Bangkok- Ko Samui rtn £110; Bangkok-Hong Kong rtn £120.

Books: Rough Guide to Thailand, Stalingrad £26; Extras: Money belt £5; shiny glasses case with snazzy pop-up lid £12.

Transport: Tube to Heathrow £3.50.

Accommodation in Chiang Mai: One night in crappy hostel with door hanging off hinges £5; two nights in hotel (4-star) £60.

Transport: Tuk tuks (taxis) £20.

Activities: Three-day trek to hill tribes £40.

What I bought: Nike sandals £5; fake Oakley shorts (fell apart the same day) £5; mosquito sprays £10; camera and films £150.

Entertainment: Thai boxing show £5.

Food and drink: £60.

Accommodation in Ko Pha Ngan/Ko Samui: Seven nights' accommodation £120.

Activities: Four days' diving £200.

Food and drink: (inc Full Moon beach party all-nighter) £100.

Transport: Boat crossings £10; tuk tuks £20.

Accommodation in Bangkok: Two nights in hotel (inc mini bar) £40.

Activities: Dismal city boat trip £8; massage £5.

Transport: Tuk tuks £15.

Food and drink: £30.

What I bought: Two fake Diesel T-shirts £10; Thai boxing shorts £5; carved teak elephant with stand, four teak bowls, two sets of teak salad server spoons, two coconut bowls for rice, giant teak plate, 11 sets of chopsticks, two pairs colourful beach trousers (not teak) £50.

Accommodation in Hong Kong: £0.

What I bought: Ralph Lauren top (not fake) £40; Adidas trainers (not fake) £35; Johnny Walker Red Label whisky (present) £10; silk dressing gown (present) £120.

Transport: Airport train return £20; taxis £40.

Activities: Daytrip to Macau (inc dinner at world-famous Fernando's) £60; daytrip to Stanley Beach (inc waterfront lunch) £20; Sunny Paradise hot bath and massage £30.

Food and drink: £200 (inc vodka jelly night); plus lunch at 62nd floor revolving restaurant £20; plus took pal and his girlfriend for a meal at classy restaurant (Harry Ramsden's) £50.

Real total: £2,647.50

Verdict: I am flabbergasted. I knew I hadn't exactly been tight-fisted. But having now totted things up, I clearly went bananas, blazing round south-east Asia haemorrhaging cash. I booked my flight late, which was costly, then thought: why spend all that then skimp when I get there? So I didn't. And it was worth it - especially the Full Moon party and the Sunny Paradise massage.

Mark Porter and Lizzy Hubbard

Estimated total: £2,300

The first week was spent self-catering in a traditional black house by the sea on the isle of Harris. It takes ingenuity to find ways of spending money in Harris, but we succeeded by dining lavishly twice at a nearby hotel. The second week was at a hotel in Skye, which was comfortable, but creaky. It reminded us more and more of Fawlty Towers, so we decamped for the last night to a restaurant with rooms on the other side of the island.

What we spent

Transport: Return train fare from London (overnight sleeper to Inverness) £258; ferry tickets £145.90; cab to Euston £8.50;car hire £210; petrol £60.43; cab home from Euston £8.

Clothes: Shoes, T-shirts (one pair of Merrell aquamocs, three T-shirts from Joseph, two T-shirts from agnès b) £225.

Books: Stewart Brand's The Clock of the Long Now, Lee Seldes' The Legacy of Mark Rothko, Freeman J Dyson's The Sun, the Genome and the Internet and Hugo Vickers' biography of Cecil Beaton £44.62;

Extras: Binoculars (to spy on the Taransay castaways) £29.99; maps £10.50; camera films £12.75; walking kit (we already had the basics, but bought socks, trousers and hat) £120.45.

Accommodation: Hotel deposit £80; house rental on Harris £345; house electricity £12; Hotel in Skye (5 nights B&B, pre-dinner drinks, one restaurant dinner, 4 bar meals, telephone) £678.99; drinks, dinner, B&B for one night at Three Chimneys restaurant-with-rooms £260.

What we bought when we were there: Fleece top £43; enough tweed to make two skirts £60.

Food and drink: Shopping in Inverness (deli, butcher, baker, wine) £100.15; shopping in Ullapool (household supplies, groceries) £45; pub lunch £12.20; afternoon tea waiting for ferry £4.50; Skye pub/tea shop lunches £29; groceries in Harris £43.20 (bag of fresh langoustines from fishermen at Leverburgh pier was free); Harris pub/tea shop lunches £24; drinks & dinner twice at Scarista House £203.10; supper in Inverness £65; lunch in Drumnadrochit £12.50.

Extras: Left luggage at Inverness station £8; film processing £20.

Real total: £3,179.78

Verdict: A lot, considering that most days were spent walking in the hills. Expensive train fares, car hire, hotels, and restaurants mean that a holiday in Scotland costs us much more than one in Italy or Spain (and we have to go to Italy or Spain afterwards to get some decent weather).

Ben Mallalieu, Jenny Taylor and three children
Estimated total: £3,200

Apart from the cost of the ferry and the apartment, this ought not to be an expensive holiday. Food and drink in France is still the best in the world and far cheaper than in England. We're well stocked up with summer clothes and unread books. We even have plenty of suntan lotion left over from last year, and we won't be buying any English newspapers . . .

What we spent

Clothes: Swimming costume for Jenny, children's shorts and T-shirts £100.

Extras: Topping up first-aid kit £20; food staples £20; film £20; batteries £5; Green Card £15; pre-trip service for the car £360; tank of diesel £40.

What we bought on the journey: One coffee (between two), one Coca-Cola (between three) at a Little Chef, at least £5; drinks at ferry terminal £15; plastic headlight deflectors £7.50.

Accommodation: Two weeks' self-catering at Pierre et Vacances holiday village, Port du Crouesty, Brittany, plus crossing with Brittany Ferries and insurance £2,411, five-star service £180, children's clubs £38.

fields.headline: Your département
fields.standfirst: We used to give the Languedoc a wide berth as we made our way down to Provence. Now it is the new Provence and more and more of us are flocking there. Enjoy it while you can, says  Paul Kelso
fields.trailText: We used to give the Languedoc a wide berth as we made our way down to Provence. Now it is the new Provence and more and more of us are flocking there. Enjoy it while you can, says Paul Kelso.
fields.body:
The British have been heading south to holiday in Mediterranean Europe for so long and in such numbers that it seems every destination has become a cliché. In Tuscany, you can't move for members of the Cabinet; the Spanish Costas are a summer camp for football fans and a rest home for retired gangsters; and St Tropez is fast becoming a theme park for subscribers to OK! magazine.

No less of a cliché, of course, is the "undiscovered" corner of Europe. But visit the Languedoc, a hot, rocky corner of south-west France, and you cannot help but feel you have uncovered a well-kept secret. The Languedoc is, to use travel industry jargon, seriously underdeveloped as a destination.

The area has always had a distinct identity defined by its own language (Occitan), a cultural heritage steeped in Catharism (a heretical strand of Christianity), and a degree of Spanish influence. Bordered by the Pyrenees to the south and the Black Mountains to the north, at its heart lies the lower Aude alley - a 100-mile-long triangle with Toulouse, Narbonne and Perpignan at the corners - which stretches in a widening plain to the Mediterranean.

With staggering scenery, sandy beaches, ancient castles, abbeys and churches, affordable accommodation, great food, some of the most drinkable vintages in France and a local population not yet sick of the sight of tourists, it has all the elements of a classic Mediterranean holiday minus the crowds. Indeed, if you were in marketing, you would call it the new Provence. It even has its own Peter Mayle in Christopher Hope, whose book Signs of the Heart: Love and Death in Languedoc was published in paperback last month.

Hope, however, recently bemoaned the ever-increasing Brit presence. And he's right, of course - the peace and quiet can't last. Ryanair has been operating budget services from Stansted to Carcassonne for more than two years and this summer introduced daily flights to Perpignan. Return flights start at £70 a head plus tax, and nearly 70,000 people flew in between June and August.

However, wine, not tourism, is the dominant, industry, with vines growing on every spare scrap of land; one of the great pleasures of the Languedoc is to sit in a restaurant overlooking the vineyards from which the wine in your glass was produced. The peace and quiet may not last long - the Brits are coming - but there's still time to visit without noticing. Fly cheap, hire a car and tour the castles, villages and beaches while you can.

The beaches

Do not expect the celebrity-filled golden sands of St Tropez - the Languedoc coast is a more egalitarian place than that. Typical is Gruisson, 15 miles from Narbonne. An ancient seaside town supplemented a decade ago with a marina development, the long, shallow bay is backed by rows of beach huts on stilts, which famously featured in the film Betty Blue.

There's all the usual beach stuff to do, but a local favourite is bat and ball. The French appear obsessive about the game and it is played with gusto by men and women, young and old alike.

The marina at Gruisson has affordable hotel accommodation and enough nightlife to keep one going. At Le Corail, a personable small hotel on the waterfront, a twin room costs £40 a night.

The marina is lined with restaurants offering menus ranging from an absurdly cheap 60F (£6) for three courses to 180F for foie gras, langoustine and lobster. The seafood is of the highest quality and as long as you try and eat when the restaurateur wants you to, you can't go wrong (at one restaurant, we were told that it was too hot for the chef to cook lunch).

Further south, Argeles sur Mer and Banyuls, the most southerly resorts in France, are a little cosier, more Salcombe than Blackpool.

Castles and churches

Central to the local heritage is Catharism, the great heresy stamped out by the Catholic church early in the second millennium. The Cathar's differences with Rome seem somewhat petty viewed from the 21st century. Essentially, they believed that evil existed independently of God, while Rome held that Lucifer was initially a good being who revolted against the creator. But in the 13th century, the Cathars belief in this dualism was serious enough for successive pontiffs to launch murderous campaigns against them. By 1244, they had succeeded in crushing the Cathars, but not before the heretics had built hundreds of spectacular mountain-top fortifications, many of which remain.

Perhaps the most spectacular is at Querebas, 90 minutes south of Narbonne and high in the Corbières mountains. The remaining castle walls cling to the top of a peak only accessible from one side and commanding views of all approaches. To the south, the Mediterranean twinkles, while to the east the snow-capped Pyrenees peek through the haze.

Across the valley from Querebas is the chateau at Puilaurens built on a jagged ridge 900 years ago. They used to fling non-believers to the rocks from here and peering down you gain a truer understanding of what it meant to be dashed. Now the only people hurling themselves off are paragliders drifting with the eagles to the valley floor.

Another church in the Corbières has attracted almost as much attention as the Cathar castles but, unlike the ruins on the peaks, it still attracts 25,000 pilgrims a year. The church of St Mary Magadalene in Rennes-le-Chateau is the focus of a complex mythology that puts it in the grassy knoll class of conspiracy theories. It has been variously described as the true resting place of Jesus Christ, home to the Holy Grail and a UFO landing pad.

In the late 1800s, Abbé Saunière, a man of no great means, spent a fortune restoring the church and presbytery. The source of his fortune is still unclear, but one theory is that he was paid off by the Vatican after uncovering the uncomfortable truth that Christ was smuggled to France before the Romans had a chance to nail him to anything. Whatever the source of Saunière's loot, the tale has inspired a stream of visitors armed with eccentric theories and it lends the tiny church an air of mystery that sets it apart. But it helps to have read a theory or two before you arrive.

The villages

One of the gentler pleasures of the Languedoc is touring the towns and villages slowly being occupied by speculating Brits. The classic settlement has a bar, a baker, a post office, a church and a square, usually shaded by the plane trees that Napolean planted to protect his troops from the noonday heat. There are few more splendid places to do nothing.

Bages overlooks the salt marshes south of Narbonne and is famous for its antique shops and its seafood.

Lagrasse, a beautiful medieval settlement on the Aude upstream from Narbonne, is wonderfully bourgeois compared with many of the villages of the Languedoc, which remain pleasantly paisant . It's a sort of French Hay-on-Wye, whose cobbled lanes are full of holidaying Parisiennes and ateliers des art .

Unlike many of the ancient monuments in the Languedoc, there is no son et lumiere at Lagrasse, nor a guided tour for the plebs. Instead, on the day we visited, the 14th-century abbey was full of earnest folk in smocks and frameless spectacles gathering to hear playwright Armand Gatti - 1960s radical and dramatiser of Antonio Gramsci's prison diaries - lecture on the nature of revolution. It couldn't have been more clichéd if he'd hung a string of onions around his neck.

The practicals

Ryanair flies twice daily from London Stansted to Carcassonne throughout the summer. From October 29, there will be one flight a day. They operate one flight a day from Stansted to Perpignan all year round, with a second flight on Saturdays between July 22 and September 2. Fares start at around £35 each way plus tax but rise according to availability. Ryanair has a deal with Hertz car rental, and a diesel Renault Megane costs around £170 a week with a £500 deposit. Accomodation is cheap and varied. Every town and village has at least a basic chambres d'htes , essentially a room in a family home for around £10 a night including breakfast. For gîtes, check www.gites-de-france.fr. A room in a basic two-star hotelstarts at around £30, but for a slice of luxury try the Hotel de la Cité in Carcassonne, which costs £120 a night for a double.

webTitle: Women win payout for soldier's race abuse

fields.headline: Women win payout for soldier's race abuse
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Two black women who were subjected to a barrage of racial abuse at an army base have been awarded thousands of pounds in compensation by a judge.
fields.body:
Two black women who were subjected to a barrage of racial abuse at an army base have been awarded thousands of pounds in compensation by a judge.

Sue Hunter and her sister Angie DeMeyer suffered chants of "nigger" and say they had guns pointed at them when they attended a dance at Oakington barracks, Cambridgeshire, in August 1995.

The women say their ordeal came at the hands of soldiers of the first battalion of the Cheshire regiment, based at the barracks, whose commander-in-chief is the Prince of Wales.

Nottingham county court ordered former soldier Kenneth Bragg to pay £7,000 compensation to Mrs DeMeyer and £5,000 to Mrs Hunter. He was dismissed from the army after a court martial in August 1997 for racially abusing the two women.

But the county court on Thursday dismissed a claim for damages against the Ministry of Defence after the ministry argued it was not liable for the women's ordeal, even though this happened on its land.

The MoD was condemned by Mrs Hunter, from Leicester. She said yesterday that several soldiers who had never been punished were involved: "What annoys me is the MoD's attitude towards the case, they have still not apologised."

webTitle: Kingfisher refugee could be Marks' man

fields.headline: Kingfisher refugee could be Marks' man
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Anxiety that Marks & Spencer's rumoured new chief executive lacked the experience needed to turn the troubled retailer around knocked its shares yesterday.
fields.body:
Anxiety that Marks & Spencer's rumoured new chief executive lacked the experience needed to turn the troubled retailer around knocked its shares yesterday.

The group, which has repeatedly denied looking for a new chief executive, is widely expected to appoint Roger Holmes, a director of Kingfisher, into the role of director of UK retailing. It would then groom him as the replacement for Peter Salsbury, the M&S chief executive.

M&S refused to comment on the appointment but Kingfisher, which this week announced plans to demerge its Woolworths and Superdrug chains from its electrical retailing operation, admitted that Mr Holmes intended to "take up a career opportunity currently outside of the group".

Kingfisher, which is still negotiating the departure terms for Paris-based Mr Holmes, announced his intention to leave amid a series of management changes related to its planned demerger.

As part of the restructuring, Martin Toogood, currently chief executive of do-it-yourself group B&Q, will be chief executive of the new general merchandise arm of the demerged Kingfisher, comprising Woolworths and Superdrug. M&S shares fell 5.75p to 210.25p at the close last night.

webTitle: Met calls for rethink on carnival

fields.headline: Met calls for rethink on carnival
fields.trailText: The venue for the Notting Hill carnival should be reviewed in response to public fears over "extreme and unacceptable levels of crime", the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, has said in a report.
fields.body:
The venue for the Notting Hill carnival should be reviewed in response to public fears over "extreme and unacceptable levels of crime", the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, has said in a report.

Crime at this year's carnival rose by 27%. Two men were murdered, 11 stabbings were reported and robberies rose from 13 last year to 132.

There were "areas which seem particularly important to review, and which may yield changes to the event and the policing which give a good chance of improving public safety and reducing crime and disorder", Sir John's report to the Metropolitan police authority said. These included "the suitability of the venue for such numbers".

Despite having an average of 2,474 officers on duty on each of the three days, "crime could take place within 10 metres of a group of officers, and they would be completely unaware of it.

"This crowd density, together with noise levels and the capacity of radio and phone systems, also makes command and communication very challenging," the report said.

It rejected accusations that there was a "politically correct" policing policy at the carnival.

Press Association

fields.headline: Twin dilemmas of God and man
fields.trailText: The discussion over the fate of the conjoined twins Mary and Jodie has been painted by some as a case of "the rationalists against the religious as usual."
fields.body:
The discussion over the fate of the conjoined twins Mary and Jodie has been painted by some as a case of "the rationalists against the religious as usual."

The assumption behind this generalisation is that the rationalists will be those putting forward reasoned arguments about the scientific possibilities and what is in the best interests of the twins, while the religious will be making impassioned statements about the will of the Almighty and how we humans should not interfere in such matters.

Of course, there are those whose approach to religion is a fundamentalist one, claiming that every word in ancient, supposedly divine, texts must be rigidly followed, and who see every happening in their lives in terms of some kind of divine reward or punishment for their behaviour, or that of previous generations. If this were true of all religious points of view, and all adherents to religion, I would be inclined to agree with the dismissive view of this perspective, and allow the rationalists (whoever they may be) to win the day.

But, as a rabbi, I assume I have the right to define myself as a religious person. Members of my congregation - and other congregations - presumably see themselves in the same terms. This manifests itself not in adherence to archaic and outdated practices and beliefs, but in a genuine attempt to learn about the world, using our ancestors' wisdom as a starting point.

At this time of the year, a series of laws from the Book of Deuteronomy is read in synagogues. A fundamentalist approach to these laws would, of course, regard them as divine law to be obeyed without question, but that is not my position, nor that of reform or progressive Judaism.

The latter approach to this religious text would see it as a collection of regulations, whose purpose was to establish a society which demonstrated justice, both individually and collectively, in the moral, political and social spheres of the existence of a group of people some 2,500 years ago. Such laws and regulations were an attempt by our ancestors to come to terms with a strange and puzzling world, and to create structures to promote justice and an understanding of the divine will.

Thus it is that we read that it is forbidden to abuse a needy and destitute labourer, whether a fellow countryman or a stranger in one of the communities of your land (Deuteronomy 24:14). Thus it is that instruction is given not to subvert the rights of the stranger or the fatherless, nor to take a widow's garment in pawn (24:17). Thus it is that our ancestors are told not to gather every last sheaf, olive or grape at harvest time, but to leave some for those who are needy (24:19-21).

Such laws are not the fundamentalist ravings of humans who subvert their own will and behaviour to the apparent demands of some invisible greater power. These are intelligent, sensible teachings, whose aim is to create justice - hardly the irrational perspective on the world which many supposed rationalists seem keen to assign to anything which defines itself as religious.

The truth is that religion and rationalism are as entwined as - well, as conjoined twins, I suppose. And while the question of separating the two does not bear the same level of personal anguish and potential tragedy as the case of Mary and Jodie, in terms of the future development of humanity we would do well to recognise that religion and God have a voice and a contribution to make in an increasingly rationalist and scientific world.

Religion does not offer scientific and medical explanations and options. It does not (though some might consider it does) give pseudo-theological justification for tragic occurrences by regarding them as some kind of divine punishment for apparent previous failings. Instead, it offers a blanket of comfort, a framework within which elements of humanity that cannot be rationally defined - such as compassion and care - find expression.

And it is here that religion can speak out most clearly in a world seemingly obsessed with scientific and rational definitions - by recognising that there are elements of life which cannot be so easily quantified, that what makes us human is not our ability to rationalise and explain, but our capacity to care and support one another, to yearn for harmony and, where there is none, to hope and struggle against seemingly impossible odds to rediscover its possibility.

If there is anything to be learned from the tragic case of Mary and Jodie, let it be this: the parents deserve our compassion and our respect, and, in the end, whatever the legal and ethical niceties, the decision about their tragic offspring's future can only be theirs, since they must live with its consequences.

The rest of us can only silently acknowledge their anguish and courage, and recognise that such courage, and the concern which this situation has evoked, is a testimony to the nobility of the human spirit. And that is a religious statement.

Pete Tobias is rabbi of the Glasgow new synagogue.

fields.headline: Prague braced for demos
fields.standfirst: Borders jammed as thousands arrive for IMF-World Bank annual conference
fields.trailText: Border crossings into the Czech Republic were jammed yesterday as thousands of anti-globalisation protesters began streaming into the country for next week's International Monetary Fund and World Bank annual meeting.
fields.body:
Border crossings into the Czech Republic were jammed yesterday as thousands of anti-globalisation protesters began streaming into the country for next week's International Monetary Fund and World Bank annual meeting.

Motorists on the Austrian, German, Polish and Slovak borders were delayed for up to eight hours as the police carried checked almost every vehicle for weapons, ammunition and explosives, fearing that they would be used in riots during the September 19 to 28 summit.

Long delays were also reported at Prague airport and on the railways.

The police and pressure groups reported that scores of people had been turned back at the border, mostly to Germany.

On the outskirts of Prague, protesters linked to the umbrella group Initiative Against Economic Globalisation said they had set up a camp at a farm 37 miles outside the city, but refused to reveal the exact location.

In the next few days 25 activists will be trained in demonstration management, first aid, tree climbing and samba dancing.

As the biggest security operation in the Czech Republic's history got under way, the police stressed that their main aim was not to crush the demonstrations or the scheduled "counter summit".

"Our prime concern is to ensure the smooth-running of the conference from start to finish," the police president, Jiri Kolar, said.

He said that after close cooperation with officers from the FBI and Scotland Yard, the Czech police had lists of "several hundred people whose entry into the Czech Republic is undesirable at the time of the meeting", including protesters who took part in the May Day riots in London.

About 23,000 delegates and 15,000 to 25,000 protesters are expected to attend the meeting.

There have been 5,000 bookings over the internet for a "tent city" set up in a former communist concrete monolith, the Strahov stadium.

This the first such event to be held in a country of the former Soviet bloc, and the authorities are nervous.

Eleven thousand police officers - more than a quarter of the country's entire force - backed-up by 1,600 soldiers will be present in Prague. About 100 independent observers will monitor the actions of the police.

"We've never had to deal with anything like this before," the police spokeswoman, Ivana Zelenakova, said.

"The water cannons have not been used since the demonstrations in the run-up to the 'Velvet Revolution' of 1989, so we're having to dust them off."

Teargas equipment has been borrowed from Germany.

"The British police persuaded us to use mounted police because they create a distinct psychological advantage by towering above protesters," Ms Zelenakova said.

fields.headline: Still ill
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I used to scoff at my dead grandmother Edna Mole's assertion that microwaves damage the brain, but since upgrading to a superior wattage I have noticed a diminution of brain power.
fields.body:
Saturday, September 9, Arthur Askey Walk, Ashby-de-la-Zouch.

There are now two male members of our family in hospital: my father's infections keep mutating, and he is now the subject of a controlled trial. He's in an isolation unit. Quite honestly, this has come as quite a relief: visiting is strictly forbidden. It is possible to observe him through a glass panel, but what's the point of driving seven miles there and seven miles back to watch a middle-aged man puzzling over the Sun crossword.

Ivan Braithwaite has also been forbidden visitors. The psychiatric nurse in charge of him, a certain Steve Harper, said, "Ivan needs a break from the family dynamic." The family dynamic in question, my mother, is furious and spends most of the day sitting outside the locked ward telling anybody who will listen that it is "an overload of information technology that caused Ivan's breakdown". He'd processed 300 emails only half-an-hour before he cracked, she told me. I am now convinced that technology is to blame for most of society's ills.

I used to scoff at my dead grandmother Edna Mole's assertion that microwaves damage the brain, but since upgrading to a superior wattage I have noticed a diminution of brain power. It took me more than an hour to remember whether it was Shakespeare who wrote, "He that sleeps feels not the toothache", or Sir Walter Raleigh. I spoke these words at 4am to Glenn, who has got an abscess. However, he didn't sleep but kept me awake with his groans of pain. It was just our luck not to have a single painkilling tablet in the house.

Sunday, September 10

At first light, I went to the emergency chemist and asked for Paracetemol. The chemist, a child of 10, asked me if I intended to kill myself. I assured her that I didn't, and she handed over the pills. I tried to buy petrol today, but the queues were too long and there was a fight on the forecourt. Why?

Monday, September 11

Mohammed at the BP garage refused to sell me more than £5-worth of lead-free this morning. We were at school together, and our relationship has deepened in friendship over my fuel-buying years, yet he refused to help me out. How am I going to get William to school? There is no convenient public transport, and the journey is almost a mile.

Wednesday, September 13

I rang my MP, Pandora Braithwaite, to complain about the fuel crisis. She reminded me that when we were school-children together we used to walk a mile-and-a-half to Neil Armstrong Comprehensive School. I reminded her that, "This is the year 2000, where paedophiles stalk the avenues and cul-de-sacs."

She said scornfully, "You've obviously forgotten that sweetshop keeper who used to pretend his trousers had fallen down when we innocently asked for a gobstopper." I asked her why she was in such a bad mood. She said, "On the contrary, I'm in an excellent mood. I'm relieved that I'm not mentioned in Andrew Rawnsley's book, Servants Of The People. I was sure he was going to use that story about me and Mo and Gordon Brown in that hotel service lift at Bournemouth."

Thursday, September 14

Glenn has come home from school with a homework project about third world poverty. I took him to the library on the estate on a search for information. Unfortunately, it was closed due to "staff shortages". I rang my mother and she brought round some statistics she'd found on the internet. I was shocked to realise that me and my boys have been living in third world poverty for the past two years.

Glenn is relieved: he was planning to do his project on Bangladesh, but now, as he says, "All I have to do is go walkin' round the streets talkin' to people, Dad."

fields.headline: Hotel du Vin, Bristol
fields.trailText: Spacious, 'loft-style' bedrooms, each individually named after a wine house, complete with smart, simple, modern decor and leather armchairs. Oh, and CD players.
fields.body:
Address: Hotel du Vin & Bistro, The Sugar House, Narrow Lewins Mead, Bristol, BS1 2NU.
Tel: 0117 9255577.
Web address: www.hotelduvin.com

First impressions: Grade ll-listed former sugar refinery with picturesque courtyard.

What are the rooms like? Spacious, "loft-style" bedrooms, each individually named after a wine house, complete with smart, simple, modern decor and leather armchairs. Oh, and CD players.

The bed test: The vast, custom-made, blissfully-comfy über-beds are the best thing about this place - and the Egyptian cotton bed linen is a nice touch.
