As he's gathering up his various instruments ready to leave - the accordion, the bagpipes, the didgeridoo, the Jew's harp - he breaks off to draw a cartoon for my daughter, whistling throughout, even though he is already late checking in for his flight. As we descend to the lobby, he hugs the hotel manager. He hugs the publicity girl. He hugs me. He waves and smiles from the back of the car, ever cheery, his didgeridoo jammed up against him, his 10-gallon hat - the sort that ought to be hung with corks - on his head. He looks like a cartoon. In fact, he looks like a Rolf Harris cartoon. I expect he always will. Then the car drives away, until I can no longer tell who it is.  Fine Day is released on September 25.

fields.headline: Project Telecom float relaunch
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Project Telecom, which abandoned plans for a flotation in the face of a turbulent stock market earlier this year, yesterday gave details of the lowered price for its second attempt at a float.
fields.body:
Project Telecom, which abandoned plans for a flotation in the face of a turbulent stock market earlier this year, yesterday gave details of the lowered price for its second attempt at a float.

The company will join the market with a value of £152m, down from £250m under the original listing plans which would have seen the company floating in May.

The offer price has been clawed back to 70p a share, raising £20m instead of the £30m the company had previously hoped for.

Project Telecom has placed 50m shares with insitutional investors and employees.

The company's chief executive, Tim Radford, said the group had been the victim of poor timing in the previous at tempt to join the market. "It was frustrating. The market disappeared beneath us.

"I'm just delighted we're going ahead - and no doubt we will put the value back in the business."

The business provides telecommunications services to the corporate market - focusing on the mobile market, where it has 41,000 customers including News International and the Royal Air Force.

It aims to use the cash raised to build up its corporate back office ahead of the introduction of next generation mobile services.

The group was founded in 1987, and last year reported pre-tax profits of £3.7m on sales of £117m.

Trading in the shares will begin on Tuesday.

fields.headline: EMI 'still hopeful' of EU approval
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: EMI last night was playing down suggestions that its merger with Warner Music had already been scuppered by regulators in Brussels.
fields.body:
EMI last night was playing down suggestions that its merger with Warner Music had already been scuppered by regulators in Brussels.

A spokesman insisted that the music business was still hopeful it could settle the European Union's outstanding concerns, despite the circulation of a draft report appearing to block the £14bn deal.

Executives from the music business are holding critical talks with EU competition commissioner Mario Monti on Monday, and will submit written responses to any remaining concerns he has by midnight on Tuesday. The EMI spokesman said talks with the commission were focused on how the deal could be done.

The primary issue appears to be that the industry may be narrowed down from five to four dominant players. Regulators are also worried about the distribution of music via the net due to Time Warner's planned merger withAOL.

An EU spokesman said a draft negative decision did not necessarily mean the deal would be blocked but set out very specific problems which needed to be dealt with.

"It is a standard procedure that a draft decision is prepared at this stage. It is only against a backdrop of an anticipated negative decision that a settlement can be reached."

A decision from the EU is due to be announced on October 18. Shares in EMI yesterday fell 14p to 571p.

fields.headline: Adventures in old Fleet Street
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham talks to Modesty Blaise's creator, Peter O'Donnell
fields.trailText: John Cunningham talks to Modesty Blaise's creator, Peter O'Donnell
fields.body:
Modesty Blaise is dead. True to form, she was fleeing gunfire in a remote South American valley when she caught the fatal bullet; moments before, she'd revealed to steadfast sidekick Willie Garvin that she had a terminal brain disease, adding prophetically: "I'd rather go with a bang than a whimper."

Modesty was granted her last wish four years ago, in a collection of short stories which her creator, Peter O'Donnell, intended as the finale to her literary existence. She is still extant, though, in the long-running newspaper strip. And she's alive and kicking (literally - as a martial arts expert) on the internet, thanks to her fans and much to O'Donnell's surprise.

Modesty's age has always been problematical: in the last book, Cobra Trap (now reissued Buy it at BOL), someone surmises that she's 52, "though her body would have passed for 30". On her website, though, a meanie has calculated that with so many adventures notched up, she must be over 70.

Chronology is not O'Donnell's strong point, but his own creative span is undisputed. He started work as a teenager in Fleet Street on "picture stories" - illustrated adventure serials for young readers. Modesty is a daughter of this genre. She was conceived 38 years ago and O'Donnell, now 80, is still backing her into tight corners in the daily syndicated version. Though the scams and scoundrels she's been involved with over the decades have been updated, what hasn't altered is the moral line - drawn somewhat arbitrarily, it may seem - and the way in which O'Donnell strives to keep her on the right side of it.

The outfit she ran - the Network - can't be classified as just another criminal gang. Based in Tangier, it was tacitly approved by the authorities, which it sometimes helped. Its operatives, though they handled many a murky assignment, never tangled with the trade in drugs or sex. And even when a load of butch broads muscled in on her act - in the Bond books and movies and TV's Charlie's Angels - Modesty refused to become a female Rambo.

O'Donnell is proud of the way she has stuck to her standards. "She does other things besides kick people in the head," he says. "She's very compassionate and vulnerable." In the early days, she would have a little weep on Willie's chest when they had been in a dicey situation, but soon pull herself together.

Modesty bid farewell to the Network several books ago and, as a very rich retiree, could afford to be picky about her subsequent challenges. She in turn has seen O'Donnell right, setting him up with a handsome home in an unspoilt Brighton square. Along with the 12 Modesty books, two other authors get pride of place on his study shelves: Madeleine Brent is blazoned on a set of bright dustjackets, while Bernard O'Donnell graces the faded spines of the other set.

Both hold the key to O'Donnell's success. Bernard was his crime reporter father, who also wrote volumes on cops and crims and gave his young son a sniff of gangland and Fleet Street. Madeleine is O'Donnell himself in drag as a romantic novelist, proving that the way to writerly wealth is to have two personae.

As a kid, he'd find stubbly scar-faced characters at the breakfast table, invited in by his dad, who knew gangland from Bethnal Green to Brighton racecourse. He was also on nodding terms with everyone in "The Print". "My old man trundled me round the newspaper offices when I was 17, giving them all first refusal of this brilliant lad," recalls O'Donnell, "and they all refused!" But Amalgamated Press took him on, writing storylines for its stable of publications for young people.

"It was a hard school," he says: writing to order, to length and to time; literate but not literary. It was hackwork at its best, and it paid off in a post-war Fleet Street avid for fiction as well as fact. "I used to write 20,000 words a week: an adventure, a detective, a western; short stories and scripts for strips." He worked in a big garret above El Vino's, but there was a flipside to the conviviality of hacks. Once, stuck for an idea, a surly editor he approached for inspiration glanced up from the racing pages and scowled: "You're a fucking author, aren't you? Well, go away and auth."

He did just that, creating Modesty in 1963 as a woman who could counter the butch heroes of pulp fiction. Nothing was wasted. From a wartime posting in the Caucasus he remembered a refugee girl, all alone at 12 or 13, who was given food by his unit, smiled her thanks and went on her way. He often pondered the mystery of her rootlessness, and years later used it as the basis for the footloose independence of Ms Blaise: the original wild child. When a film was mooted in 1964, part of the deal was for a tie-in novel. No problem: the novel did better than the subsequent movie, and he continued with the hardbacks, alternating Modesty with Madeleine, for the next 20 years.

O'Donnell's is a road to fiction and fame that no young novelist today would recognise. It had disappeared, anyway, long before Fleet Street replaced the compositor with the computer. But, hard though it was, O'Donnell makes it sound a lot more romantic than the sunbeam path of today's golden literati, with their angst and their advances. "I write from the gut about characters I care about," he says, as though nothing could be simpler.

fields.headline: What's selling in the 'original fiction' chart
fields.trailText: What's selling in the 'original fiction' chart
fields.body:
You'd have thought a title like Turning Thirty would be discouraged in this age of mass marketing - it's hardly going make friends among 50-year-old bibliophiles who might otherwise be charmed by Mike Gayle's lively take on growing older. Or perhaps it shows the purchasing power of the Friends generation - the same generation, presumably, that has pushed Never Trust a Rabbit into second place in Waterstone's in Manchester.

For the record, our critic's verdict on this short story collection, by the non-acting member of the League of Gentlemen, was that it was better than most tomes pumped out by stand-ups desperate to be taken seriously. Mark Z Danielewski's House of Leaves is altogether chunkier and more demanding - a smart po-mo chiller which seems well on its way to becoming a cult classic. While the UK's bright young things are pursuing the Puritan, here's a slab of pure rococo.

fields.headline: Paradise seed
fields.trailText:
Where is the seed

Of the tree felled ...
fields.body:
Where is the seed
Of the tree felled,
Of the forest burned,
Or living root
Under ash and cinders?
From woven bud
What last leaf strives
Into life, last
Shrivelled flower?
Is fruit of our harvest,
Our long labour
Dust to the core?
To what far, fair land
Borne on the wind
What winged seed
Or spark of fire
From holocaust
To kindle a star?

webTitle: Guardian review:  In the Shape of a Boar by Lawrence Norfolk

fields.headline: Thrill of the chase
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on the original all-action heroes in Lawrence Norfolk's In the Shape of a Boar
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on the original all-action heroes in Lawrence Norfolk's In the Shape of a Boar
fields.body:
In the Shape of a Boar
Lawrence Norfolk
320pp, Weidenfeld
£16.99
Buy it at BOL

Greek heroes, according to Lawrence Norfolk's astonishing new novel, do not require adverbs. They do not perform an action in one way or another; they either do it, or fail to do it. Such a view is now, as it doubtless was already to Homer's audiences, an idealistic dream of pure action - of man as his own reliable instrument, unassailed by doubts or contradictory intentions.

The first third of In the Shape of a Boar recounts how the ancient heroes gather in order to hunt the monstrous Boar of Kalydon, a ferocious beast that is ravaging the land because their leader's father omitted to honour Artemis in his sacrifices. The hunt is much celebrated in Greek art and sculpture. But just as the Odyssey is set at the fraught intersection between the imagined ancient purity of heroic action and the compromises of modernity - its hero, the wily Odysseus, is the man who is expert at seeming otherwise than he is - so Norfolk fashions something more doubtful and weirdly compelling from his mythical sources. His heroes track the beast into a terrain where no traces can be left: a (non-canonical) place called Agrapha, "unwritten things". Its hellish blankness stands for, among other things, the unknowability of unsung lives.

Unknowable, too, are the shapes of the original myths themselves: heroes die in one telling, only to reappear fighting a new enemy in another version. Norfolk floods the first few pages of his account with an ironic surge of scholarly footnotes, tributaries of manifold myth-rivers merging in a wild sea of contradictory meanings. Slowly this babble of papyric voices recedes, drawing the reader in expertly to the potent tug of the main text; eventually the footnotes reappear to trace the ambivalences of the tale's mysterious end.

Central to Norfolk's telling is the only woman among the heroes: the virgin huntress Atalanta. She becomes erotically fascinated by their leader, golden-haired Meleager, but the two are watched jealously by a third hero, Meilanion. His name is cognate with the Greek for "darkness"; he is the night-hunter, and soon he peels off from the throng of heroes and tracks Atalanta and Meleager in bitter silence. The heroes' number, meanwhile, is reduced by disaster: an ambush in an abandoned city, a glorious set piece of clangorous steel and soaking blood; and an inexplicable, sudden flood in a narrow gorge that leaves one hero dying, broken-boned, in a deep rock crevice.

Norfolk forges a tolling prose of hypnotic sensory immediacy. The heroes are at home in their sinews and at one with their wounds. Naming is power, and so great attention is paid to the specific names of grasses, trees and birds. The landscape itself becomes imbued with will: ravines "cut" and hillocks "nudge"; the water is "devious", while the earth will "accept" some incursions by foot or hand but not others. As the hunt nears its climax, the very rocks seem to mock the heroes' quest.

Norfolk's boar hunt is a fiercely brilliant, sustained display of virtuoso writing. The problem with the novel as a whole, in fact, is precisely that this section is too good. For it ends, at least temporarily, on page 110. What on earth, the exhilarated reader thinks, can follow this? Perhaps nothing can. Certainly what does exists in a subordinate imaginative relationship to it.

We fast-forward to Paris in the 1970s, into the company of a middle-aged poet named Solomon Memel. As a Romanian Jew during the second world war, Memel had managed to escape his home-town ghetto and trek over the mountains into Greece, where he was taken in by a group of resistance fighters. After his subsequent internment in a prison camp and repatriation at the end of the war to France, Memel achieved fame with a long poem called "The Boar Hunt". In it he immortalised a female member of the Greek resistance named Thyella, figured as a modern-day Atalanta.

Memel's poem, then, both is and is not the account we have just read; the footnotes both are, and are not, the carping emendations of Memel's childhood friend Jakob (whom he has not seen since the war) in a scandalous new edition of the poem that claims Solomon could not have witnessed the wartime events he describes. Meanwhile, Solomon is about to meet his other old friend from home, Ruth: she is now a film director, in the process of making a bizarre celluloid version of his poem that involves a half-naked man and a woman arguing in a Paris apartment.

Norfolk's flashbacks to 1940s Romania splendidly depict an atmosphere of rising paranoia and inexorable harm, while the idyllic triumvirate of Solomon, Jakob and Ruth disintegrates into a love triangle of buried jealousies and random spite. Solomon's trek across the mountains, too, is a masterfully stage-managed whirl of fear and delirium, injury and sudden action, mimicked in fast-cutting, disassociated scenes. Gone is the singing logic of a purposeful hunt across a living landscape; in its place is a modern mess of horror and confusion.

Though we do not quite know how Ruth and Jakob managed it, all three friends survive the war - so that, it appears, they can end up arguing about history and myth. Ruth and Jakob have researched Solomon's story and decided that Thyella, his poetic heroine, never existed. And the German officer cast in the role of the boar is thought insignificant rather than monstrous. The point, rather too baldly stated in the end, is that "our heroes never live the lives we require". The age of pure action, unwavering purpose, is lost; perhaps it never existed. Solomon's story never attains any grand resonance: the telling is too hesitantly modern, too neatly open-ended for that. One might read this as a failure, as an author grasping unsuccessfully at big themes on the vine of history; yet it may well be quite deliberate. The time of epic, after all, is over. The attempt to overlay history with an intelligible mythical pattern can only traduce it, even while there is no such recoverable entity as the unvarnished set of facts.

Because of the way this theme is enacted serially in its two halves, In the Shape of a Boar does not make for a traditionally satisfying novel. But then satisfaction of a certain low sort can be had anywhere you choose: in any of the wan, half-brained, style-mag sitcom-novels typed out every year by Norfolk's contemporaries. It is much rarer, and more valuable, to be exasperated by the thrilling ambition of a real writer.

Memel's poem, then, both is and is not the account we have just read; the footnotes both are, and are not, the carping emendations of Memel's childhood friend Jakob (whom he has not seen since the war) in a scandalous new edition of the poem that claims Solomon could not have witnessed the wartime events he describes. Meanwhile, Solomon is about to meet his other old friend from home, Ruth: she is now a film director, in the process of making a bizarre celluloid version of his poem that involves a half-naked man and a woman arguing in a Paris apartment. Norfolk's flashbacks to 1940s Romania splendidly depict an atmosphere of rising paranoia and inexorable harm, while the idyllic triumvirate of Solomon, Jakob and Ruth disintegrates into a love triangle of buried jealousies and random spite. Solomon's trek across the mountains, too, is a masterfully stage-managed whirl of fear and delirium, injury and sudden action, mimicked in fast-cutting, disassociated scenes. Gone is the singing logic of a purposeful hunt across a living landscape; in its place is a modern mess of horror and confusion. Though we do not quite know how Ruth and Jakob managed it, all three friends survive the war - so that, it appears, they can end up arguing about history and myth. Ruth and Jakob have researched Solomon's story and decided that Thyella, his poetic heroine, never existed. And the German officer cast in the role of the boar is thought insignificant rather than monstrous. The point, rather too baldly stated in the end, is that "our heroes never live the lives we require". The age of pure action, unwavering purpose, is lost; perhaps it never existed. Solomon's story never attains any grand resonance: the telling is too hesitantly modern, too neatly open-ended for that. One might read this as a failure, as an author grasping unsuccessfully at big themes on the vine of history; yet it may well be quite deliberate. The time of epic, after all, is over. The attempt to overlay history with an intelligible mythical pattern can only traduce it, even while there is no such recoverable entity as the unvarnished set of facts. Because of the way this theme is enacted serially in its two halves, In the Shape of a Boar does not make for a traditionally satisfying novel. But then satisfaction of a certain low sort can be had anywhere you choose: in any of the wan, half-brained, style-mag sitcom-novels typed out every year by Norfolk's contemporaries. It is much rarer, and more valuable, to be exasperated by the thrilling ambition of a real writer.

fields.headline: One man went to mow
fields.standfirst: A man and his lawnmower are not easily parted. It's a hunter-gatherer thing, claims Tom Fort in a new book. Celia Woolfrey checks out the lumps and bumps of his home turf, and gets a lesson in psychoanalysis to boot
fields.trailText: A man and his lawnmower are not easily parted. It's a hunter-gatherer thing, claims Tom Fort in a new book. Celia Woolfrey checks out the lumps and bumps of his home turf, and gets a lesson in psychoanalysis to boot.
fields.body:
One of the first things Tom Fort does is apologise for the state of his lawn, as I knew he would, because, as he says in his new book, lawn people are never happy with the level, or the composition, or the general condition of their grass.

To be fair, Fort isn't a full-on lawn man, more someone who has flirted with a cult and then drawn back after glimpsing a strange world populated by, among others, mower spotters and those who creep out at night to impale moles on garden forks. Both these feature in The Grass Is Greener: Our Love Affair With The Lawn. An obsessive love, then?

Actually, no. You can tell from the lumps and bumps in his lawn that Fort has not gone over to the dark side. He is more interested in history than gardening tips, and chose the lawn as his subject because he was fascinated about how worked-up people - men, in particular - get about the grass.

His book is all about one-upmanship; how national pride, social status, even sexual identity can be bound up in the greenness and smoothness of the grass. It is also about his own attempts to make a lawn: not a how-to book, more how-not-to.

Fort is much more affable than I had been expecting after his on-page asides about figures such as the poet Alexander Pope ("that stunted draper's son"), smart-arsed presenters of gardening TV shows, garden columnists trotting out the same old advice year after year, even the way that "wandering cats crap and bitches spray their discolouring piss" on lawns, ruining the grass. A former radio news journalist (he quit after 22 years) and current angling correspondent for the Financial Times, he lives with his second wife, Helen, in an Oxfordshire village because he feels like he belongs in this part of England, though it's a "geographical mischance" that leaves them just the wrong side of the Berkshire border, where he was born.

The scope of the book is vast, and shifts from the Cotswold wool industry to grand 18th-century estates to the golf-courses of 20s America, with thought-provoking views on the differences between men and women offered up alongside the historical research. These boil down to his belief that men love lawns because, like dogs, they repay love and attention, and women aren't bothered about lawns, apparently, because we aren't afraid to venture into the flowerbeds (" terra incognita " for men, writes Fort), where there is much more interesting gardening to be done.

Fort tries to play down this side of the book: "Women have got nothing against looking at a good lawn [as opposed to making one]," he says. "This is my view, and most of my views on most subjects are disputed by somebody. But the gender aspect didn't dawn on me so forcibly until I started talking to lawn people. The early research was from a historical angle. Here's an aspect of Anglo-Saxon life, but who invented it? And what did people do before the mower?"

It's true, there is a lot on the evolution of the motor mower in the book, but Fort's theories about the man behind the mower were always bound to provoke more of a reaction."I tried not to get too heavy about it, it was only a bit of fun," he says. "The thing about grass cutting is that all the women I spoke to were grateful that they didn't have to do it, because it's intrinsically such an incredibly boring, pointless exercise." Man, on the other hand - Fort calls him a "domesticated hunter-gatherer and demobilised warrior" - was always going to head straight for anything that involved playing with some machine as soon as he got in the garden. "The point is that it's harmless, unlike a lot of other things men do."

Social psychologist Michael Argyle told Fort that "his instinctive response on encountering a man with a keen enthusiasm for flowers would be to assume he was homosexual". He made further enquiries with the eminent psychologist Halla Beloff, who confirmed that a liking for flowers, and skill at flowering arranging, were part of a traditional evaluation of sexual identity and orientation. Later, she got back to him with further thoughts on the subject - opening the conversation with the question,"Have you considered the phallic dimension of mowing?" Her thinking was that pushing out all that thrusting, throbbing motor mower in front of you, cutting a swathe through the rampaging grass and making nice straight lines fits the male desire to feel potent and to change the world.

Fort asked lawnsman and novelist Jim Crace about this impulse: "Crace thought it sprang from a deeply imprinted desire to control and domesticate nature. It was, he agreed, a purely masculine province, legitimised by being distinct from housework."

Fort is at his best when he shows how mowing became central to the 20th-century suburban code in this country and in America, or, as the magazine Better Homes & Gardens put it, "Not to mow is to attack one's neighbours, lowering the value of their homes and calling into question the integrity of the street."

There are also autobiographical breaks, in which Fort talks about childhood games of cricket and football with two of his three brothers, James and Matthew (now Guardian food and drink editor) - the third brother, Johnny, preferred his train set, while sister Elizabeth was too young - when they used two cigar-shaped yew bushes as goal-posts and infuriated their mother, "a very keen and accomplished gardener", with direct hits on the greenhouse or, worse, on her.

A brief but telling reference is made to the death of their father when Tom was eight, and the subsequent way that he was initiated into lawncare by his elder brothers and the family odd-job man, Albert. "My father was an MP, but he was untypical - he wasn't like today's breed of career politician; he did it because he wanted to be of service to his country, and similarly clapped-out old ideas of the past. The mower, a 24-inch Dennis, was his purchase; it was just a fantastic machine."

His descriptions of the mowing ritual are evocative, recognisable to anyone whose teeth have been set on edge by the gritty sound of the mower being rolled across concrete, or who knows the musty smell of the shed or the sweet warmth of decomposing grass.

Jim Crace lost his father, too, and found himself taking on his father's duties, including a fanatical zeal for lawncare, as he lay dying. Crace's theory is that, in the transition from boy to man, by taking on lawncare, men turn into their fathers.

So, did a Crace-style rite of passage occur a couple of years ago when Tom Fort made his lawn? "I'm never sure what a rite of passage is supposed to be," he says. "My son has just come back from Ayia Napa in Cyprus, which is widely described as a rite of passage, which appears to me to be drinking and throwing up all night. So, no, I don't think of it like that," he says.

Fort's favourite lawns are at Chatsworth House, on the east side, in front of Paxton's cascade, where an incredible range of wildflower species, hidden for centuries in the turf, are being allowed to flourish instead of being killed off by chemicals or scarified out. Perhaps with this, and the trend towards wildflower meadows and new perennial planting on both sides of the Atlantic, the orthodox lawn is fast becoming another clapped-out old idea of the past.

Whatever the case, once hooked, the lawn can be an addiction. Fort keeps promising himself that he is not going to bother with his unruly lawn any more. "I've spent hours on it to no good effect," he says. "But then I thought, at the end of the year I'll do a proper top dressing, then some scarifying, and then , if it's no good, I'll give up."

 The Grass Is Greener, by Tom Fort, is published by Harper Collins priced £12.99.

webTitle: Guardian review:  How It Ended by Jay McInerney

fields.headline: Me, myself, ayee-e-e!
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer  admires subtle stories of self-discovery in Jay McInerney's  How It Ended
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer admires subtle stories of self-discovery in Jay McInerney's How It Ended
fields.body:
How It Ended
Jay McInerney
160pp, Bloomsbury
£12.99
Buy it at BOL

Readers who have come across anything at all by Jay McInerney will buy this set of stories whatever I write here, because they will know in advance that his plots are watertight, his characters are immediate and his style, without being over-polished, has lasting shine.

Readers who haven't read him yet will find this collection the perfect way to make his acquaintance. Normally a novelist, McInerney has set out to prove he can handle that slippery form, the short story. He succeeds with ease. His efforts all manage to run their natural length, being genuinely short without feeling compacted or reading like novels ruthlessly sliced off at either end. They aren't overstuffed with character or incident, nor are they heavy with laborious detail. They are single-issue without being simple-minded.

A couple spend their first Christmas together on opposing drugs (one on uppers, one on downers). The girl ends up wishing she could strip her visible skin off altogether and arise brand-new. A would-be president is sunk when people on his own side expose his sexual infidelities in revenge for his indifference to their loyalty. In doing so they not only betray their own political principles but irreparably damage their country, leaving it "on its knees, governed by men without character or conviction".

Two lovers give up smoking together, and thereafter every stolen cigarette assumes the significance of infidelity, generating real if hypocritical grief on the part of the cuckolded (but also secretly smoking) partner. A young man longs for a unified world without "divisions and divorces and separations" - in fact, on a less spiritual level, he would like to bundle four sisters up into one woman and have them all simultaneously, particularly as the one he is marrying is probably infertile, due to an abortion he himself instigated.

McInerney's characters, who live in a bluster of self-justification, are suddenly revealed to themselves as self-serving, emotionally cold, irretrievably lost or even, as in "Third Party", without intrinsic worth. Here self-satisfied Alex is picked up by a couple in Paris who seem to know him; he assumes they think he's someone famous, until he finds they have only hit on him because they consider him to be expendable.

The dark current of private lives constantly threatens to bubble up through the bright splashy public surface. In "The Business" a young screenwriter on his way to the top is momentarily sandbagged by the memory of his girlfriend leaving him many years ago - but he slams down the lid on his emotions, thinking that he will never cry again. In "The Queen and I", the glamour of the gutter is revealed as filth when a breezy transvestite prostitute climbs into a car only to discover that the expectant punter is his own father.

McInerney looks again and again at that fleeting moment of harsh insight when someone glimpses themselves as they really are - seeing themselves afresh with their own eyes, or catching their true reflection in the gaze of others. And his tales, while flying past in the reading, stick for a long time in the memory, just like one's own uncomfortable moments of self-discovery.

fields.headline: The Battle of Britain rewritten
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  on the last of the few in That Summer by Andrew Greig
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom on the last of the few in That Summer by Andrew Greig
fields.body:
That Summer
Andrew Greig
272pp, Faber
£9.99
Buy it at BOL

Andrew Greig is one of those very fine writers (Ron Butlin is another, and so are Kathleen Jamie and WN Herbert) who seem for some reason to have missed the brightly painted bandwagon that came hurtling out of Scotland back in the 1990s, driven like a Neal Cassady by Irvine Welsh - a motley crew of tanked-up old-timers and young pretenders on board, the tartan Merry Pranksters. With his new novel That Summer, Greig may finally have caught up with his more notorious and colourful compatriots.

Greig has in fact already published three novels and five books of poetry. His first novel Electric Brae (1992) was excellent, while his poetry is uniformly good. He has also written two books about his experiences as a mountaineer. These are remarkable because it is rare for writers to be climbers; or rather, it is rare for writers to be mountain climbers. In Edmund White's formulation, "Writers are creatures with working-class salaries, middle-class origins and upper-class pretensions."

In his book Feeding the Rat, the poet and critic Al Alvarez describes climbing - borrowing a phrase of Jeremy Bentham's - as a kind of "deep play". He explains: "In deep play the stakes are so high that, in Bentham's view, it is irrational for anyone to engage in it at all, since the marginal utility of what you stand to win is grossly outweighed by the disutility of what you stand to lose." Deep play is exactly what Andrew Greig does best.

That Summer is set in the summer of 1940, and the stakes are very high indeed. On July 10 the Luftwaffe stages a major attack on a Channel convoy. "They don't know what just begun. They don't know about the Battle of Britain; it's not called that yet." Leonard Westbourne is a young Hurricane pilot based in Gravesend. He is described as "salt of the earth". Stella Gardam is a radar operator. She is university-educated. They meet at a dance ... You can almost fill in the rest without having read the book.

It is classic Boy's Own stuff: "Group of Stukas going down in bombing formation. After them! Flip the kite over so she won't cut out, dive. Close in, pick the rear left one. Closer, closer. Set the bloody sights! Closer. Get to 300 yards. He hasn't seen me yet. Blast, he has! Bombs falling, he's straightening, coming right across my sights ..." Women are "getting ideas". Lovers "lay ... under every hedge in England".

And the war gives people a passion and a purpose. Even Len's middle-aged father, who is in the ARP, finds a focus: "No one was as useful and quick-witted at propping up walls, opening up cellars, locating mains, comforting and joking with those whose lives had suddenly disintegrated." "War is like real life," writes Greig, "but more so."

This much is already known, and already written. In his acknowledgments Greig name-checks Fighter by Len Deighton and The People's War by Angus Calder. Their influence is palpable. What distinguishes That Summer is what distinguishes all of Greig's work: the teasing out of the complex relationship between irresolution and adventure.

Len, for example, comes to self-knowledge through his relationship with the fearless Polish airman Tadeusz: "I knew then I'd never really be a true fighter pilot. I hadn't that careless capacity to live in the present, to be, as they said, regardless." Meanwhile Stella befriends Maddy, a "cheery bouncing blonde" who teaches her to leave behind her "long drawn-out adolescence" and "insecure snobbery".

The flab and the fat of the poetic that was off-putting in some of Greig's earlier novels has finally been sweated off, and the prose is now down to its fighting weight. Like Len, the sentences are lean and almost, perhaps, a little gauche: "So many jokes, so many yarns, so much sliding away from anything difficult. So many boats and yards and rivers messed about in. So many pints of beer between those parted lips."

The book is dedicated "To the vanishing generation" and is based partly on Greig's own mother's diaries, material which he has already mined in a collection of poems, A Flame in Your Heart (1986), written with Kathleen Jamie. Not merely in its subject matter, therefore, but also in its method of composition, That Summer is a valuable lesson in how waste may be turned into use.

The book is dedicated "To the vanishing generation" and is based partly on Greig's own mother's diaries, material which he has already mined in a collection of poems, A Flame in Your Heart (1986), written with Kathleen Jamie. Not merely in its subject matter, therefore, but also in its method of composition, That Summer is a valuable lesson in how waste may be turned into use.

fields.headline: Fiction round-up
fields.trailText: Capability's Eden | Alcestis | The Illusionist | Midnight All Day |
fields.body:
Capability's Eden
Diana Saville
Flamingo, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Horticulturally inspired novels have sprung up like weeds over the last two summers. Most deserve to head straight for the compost heap, not so this one. Saville understands the slow-burning passion that a piece of ground inspires and conveys that love with subtlety. Boyd is a landscape designer who once saw himself following in the contours of Capability Brown until, inspired by a Cornish garden and the charms of its owner, he conceives the God-like folly of recreating Eden. But carnal knowledge sours his relationship with his clients, and paradise is lost. Saville plays out the allegory with restraint in an intelligent, engrossing read.

Alcestis
Ted Hughes
Faber, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

It's drama, not a novel, but so good we included it anyway. Hughes began his translation of Euripides in 1993, but only completed it in the months before his death in 1998. In between he produced the Oresteia, Tales From Ovid and a version of Racine's Phèdre. This is much more than Hughes's translation; it is suffused by his personal vision of an elemental world in which "At some point, it seems, the heavens closed". Admetos, king of Thessaly, is fated to die unless someone is prepared to die in his place. His wife Alcestis volunteers. As Apollo rages, Death waits to gather his prize. As a portrayal of human grief it is ever fresh, mesmerising and forceful.

The Illusionist
Dinitia Smith
Scribner, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

Sparta is a small town on the edge of New York State where jobs are scarce and sensitive men non-existent until Dean Lilly shows up. He performs magic tricks and is everything that three women want. To Chrissie he is a friend, to Terry a revelatory lover and to Melanie a soul mate. The only trouble is that Dean is a woman, and his deception rankles with the boys. Smith's fictionalised account of a real event is more than a nasty story. She portrays the wintry claustrophobic town and the limited expectations of its young women expertly, conveying why they need to believe Dean's deception and the suspense of knowing that their illusions must shatter.

Midnight All Day
 Hanif Kureishi
Faber, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Superficially, Kureishi has moved a long way from The Buddha of Suburbia in his second collection of short stories. The settings are large London houses with vistas of trees. The characters are well-paid upmarket types with record collections frozen in time and only recreational drug habits. Underneath, though, their frustrations are as deep and their anxieties have the same sharp edges. Alternating between novella length stories and single-incident tales, Kureishi writes of Janus-faced people unsure whether to turn towards comfortable relationships or be pulled towards the excitement of a lover. An admirable collection.

webTitle: Guardian review:  The Mark of the Angel

fields.headline: Critical mass
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard becomes embroiled in the debate around Nancy Huston's The Mark of the Angel
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard becomes embroiled in the debate around Nancy Huston's The Mark of the Angel
fields.body:
The Mark of the Angel
Nancy Huston
Vintage, £6.99

Buy it at BOL

You may know that insurers purse their lips when it comes to insuring journalists. Fair dos, you might think, they get into all kinds of scrapes. What surprised me was when I learned that insurers - or at least the ones I have the misfortune to deal with - don't like even book reviewers that much. Speaking as someone whose main professional fear lies in typing half a paragraph in capital letters by mistake, this strikes me as unnecessarily cautious. (True, Jeanette Winterson has been known to serenade reviewers with invective in the small hours, but it's hardly criminal damage and you can take steps to avoid this, mainly by not reviewing her work.)

So I'm quite excited to discover that I may be entering into a little literary controversy simply by mentioning this novel. I picked it up off the pile with few expectations, beyond the fact that its publisher is pretty reputable and it had a laudatory quote from Alberto Manguel, author of the intelligent and likeable A History of Reading, on the back. A Times reviewer, unnamed, said "tense, chillingly beautiful, moving ... this is first-class reading".

Well, one learns to take such things with a pinch of salt, for there are often wheels within wheels when it comes to reviewing (though not in these pages, of course), but Manguel carries a fair amount of weight round these parts, so off I went.

The story begins in 1957, as a young Parisian flautist hires Saffie, a fascinatingly inscrutable German, to be his maid. She fascinates him so much, in fact, that he asks her to marry him. "That's OK with me," she says. (The novel has been translated from the French by the author.) The only change of tone in her calm, almost supernatural indifference comes when she freaks out completely at the sound of an alarm clock; and, during her pregnancy, when Huston does a cleverly understated but still quite alarming attempted auto-abortion scene. When the child is born, we duly fear for its safety.

It turns out that Saffie, of course, has some very nasty memories of the war; and when she meets a charismatic Hungarian instrument repairer called András, they can share their unspoken war traumas, in a manner of speaking (or not speaking). Meanwhile, as Huston reminds us, the French are doing terrible things to Algerians.

It all chunters along quite enjoyably if you read it without too many expectations, or much scrutiny. Huston's voice may occasionally become irritatingly arch, but it is still very readable; as befits a book that was not only a best-seller in France but won the Grand Prix des Lectrices d'Elle - by which I understand that the readers of the French edition of Elle magazine considered it their fave book of 1998. This was one of the grievances of a highly dismissive review in the TLS, which complained that the novel's triteness was particularly offensive in the light of the events it leans on for its historical power.

At which point this reviewer raises his hands in despair. I can see what the objections are to this novel; it is, in truth, a far thinner story than it claims to be. And yet it is perfectly pleasurable to read. It is not criminally inane, like that novel Damage by Josephine Hart, which was turned into a rotten film with Jeremy Irons. One reads The Mark of the Angel at the kitchen table, munching an apple and at times forgetting which hand is holding the apple and which the book. And there is room in the culture for that kind of novel, isn't there?

fields.headline: Non-fiction round-up
fields.trailText: Memories of the Great and the Good | The Essential Groucho
fields.body:
Memories of the Great and the Good
Alistair Cooke
Pavilion
£7.99
Buy it at BOL

Extended, reminiscent footnotes, which are the Cooke-ian forte, more pertinent than grand commentary. Frank Lloyd Wright was "like Merlin posing as Whistler's Mother" in a room "seedy, in a lavish Edwardian way". That's the defining architect of the American century skewered in a sentence. PG Wodehouse at 80 asked AC if it was wise of the Guardian to drop the name Manchester (er, no), while a dachshund snuffled at the door. Contains AC's graceful goodbye to Charles "Peanuts" Schulz - "all the loves are unrequited, the Great Pumpkin never comes", connecting him with the frenetic unhopefulness of Mark Twain. Ace.

The Essential Groucho
ed by Stefan Kanfer
Penguin
£6.99
Buy it at BOL

Reprints dialogue from stage, films and radio - which is less writing than a form of choreographic notation for words, following their rapid movement and angle of attitude. In this, and in his later letters and journalism, Marx comes over as a key link between the comic naturalism of 19th century novels or the improvised shtick of that era's low theatre, and 20th century movies and live television - in which Groucho retained his delight in unpredictability and taking risks at flywheel-spinning speed. This is also a parallel social history; Groucho left no aspect of sport, finance or politics unturned, or, indeed, unharmed.

fields.headline: Darkness at Noone
fields.standfirst: Robert Potts on Armistead Maupin's intimate tale of abuse and doubt,  The Night Listener
fields.trailText: Robert Potts on Armistead Maupin's intimate tale of abuse and doubt, The Night Listener
fields.body:
The Night Listener
Armistead Maupin
344pp, Bantam
£16.99
Buy it at BOL

Armistead Maupin became famous through his Tales of the City, a series of books tracking the fortunes of a kooky and loveable bunch of San Francisco denizens through the 70s and 80s. Although Maupin is gay, his books are not exclusively about homosexuality; there is a diversity, generosity and inclusivity (not to mention buoyant humour) that has given them enormous and international appeal. They began as newspaper serialisations, making them pacy and multi-plotted. They were warm, sweet, funny entertainments (though with darker political themes in the Reaganite, Aids-scarred 80s); but Maupin's subsequent work suggests he has ambitions beyond the literary sitcom.

In his latest novel, The Night Listener, Gabriel Noone, the narrator, is a writer of short stories for a late-night radio show. As he explains early on, "my characters were a motley but loveable bunch, people caught in the supreme joke of modern life who were forced to survive by making families of their friends. The show eventually became a cult hit ... while this fulfilled me hugely as a storyteller, it left me feeling illegitimate as a writer, as if I'd broken into the Temple of Literature through some unlocked basement window."

Noone shares many characteristics with Maupin: both served in the US navy and in Vietnam; both have recently split up with long-term partners; both came out to their parents through their work, with identical results. When it emerges that Noone is struggling with writer's block, and one considers that Maupin's most recent novel was published as far back as 1992, one is less than convinced by the other pun in Gabriel's surname - that it can be read as "no one".

Noone's long-term boyfriend, Jess, has had Aids for a decade; Noone has used him as his main character and was convinced that Jess would die in his arms. But Jess not only moves out to "take a break" and explore other lovers; he also reveals that his health, with new medication, is not worsening. (Noone's difficulty in feeling happy about this news is harrowingly rendered.) Noone, in his 50s and suddenly alone, finds distraction in the manuscript of a memoir, sent to him by the publisher in the hope of a good blurb.

The Blacking Factory (the title is a reference to Dickens's traumatic childhood) is the story of a 13-year-old boy, Pete, horrifically sexually abused by his parents and their friends, who is rescued and adopted by a social worker, Donna Lomax. But Pete is already dying of Aids. In the darkness of hospital wards, he has been listening to Noone's show: "The man's voice was low and soothing, the voice of an understanding father. And sometimes, though Pete knew better, it seemed to be speaking to Pete alone."

The two, with the assistance of Donna, begin a quasi-parental relationship by telephone in which Noone is the good father Pete never had and Pete is the son Gabriel does not have. In the course of this relationship Noone is able to discuss, and come to terms with, his relationship with Jess and also with his own parents, particularly his provocatively prejudiced yet stumblingly loving father. The healing that Pete affords Noone is compromised, however, by doubt. Did Pete write his own story? Is Pete's story true? And, most unsettlingly, does Pete really exist?

It would spoil an excellent psychological drama to say any more about the plot. What is interesting is that Maupin, clearly wanting to write a more serious piece of fiction, has not had to depart radically from his successful format; The Night Listener is a serialised work (broadcast on American radio this autumn) of generous liberalism. What he has added is a darkness of texture, not simply in the atrocity of Pete's abuse, but also Noone's vulture-like solipsism, which is gradually exposed and criticised by family and friends. And, although the devices are far from shocking or original, Maupin's disruption of trust and certainty in his narratives is achieved precisely and with deceptive simplicity.

Noone is an unreliable narrator, and reliably tells us so from the first chapter, resonantly titled "The Elephant Jeweler", in which he confesses his tendency to embellish or distort without even realising it. All unreliable narrators point out their unreliability; if they did not we would simply suspend our disbelief and trust them, this being the way fiction works. The unreliability of narratives within the unreliable narrative, however, and the narrator's anguish in his own uncertainty, are brilliantly handled. The Night Listener asks why we tell stories, and to whom, and why we listen to them.

It raises other questions of trust and identity too, not least the importance to survivors of abuse that they be unquestioningly believed, these voices in the darkness, or over the phone; the ease with which they can be mistaken; the "blacking factory" of pain from which many stories evolve. These aspects make sense of the book's central phrase: "All you have to do is believe and let go, and you'll have all the proof you need."

webTitle: Guardian review:  Eclipse by John Banville

fields.headline: Giving up the ghosts
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  acclaims one man's search for himself in  Eclipse by John Banville
fields.trailText: Alex Clark acclaims one man's search for himself in Eclipse by John Banville
fields.body:
Eclipse
John Banville
214pp, Picador
£15.99
Buy it at BOL

In John Banville's extraordinary family romance, a troubled actor returns to his deserted childhood home to exact a minute survey of his past and, by extension, of his mind. He finds it far less deserted than he imagined, and this fact provokes further self-scrutiny. During the course of the novel little else happens, save from some minor shuffling of characters and one swift, brutal event that occurs offstage at the end; but here psychological investigation stands in for plot, and Banville's inward prose comes to seem both populous and crowded with incident.

The narrator of Eclipse, Alexander Cleave, is a classical actor who has recently corpsed during a first-night speech and fled, reputation in tatters, into self-imposed exile. Despite a sense of enfolding mental crisis, his narcissism remains largely intact, much to the exasperation and despair of his abandoned wife, Lydia, who accurately detects in his return to his mother's old, creaky house the curse of arrested development. "I dreamed last night I was a child and here again," Cleave confides to her at the novel's opening, to which she justly retorts: "Of course; you never left here, that's the truth." But the insight only provokes in its object an admiration for his wife's use of iambic pentameter; later, when she challenges him in vain once again, he muses on whether her accusations take the form of anapaests or "the rarer, shyer amphibrach". His recourse to infuriating pedantry is in part sadistic, but also points towards a mental armoury which mere words or stray thoughts cannot easily dismantle.

In a state of agonised self-consciousness, Cleave clings to the limbo that the house offers: a way, as he puts it, of "being alive with out living". Variously, he ascribes this paralysis to an emotional cauterisation probably inflicted on him during childhood; to the dead parents for whom he did not grieve; to the profession that has imbued him with a constant sense of being watched and has required of him his own constant watchfulness; and to his daughter Cass, similarly tormented by demons and now miserably cordoned off in her own world.

"What confusion there is in me; I really am a stranger to myself," Cleave reflects, but his proposed solution to that inner chaos is a period of quiet introspection that soon begins to seem almost wilfully misguided. Amid the false starts and blind alleys of remembrance, he is besieged by ghosts - as he would have us and himself believe, actual ghostly presences - who move about his house in "naggingly insinuative" fashion; "ancestral resemblances" who make the furniture they perch upon "blush, almost, in the surprise of being singled out". In time, the phantoms are displaced by solid humans; by the sly surprise of Quirke, the caretaker of the house who has furtively moved in, together with his slatternly adolescent daughter, Lily. The pair regard Cleave with a mixture of bemused concern and insolent tolerance, and their arrival on the scene, like characters in a Shakespearean subplot, provides humorous counterpoint to the would-be tragic hero's manic melancholia. Banville's handling of this strand of the novel is impeccable: the gruesome comedy of manners alternating with the painful impulse that prompts Cleave to take on, ineptly and disastrously, the role of paterfamilias.

If the psychological wranglings of the situation are familiar - the unresolved detritus of childhood, the fruitless search for an authentic sense of self - then the language and tone in which they are conveyed makes them hard to recognise, not in the sense that they are unconvincing, but because the mental trauma they provoke is near impossible to unpick. "Making strange", in the idiom of Cleave's provincial town, is used to describe the upset of a frightened child when confronted by an unknown adult, and Cleave is indeed estranged from himself and from the world about him. Stranded in a past that has no use for him, he is plagued by delusion and suspended in a state of "transcendent tipsiness", an alienation that renders him both pitiful and monstrous.

Banville's flighted prose, in which atmosphere is evoked through a dripfeed of lyricism, is superbly suited to his subject matter; his willed patience and defiant wordiness resonate with an almost unbearable sense of claustrophobia and the lurid excess of breakdown. At one point, Cleave recalls a stalled session with a therapist whose diagnosis is that he is overwhelmed; in parallel, the writing expertly communicates that helplessness - the critical loss of coherence in the face of a sudden onrush of feeling. Paradoxically, words are all we have available to us to describe the indescribable, the loss of language - or of the connection with language - being a common complaint of the depressed and the psychologically dispossessed.

Eclipse avoids the doomy territory of the morality tale by its constant playfulness, and by maintaining a certain degree of detachment that, at times, infects the reader with its own ennui. Yet just as Cleave is prone to portentousness, seeing in the dazed scamper of a roadside animal the call home, or in the whirl and screech of seagulls his own family dramas, the novel is not without its message. At its close, the protagonist is summoned back to life by a vast, external event and the past, if not quite yet another country, is temporarily sidelined. Ghosts, it appears, can exist in the future as well as the past; whether or not we choose to respond to their beckoning is another matter.

The narrator of Eclipse, Alexander Cleave, is a classical actor who has recently corpsed during a first-night speech and fled, reputation in tatters, into self-imposed exile. Despite a sense of enfolding mental crisis, his narcissism remains largely intact, much to the exasperation and despair of his abandoned wife, Lydia, who accurately detects in his return to his mother's old, creaky house the curse of arrested development. "I dreamed last night I was a child and here again," Cleave confides to her at the novel's opening, to which she justly retorts: "Of course; you never left here, that's the truth." But the insight only provokes in its object an admiration for his wife's use of iambic pentameter; later, when she challenges him in vain once again, he muses on whether her accusations take the form of anapaests or "the rarer, shyer amphibrach". His recourse to infuriating pedantry is in part sadistic, but also points towards a mental armoury which mere words or stray thoughts cannot easily dismantle. In a state of agonised self-consciousness, Cleave clings to the limbo that the house offers: a way, as he puts it, of "being alive with out living". Variously, he ascribes this paralysis to an emotional cauterisation probably inflicted on him during childhood; to the dead parents for whom he did not grieve; to the profession that has imbued him with a constant sense of being watched and has required of him his own constant watchfulness; and to his daughter Cass, similarly tormented by demons and now miserably cordoned off in her own world. "What confusion there is in me; I really am a stranger to myself," Cleave reflects, but his proposed solution to that inner chaos is a period of quiet introspection that soon begins to seem almost wilfully misguided. Amid the false starts and blind alleys of remembrance, he is besieged by ghosts - as he would have us and himself believe, actual ghostly presences - who move about his house in "naggingly insinuative" fashion; "ancestral resemblances" who make the furniture they perch upon "blush, almost, in the surprise of being singled out". In time, the phantoms are displaced by solid humans; by the sly surprise of Quirke, the caretaker of the house who has furtively moved in, together with his slatternly adolescent daughter, Lily. The pair regard Cleave with a mixture of bemused concern and insolent tolerance, and their arrival on the scene, like characters in a Shakespearean subplot, provides humorous counterpoint to the would-be tragic hero's manic melancholia. Banville's handling of this strand of the novel is impeccable: the gruesome comedy of manners alternating with the painful impulse that prompts Cleave to take on, ineptly and disastrously, the role of paterfamilias. If the psychological wranglings of the situation are familiar - the unresolved detritus of childhood, the fruitless search for an authentic sense of self - then the language and tone in which they are conveyed makes them hard to recognise, not in the sense that they are unconvincing, but because the mental trauma they provoke is near impossible to unpick. "Making strange", in the idiom of Cleave's provincial town, is used to describe the upset of a frightened child when confronted by an unknown adult, and Cleave is indeed estranged from himself and from the world about him. Stranded in a past that has no use for him, he is plagued by delusion and suspended in a state of "transcendent tipsiness", an alienation that renders him both pitiful and monstrous. Banville's flighted prose, in which atmosphere is evoked through a dripfeed of lyricism, is superbly suited to his subject matter; his willed patience and defiant wordiness resonate with an almost unbearable sense of claustrophobia and the lurid excess of breakdown. At one point, Cleave recalls a stalled session with a therapist whose diagnosis is that he is overwhelmed; in parallel, the writing expertly communicates that helplessness - the critical loss of coherence in the face of a sudden onrush of feeling. Paradoxically, words are all we have available to us to describe the indescribable, the loss of language - or of the connection with language - being a common complaint of the depressed and the psychologically dispossessed. Eclipse avoids the doomy territory of the morality tale by its constant playfulness, and by maintaining a certain degree of detachment that, at times, infects the reader with its own ennui. Yet just as Cleave is prone to portentousness, seeing in the dazed scamper of a roadside animal the call home, or in the whirl and screech of seagulls his own family dramas, the novel is not without its message. webTitle: Guardian review:  All Hail The New Puritans

fields.headline: Celluloid junkies
fields.standfirst:
All Hail The New Puritans
ed Nicholas Blincoe and Matt Thorne
204pp, Fourth Estate
£10

Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: All Hail The New Puritans is really a manifesto for the New Philistinism. Fortunately, the best contributors to this book ignore the editors' rules.
fields.body:
I like manifestos, gauntlets, red rags. It is necessary to assassinate some orchards, especially when those English gardens are full of people exclaiming what a "vintage year" it has been for fiction. Wyndham Lewis's phrase, "Kill John Bull with art", has always seemed a fine slogan. But the manifesto proposed by Matt Thorne and Nicholas Blincoe in this anthology of 15 stories seems more likely to kill art with John Bull. It flourishes the possibility of a new kind of fiction, but in fact it represents a kind of hidden shame about literature, and an embarrassment that fiction is not more like film. It is really a manifesto for the New Philistinism. Fortunately, the best contributors to this book ignore the editors' rules.

Those rules are laid out in the form of a dialogue between Blincoe and Thorne. Gathering around them a group of writers in their late 20s and early 30s, they argue that "new, exciting voices" in recent contemporary fiction - generally men who, in the last three years, have written punchy novels with monosyllabic titles like Coast, Go, Seaside, Tourist, Corpsing - have been "marginalised". Blincoe and Thorne propose that the new fiction obey the following rules: it should be simple and "avoid all devices of voice", such as rhetoric and authorial asides, and shun "poetry and poetic licence in all its forms"; it should be plotty and forward-driving, and eschew flashbacks; it should be grammatically simple, and avoid elaborate punctuation; being a "fragment of time", it should be set in the present day; and all references to "products, places, artists and objects" should be "real".

The first thing to observe is that if these writers - such as Alex Garland, Bo Fowler, Thorne himself, Toby Litt - have been marginalised, then their margin is our centre, because it is difficult to move in a bookshop without falling over some dictator-sized photograph of a slightly hooliganish figure, his hair as shaved as his prose style, his mouth set in a macho moue, his fine eyes focused on some suitably menacing abstraction in the middle distance.

Second, one can hardly help agreeing that the editors, at least, should shun poetic licence, for when they indulge in it, the results are not good. Blincoe allows himself an unfortunate metaphor when he says that "poetry is defined by metre - ultimately by the storm of jackboots". (Heil Hölderlin!) Thorne, mixing a metaphor, suggests that "the building blocks of storytelling should not be focusing on the minutiae of narrative but the grand plan". (So those building blocks won't get too distracted.)

Third, this manifesto is largely a list of prohibitions. Yet the great revolutions in literature - the Lyrical Ballads, naturalism, modernism - were fervent with proposal, and correspondingly eager to hit their enemies with those proposals. On both counts, Blincoe and Thorne are not revolutionaries: they admit to no apparent enemies, and they want literature to do less, not more.

This quietism seems a mystery, but the clue is film. Blincoe and Thorne seem less goaded by the failures of British fiction than piqued by the success of cinema. And correspondingly, their response is not literary but cinematic. Blincoe says that flashbacks are "essentially undramatic", and Thorne concurs, adding that "if the characters are strong, we need only know what they're doing now". So: out with memory, because memory is undramatic. The model, the idol, is the linearity of film (though not, one presumes, the unlinearity of Antonioni, Bergman, Kurosawa, Ozu).

Thorne says stories should shun "poetry and poetic licence in all its forms", because poetry is not the great influence on fiction: that is "film, technology, music or television ... Today, fiction should be focusing on visual culture, and attempting to prove itself the equal of these mediums." This is a revealing slip, for Thorne must mean that fiction is not, at present, the equal of these mediums. The idea that literature might be superior, or simply engaged in a different kind of activity, has seemingly not occurred to Blincoe and Thorne.

But then what can "equal" mean? Since it cannot mean "the same as" it must mean "equally successful". The manifesto for the New Puritanism is really a plea for success on the scale of film - a plea for worldly success wrapped in the disguise of denial. And a deep defensiveness, amounting to an embarrassment on behalf of literature, runs throughout this introduction. For what Blincoe and Thorne propose is to strip literature of all that makes it literary, so that it can better "compete" with film. It is really a commercial or pragmatic argument posing as an aesthetic and puritanical argument.

So in a strange inversion, while Dogme 95, the Danish art-film movement on which this book is loosely modelled, set itself puritanically against Hollywood film, Blincoe and Thorne really want to embrace Hollywood, despite their avowed puritanism. They are friendly to precisely those simplicities that seem deadly to the founders of Dogme 95.

Furthermore, while the rebellion of the Danish filmmakers makes sense within a world dominated by commercial cinema, the rebellion of Blincoe and Thorne is incoherent in a literary world already strongly infected by simplicity, presentism, blankness and a love affair with the cinematic. Thorne and Blincoe surely know that the contemporary short story since Raymond Carver - and as practised most recently by, say, Junot Diaz - has been quick, short, skinned and generally New Puritanical. Certainly in America, creative writing programmes process the story that only aspires to be a quick savage swipe of the cloth across reality. Such a story - invariably a "fragment of time", to use Blincoe and Thorne's phrase - offers itself as a kind of victim of its own confusion. Like many in this anthology, it is always narrated by a character, since third-person narration is nowadays taken to be something sent from an official ghost, like a bill.

The contemporary short story is invariably written in a babyish or busted English of thoughtless simplicity. In its refusal to take much note of place, history, or society, it seems - like its characters - the victim of sensory deprivation. Its characters speak to each other, if they are into conversation at all, in stringy glazed abruptnesses. Their conversation, in its complacent discontinuity, sounds as if each participant were on the phone to a third party. If they have pasts at all, they are thinly offered. Instead, they seem oddly stunned by the present, deseeded and without the pith of affect. We do not see them change much; instead, the story photographs their stasis.

This description of the contemporary story is also a description of the general tone of many of those in this anthology; which suggests that the New Puritans' revolution will not succeed precisely because it already has done. Pleasingly, the stories in this book that follow the "rules" are the weakest. "Monkey See" by Matthew Branton, about a policeman who watches hard-core porn as part of his job but who has not had sex with his wife for four months, seems to be an attempt to eat as many brand names as it can: "I'll pop round Londis, get some Persil ... He cooked up a Sizzle and Stir ... He spooned some Gold Blend into a jug." The absurdity of the rule that demands that all references to objects be "real" is nicely exploded by Scarlett Thomas, who in her piece misspells Häagen-Dazs ice cream, and by Thorne himself, who in his unpleasant and sexually sadistic story describes a woman in "a blue Knicks baseball T-shirt". The Knicks are a basketball team.

Thorne says that "fiction must always try to define the prominent cultural forms of its time" (oh, like The Charterhouse of Parma, War and Peace, Middlemarch, To the Lighthouse). So what do these stories tell us about British society? That people are watching a lot of TV (ER is mentioned in two of the stories, The Bill in another) and American videos, that they are masturbating quite a bit, using or making pornography, taking drugs and listening to music. Mostly, they are doing "simple" things in "simple" prose: "I shook my head and went into the kitchen, pouring myself a big bowl of cornflakes. I took a carton of juice from the fridge and filled a tall glass." Or: "For dinner, Mark's mum has Chunky Monkey ice-cream. Me and Mark's dad have egg and chips, sitting in the lounge watching Neighbours From Hell." In these stories the unexamined life is decidedly worth living.

The best stories are by Anna Davis (a lovely picture of a 15-year-old girl's frustrations: "There's so much life here and none of it is mine"); Geoff Dyer (a very funny and finely written piece about a Frenchwoman's bad trip); and Candida Clark (a rich, pleasingly old-fashioned bar-room anecdote, poetically rendered). These disobedient examples take plenty of poetic licence, indulge in all kinds of devices of voice, and are not especially simple in their grammar. Nicholas Blincoe and Toby Litt have written stories that are at least intriguing, and certainly plot-driven. But they both have trick endings, and their proper milieu seems to be Roald Dahl's Tales of the Unexpected.

Of course, the short story has historically tended toward the simple. I have a favourite line from Joyce's "A Little Cloud": "He watched the scene and thought of life; and (as always happened when he thought of life) he became sad." Many stories by Chekhov, Verga, Joyce and the incomparably simple Pirandello follow Blincoe and Thorne's rules. But this is the simplicity of those who have known richness, and who are a little weary of congestion. Blincoe and Thorne, by contrast, are too poor too young; paddling in remnants, they are incuriously abandoning something they did not possess anyway. On the evidence of this book, we need a New Abundance.

 James Wood's The Broken Estate: Essays on Literature and Belief, is published in paperback by Pimlico.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: Flight of the Storks | Hot Springs | The Big Blowdown | Stalker | The Courtship Gift | Deadly Décisions
fields.body:
The intriguing premise often disappoints in the unfolding. Not so in Jean-Christophe Grangé's Flight of the Storks (Harvill, £16.99) Buy it at BOL. Storks are inexplicably vanishing during their migration from north Europe to central Africa, and a young academic, hired to investigate by a elderly ornithologist, finds himself drawn into a bizarre journey of destiny and colonial rapacity. The speed with which the dilettante don takes to a life of murder and chase is the only questionable note in a first-rate thriller that barrels through Europe and the Middle East, into Africa and then India, blending the Gothic surrealism of Georges Franju's classic horror film Les Yeux Sans Visage (stolen body parts and weird, obsessive medical experiments) with the tropical depravities of Conrad's Heart of Darkness. Recommended.

Washington film critic Stephen Hunter has made a second career writing calibrated masculine thrillers dedicated to guns, which are detailed more lovingly than any woman. He draws heavily on film for inspiration, particularly Clint Eastwood as embodiment of the Puritan struggle and the flawed machismo and high fire-power of Sam Peckinpah. Hot Springs (Century, £17.99) Buy it at BOL features his regular crack shot Earl Swagger, demon-driven and given to improbable heroics. Suffering post-second world war depression, Swagger gets back in the killing groove when hired to clean up an Arkansas gambling town. Hunter does a professional job, but this is coarser and more cartoonish than his best work, full of set-piece slaughter, pat psychology, twinkling villains and laughably stoic women.

Like Hunter, George P Pelecanos is from Washington and has a film background. Unlike Hunter, he is an urban creature and spends more time describing natty shoes than guns; he also gives believable meaning to the trajectories of ordinary lives. The big mystery about The Big Blowdown (Serpent's Tail, £10) Buy it at BOL is why it has taken four years to get published here when Pelecanos is widely regarded as one of the best young American writers, and when this novel is one of his best. Set in Washington between 1933 and 1959, The Big Blowdown plays mainly as a post-war blues about a homecoming gone wrong. As always with Pelecanos, the prose is just dandy; the story unfolds to the beat of the city and a jukebox of hits, with the emphasis on racial mix and the overlap of retail and criminal enterprise (Greek diners and protection rackets; bars and pimping). After half a dozen interlocking novels, Pelecanos appears to be producing one of the great contemporary bodies of work.

Where Pelecanos is a writer of texture and ambition, Faye Kellerman offers little beyond formula and the odd chatty insight. The slack ease of the writing extends to lazy plotting that relies on coincidence and wild surmise. She also does a rotten red herring.

Stalker (Headline Feature, £17.99) Buy it at BOL doesn't really feature a stalker at all - more an inside case of unresolved police work that has a mustard-keen female rookie (irritating) trying to distinguish between regular departmental male chauvinism (irritating) and more specific harassment. Kellerman's bag is LA bland, and her political correctness comes at the expense of believable motivation. The villains are all routinely ugly.

After her husband is stung to death by a bee, modest Anna discovers the extent to which his life and their marriage were built on lies. She also finds herself exposed to a fanciful obsessive who orchestrates her widowhood in increasingly creepy ways, encouraged at first by her masochism. Julie Parsons's The Courtship Gift (Pan, £5.99) Buy it at BOL is set in a world of natural predators and victims whose initial curiosity serves merely to spring the trap. This Dublin tale is reminiscent of Ruth Rendell in its general nastiness, but her eye for how the ordinary turns extraordinary owes something to Patricia Highsmith, although Parsons is more Gothic in her liking for horror and twists and lacks some of Highsmith's relentless exposure of human motivation.

Kathy Reichs is pretty much a push-button, middle-range formula writer, providing middle-class weekend reading. She rips off the Patricia Cornwell thing (females and forensics) and gives it a French Canadian twist with a Montreal setting - hence those cutely accented titles, which are getting more desperate: Deadly Décisions (Heinemann, £15.99) Buy it at BOL. Ovérrated.

This Dublin tale is reminiscent of Ruth Rendell in its general nastiness, but her eye for how the ordinary turns extraordinary owes something to Patricia Highsmith, although Parsons is more Gothic in her liking for horror and twists and lacks some of Highsmith's relentless exposure of human motivation. Kathy Reichs is pretty much a push-button, middle-range formula writer, providing middle-class weekend reading. She rips off the Patricia Cornwell thing (females and forensics) and gives it a French Canadian twist with a Montreal setting - hence those cutely accented titles, which are getting more desperate: Deadly Décisions (Heinemann, £15.99) Buy it at BOL. Ovérrated.

webTitle: Eta's alleged military chief arrested in French raid

fields.headline: Eta's alleged military chief arrested in French raid
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A man alleged to be the top military commander of the Basque separatist group Eta was arrested in south-west France yesterday as police struck a fresh blow against the outlawed organisation.
fields.body:
A man alleged to be the top military commander of the Basque separatist group Eta was arrested in south-west France yesterday as police struck a fresh blow against the outlawed organisation.

Ignacio Gracia Arregui, 45, was seized in the town of Bidart with his girlfriend and a third person in an operation carried out jointly by French and Spanish police. The couple were with their two-year-old daughter when police burst into their flat. Other arrests were expected as the crackdown on Eta members, promised by Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, continued. Security forces would "continue their tenacious efforts", he said earlier this week, after 20 of the group's main strategists and fundraisers were taken into custody in Spain.

Eta's top leaders have always preferred to base themselves in the French Basque country where, for a time, they enjoyed protection. In 1987, French authorities lifted the immunity they had given Mr Arregui as a political refugee from General Franco's dictatorship. Yesterday's arrest was described by Spain's interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, as "a model of cooperation between French and Spanish police".

Mr Arregui, known colloquially as "Inaki de Renteria", after the small Basque town where he was born, allegedly took control of Eta's commandos in 1992 when the previous leadership was rounded up. Magistrates at Spain's national court, set up to try terrorist offences, accuse him of planning an assasination attempt on King Juan Carlos in 1995, foiled by police three years later. He is thought to have joined Eta in 1975, when he was barely 20 years old, and has remained a hardline activist ever since, unlike other veterans who renounced violence when Spain became a democracy and the Basque country was granted a measure of self-government.

Mr Arregui's arrest follows a period of intense Eta violence. Twelve people have died since the group broke a 14-month truce at the start of the year.
