fields.headline: Disciplinary charges for policeman
fields.trailText: Disciplinary charges of neglect, falsehood and misconduct were laid against Superintendent Ray Mallon yesterday by Cleveland police.
fields.body:
Disciplinary charges of neglect, falsehood and misconduct were laid against Superintendent Ray Mallon yesterday by Cleveland police.

The pioneer of zero tolerance policing has been suspended on full pay for nearly three years, and was cleared of any possible criminal charges earlier this year. Yesterday he reacted dismissively to the 14 allegations, repeating his view that the £5m corruption inquiry, Operation Lancet, had been a fiasco.

Mr Mallon, 45, headed crime prevention in Middlesbrough. He faces three claims of falsehood and prevarication, nine of neglect of duty, one of discreditable conduct and one of misconduct. He was notified of the charges by Cleveland after approval from the independent police complaints authority.

Mr Mallon was told that the disciplinary charges related to seven allegations from 23 made when Lancet was begun in 1997. Earlier that year he had been courted, as one of the highest profile policemen in Britain, by the then opposition leader, Tony Blair, and the home secretary, Michael Howard, in the run-up to the 1997 election.

Lancet cleared Mr Mallon of any possible criminal charges in July after the accident-prone inquiry was concluded. It had centred on claims of drugs-for-information deals and other allegedly lax or illegal procedures in the aftermath of a big, failed drugs prosecution.

Seven other officers are awaiting a decision from the complaints authority, while the chief constable, Barry Shaw, is being investigated over claims of leaking hostile information concerning Mr Mallon.

fields.headline: Blue period: Picasso on view
fields.trailText: A £16.6m Picasso painting was unveiled in London yesterday after being flown in from the Uniterd States amid tight security.
fields.body:
A £16.6m Picasso painting was unveiled in London yesterday after being flown in from the Uniterd States amid tight security.

Femme aux Bras Croisés (Woman with Folded Arms), from his Blue period, is on display at Christie's in St James's until Monday before going on a tour, taking in Zurich, Tokyo, Taipei and Los Angeles. Then it will be on sale at Christie's in New York, expected to fetch well over $25m, on November 8.

Pablo Picasso produced the picture in Barcelona in 1902, aged 21. Its first owner was the American writer Gertrude Stein. It later joined several private European collections before being bought in 1936 by a private American collector, whose family have owned it ever since.

A Blue period canvas of such quality has not been seen on the art market since 1988, when Picasso's Maternité (1901) sold in New York for $24.75m.

JV News Agency

webTitle: Gore wins battle for TV debates

fields.headline: Gore wins battle for TV debates
fields.standfirst:
Bush drops his demand for cosier chatshow confrontations

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush will hold three 90-minute television presidential election debates next month under an agreement made in Washington by their representatives.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush will hold three 90-minute television presidential election debates next month under an agreement made in Washington by their representatives.

The vice-presidential candidates, Joe Lieberman and Dick Cheney, will hold one televised debate, the agreement says.

The deal to settle a festering argument between the two camps about the number and format of this year's debates is a total victory for the Democratic candidate, Mr Gore, and an equally comprehensive climbdown by his Republican opponent, Mr Bush, who favoured more informal talkshow-style confrontations.

Mr Gore's camp said the agreement was "a victory for the American people", while the Bush camp said its man was now "looking forward to a free-flowing, substantive, real and genuine discussion of all the issues".

The Bush team is believed to have caved in when the dispute threatened to harm the Texas governor's ratings and sap energy from his campaign.

Mr Gore's preparations were given a further boost yesterday when an anonymous supporter sent his team a copy of a video tape of Mr Bush rehearsing with aides for the debates. Sources in the two camps confirmed that the tape was authentic.

The agreement commits the two men to a series of debates exactly as originally proposed by the nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates, the body which has supervised debates in US elections since 1988, established precisely to avoid the kind of stand-off which has taken place in the past three weeks.

The four debates are scheduled to begin after the end of the Olympics, as the candidates begin the intense five-week run-up to polling day on the November 7. They will be carried live on all the main national television networks.

The first Gore-Bush debate will be in Boston on October 3, followed by Winston-Salem on October 11 and St Louis on October 17. The Lieberman-Cheney debate will be in Danville on October 5.

There will almost certainly be no place in them for the third-party candidates, Ralph Nader of the Greens and Pat Buchanan of the Reform party. Neither has come close to the 15% opinion-poll rating that the commission sets as the threshold for taking part.

The agreement ends Mr Bush's attempt to change the format of the debates towards more informal, interview-style events which he hoped would be more to his advantage.

He originally proposed that there should be studio debates on NBC's Meet the Press and CNN's Larry King Live, and just one of the debates proposed by the commission.

The mysterious videotape of Mr Bush's rehearsals was sent to a former Democratic congressman, Tom Downey, in Washington and carried an Austin, Texas, postmark. It showed Mr Bush debating with the New Hampshire Republican senator Judd Gregg, who took the part of Mr Gore, at Mr Bush's ranch about a month ago. Mr Downey passed the video to the FBI.

Most Americans believe that executions should be halted until the completion of a study of how fairly the death penalty is applied, an opinion poll shows.

The poll by American Viewpoint and Peter D Hart Research shows that 59% favour a moratorium and 29% are opposed. Although it shows that most Americans still support capital punishment - 31% fully and 29% with reservations - the combined figure is the lowest for 19 years.

webTitle: Hopes and fears as plan starts to ban war diamonds

fields.headline: Hopes and fears as plan starts to ban war diamonds
fields.standfirst:
British certification scheme aims to stop trade by guerrillas

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone is to begin exporting its first diamonds next week under a complex new certification scheme aimed at curbing the trade in smuggled gems that has financed the rebel Revolutionary United Front's vicious war on civilians and propped up Charles Taylor's regime in neighbouring Liberia.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone is to begin exporting its first diamonds next week under a complex new certification scheme aimed at curbing the trade in smuggled gems that has financed the rebel Revolutionary United Front's vicious war on civilians and propped up Charles Taylor's regime in neighbouring Liberia.

The Sierra Leone government and British officials who instigated the scheme say it will have a major impact on the trade in "blood diamonds" and the weapons and drug rackets that accompany it. But sceptics argue that the process is vulnerable to corruption and the questionable commitment of importers such as Belgium and Israel.

The scheme follows a United Nations ban in July on trading in Sierra Leone diamonds that have not been approved for export, and a meeting the same month in Antwerp at which international diamond companies adopted strict measures to track the origin of gems in a bid to stave off more drastic measures, such as a publicity campaign of the kind that all but killed the fur trade.

Tamper-proof

Every parcel of diamonds leaving Sierra Leone legally will have to be accompanied by a numbered, tamper-proof certificate printed in the UK and paid for by the British government. Each certificate lists a parcel of diamonds by carat and value, and includes tear off portions to track the movement of the stones and to ensure that they have not been undervalued in Sierra Leone, either through incompetence or corruption.

The government's gold and diamond office in Freetown will issue the certificates. Its manager, Lawrence Ndola-Myers, works from a small room in the central bank, after the RUF burned him out of his original offices during the rebel invasion of Freetown in January 1999.

"We have learned our lessons from Angola and Congo, which did not have fake-proof certificates. We have gone to America, Belgium and Israel and discussed this to make sure everyone is committed. It will work. It's already started working. It will be very difficult for the RUF," he said.

Four international dealers will handle all exports. There were to have been five, but De Beers declined to participate.

"We asked De Beers to be one of the dealers because they are the biggest in the world," said Mr Ndola-Myers. "They said they didn't want to get into any funny business. They say that want to wait until there is a smooth running of the whole system. They will not be partaking."

Concerns

The success of the system relies heavily on officials in the major diamond dealing centres scrutinising all imported diamonds to ensure that illegal Sierra Leone gems do not slip in.

Diamond experts say it is easy enough to tell the origin of a diamond if it is packed with gems from the same area, but if a lone Sierra Leonean stone is mixed with others from Congo or Russia it becomes much harder to spot the illegal gem.

De Beers is providing a selection of Sierra Leonean stones for comparison by officials overseeing imports in Antwerp and Tel Aviv. But Alex Yearsley of Global Witness, an organisation that produced a widely respected report on the impact of blood diamonds, questions whether the scrutiny will be stringent.

"In Tel Aviv they are patently not interested. The biggest achievement to date is to get dealers to sign a declaration that they are not dealing in conflict diamonds. In Antwerp they are far more proactive, but only under pressure," he said.

Some dealers say that if Antwerp enforces the ban rigorously it will lose business to Tel Aviv, providing a further incentive to relax controls.

There are also concerns about the probity of the process within Sierra Leone.

"If you are determined enough it will be easy to bypass this system," Mr Yearsley said. "Officials can be bought. People say, 'How can you say the Sierra Leone government is corrupt?' But it is. This system could quite conceivably give the RUF a legal way of getting its diamonds out of the country."

Whatever its flaws, there is general agreement that the system will make it harder for the rebels and others to dispose of illegal diamonds, and that it will diminish their value.

But campaigners say the key to long term success is an international agreement requiring the certification of all diamond exports, no matter which country they come from. Britain is hosting a conference in London next month aimed at getting just such a deal.

Hisham Mackie exported more diamonds legally from Sierra Leone in the first six months of this year than any other dealer - three times as many as his nearest rival. His office in the heart of Freetown is guarded by a military policeman. Mr Mackie is ensconced behind electronic doors and closed circuit television with a parcel of diamonds worth $60,000 (£43,000) before him.

"It will work if they enforce it the other end. It it's not enforced it's just a hassle for the legitimate people. The bottom line is, you would not have a 100% system but you will get 80%. That is good enough under the circumstances here," he said.

webTitle: UN takes first step into Eritrea conflict

fields.headline: UN takes first step into Eritrea conflict
fields.trailText: As the first wave of UN military observers arrived in the capitals of Eritrea and Ethiopia yesterday, the Eritrean president, Issais Afworki, said he felt "cautious but not pessimistic" about efforts to end his country's two-year border war with Ethiopia.
fields.body:
As the first wave of UN military observers arrived in the capitals of Eritrea and Ethiopia yesterday, the Eritrean president, Issais Afworki, said he felt "cautious but not pessimistic" about efforts to end his country's two-year border war with Ethiopia.

Forty unarmed observers from countries including Sweden, Italy and Finland will be deployed on either side of the 600 mile (1,000km) front. If the current three-month ceasefire holds good, their number will be doubled next month.

The UN security council yesterday unanimously agreed to send 4,200 armed peacekeepers - two battalions from Africa, one from Europe - to join the observers.

"Our job is not only to keep these fighting dogs apart, but also to try to build some bridges between them," Colonel Fred Hoogeland, the UN's chief liaison officer in the Eritrean capital, Asmara, said yesterday as shipping crates and gleaming white land cruisers piled up outside his new headquarters.

"My impression from talking to both officials and civilians is that both parties are committed to this process."

But expressing the hostility prevalent on both sides, President Afworki poured scorn on a pledge by the leadership in Addis Ababa to pull back some 20 miles to the pre-war border once peacekeeprs are in place: "Ethiopia is not serious about peace," he declared.

In the crumbling Eritrean trenches overlooking Senafe, an occupied town in Eritrea near the Ethiopian border, volunteer soldiers in motley fatigues were surprised but pleased to hear of the UN's arrival.

"Every day it is quiet but at night we hear them [the Ethiopians] pushing men forward and improving their trenches," Lieutenant Mehretab Gerezgiher said. "Why aren't the United Nations here now?"

Col Hoogeland said he understood the impatience: "If it was up to me, the battalions would be here yesterday. This is the fastest UN deployment ever. But it is still likely to be a couple of months before the blue-beret forces arrive."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Activists' arrest
fields.body:
Activists' arrest

Yugoslav police detained five opposition activists and a lawyer yesterday during a search of the Civic Alliance party's headquarters in Belgrade.

The arrests came as some opinion polls showed the main opposition candidate in the presidential election on September 24, Vojislav Kostunica, on 40% against President Slobodan Milosevic's 22%.
Reuters, Belgrade

US execution

Proclaiming his innocence, Derek Rocco Barnabei, 33, was put to death in Virginia on Thursday night for raping and killing a 17-year-old girl he had dated.

His lawyers say they will go on with the DNA tests which they hope will clear him.
AP, Jarratt, Virginia

Joan invoked

A French rightwing politician, Catherine Mégret, mayor of the southern town of Vitrolles, showed up for her trial on racism charges yesterday dressed in sackcloth like Joan of Arc ready to be burned at the stake.

She is charged with offering 5,000 franc (£500) bonuses to French and European Union women when they had babies in her town.
Reuters, Marseille

Catholic plea

Invoking the Roman Catholic teachings about helping people, Archbishop Gabriel Kassab of Basra, Iraq, has asked the US government "in the name of humanity" to end a decade of economic sanctions against his country.

He was speaking on Thursday in Baltimore, on a US tour to talk about the plight of the Iraqi people.
AP, Baltimore

fields.headline: Flood appeal
fields.standfirst: Cambodia and Vietnam face disaster
fields.trailText: Cambodia and Vietnam yesterday appealed to the international community for emergency aid to tackle unprecedented floods hitting the Mekong river delta, as meteorologists predicted that the water will continue to rise for at least the next week.
fields.body:
Cambodia and Vietnam yesterday appealed to the international community for emergency aid to tackle unprecedented floods hitting the Mekong river delta, as meteorologists predicted that the water will continue to rise for at least the next week.

Some 1.2m Cambodians and several hundred thousand Vietnamese have been affected by the floods which have killed about 100 people in the last two months. About half of these "are in need of emergency assistance, including clothing, food, sheets of plastic and blankets", according to the Cambodian Red Cross and Red Crescent societies.

Government officials and aid agencies in both countries paint a bleak picture of hundreds of thousands of refugees camping on any available high ground, much of which consists of dykes that are threatening to crumble under the weight of the people. "It's a disaster and it's going to get worse," said John Geoghegan, senior delegate of the Red Cross.

The Cambodian foreign ministry yesterday called on foreign embassies, UN agencies, non-governmental organisations and private companies to help with the relief efforts.

It said emergency conditions existed in 13 provinces and that river banks would probably have to be burst to protect the capital, Phnom Penh. Kompong Cham, Takeo and Prey Veng were singled out as the worst affected areas, with many houses under water.

The disaster is caused by unseasonably heavy rain in July, six weeks before the usual start of the monsoon season. Rain has fallen almost continuously since then in many areas, resulting in many rivers bursting their banks.

The Cambodian foreign ministry yesterday called on foreign embassies, UN agencies, non-governmental organisations and private companies to help with the relief efforts. It said emergency conditions existed in 13 provinces and that river banks would probably have to be burst to protect the capital, Phnom Penh. Kompong Cham, Takeo and Prey Veng were singled out as the worst affected areas, with many houses under water. The disaster is caused by unseasonably heavy rain in July, six weeks before the usual start of the monsoon season. Rain has fallen almost continuously since then in many areas, resulting in many rivers bursting their banks.

webTitle: Polygamy church prepares for end of the world

fields.headline: Polygamy church prepares for end of the world
fields.trailText: There is speculation that a polygamous sect which split from the Mormons more than a century ago may be preparing for the end of the world - perhaps as soon as this month. Concern arose when hundreds of the sect's children failed to turn up at the beginning of the school year
fields.body:
There is speculation that a polygamous sect which split from the Mormons more than a century ago may be preparing for the end of the world - perhaps as soon as this month. Concern arose when hundreds of the sect's children failed to turn up at the beginning of the school year

Last year there were 1,400 pupils at the four schools which serve the remote desert towns of Colorado City in Arizona and Hilldale, Utah. This year only about 350 have enrolled, and dozens of teachers who belong to the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints have also quit.

The two small towns were settled at the end of the 19th century by polygamous Mormons. When the main Mormon church officially disavowed polygamy in 1890, so that Utah could gain statehood, they went their own way. Polygamy is widespread among the 6,000 local members of the sect.

The decision to withdraw children from school was taken on the orders of Warren Jeffs, who speaks on behalf of his father, Rulon Jeffs, the church's prophet. Sect members say they are cutting contact with non-believers and preparing for the apocalypse Mr Jeffs says is at hand.

This is not the first time that Mr Jeffs has told his followers to prepare for the end of the world. In 1993, too, he told pupils to abandon their classes because they would not be there to finish their studies.

Now the towns believe he has again warned that the second coming of Jesus Christ may be only days away. DeLoy Bateman, a former member and local science teacher, said Mr Jeffs had prophesied that the two towns would be lifted bodily into the heavens.

Colorado City's mayor, Dan Barlow, himself a member, said the decree was "merely a suggestion that people take responsibility for themselves".

webTitle: Freed Suu Kyi challenges Burma junta

fields.headline: Freed Suu Kyi challenges Burma junta
fields.trailText: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burma's pro-democracy leader, left her home yesterday after two weeks of effective house arrest and challenged the military government to stop her plans to travel outside the capital.
fields.body:
Aung San Suu Kyi, Burma's pro-democracy leader, left her home yesterday after two weeks of effective house arrest and challenged the military government to stop her plans to travel outside the capital.

On Thursday, the military regime announced that it was lifting restrictions against her and eight members of the central committee of her National League for Democracy (NLD).

All of them had been confined to their homes since September 1. They were denied telephone contact and no visitors were permitted, except their closest relatives.

The government eased the restrictions after sharp international criticism of its actions - most notably by the US, Britain, and the UN. But in barely coded language the regime has accused London and Washington of meddling in its internal affairs.

Accompanied by colleagues, Ms Suu Kyi went to her newly reopened party headquarters in central Rangoon. "We are a legal political party and they have no right to raid our party," she told reporters there.

"I shall be travelling outside Rangoon within the next 10 days for party organisational work. It will be an organised trip, and we will do it openly. It is high time that the SPDC [the ruling military council] stops putting restrictions on our rights," she said.

The regime has accused her party of having links with terrorists in Burma and along the border with Thailand.

It was an attempt to travel round the country that brought the latest crackdown on the party leaders. On August 24, Ms Suu Kyi and 14 party colleagues were blocked by security forces outside the capital and ordered to return home. They refused and camped beside their vehicles for nine days before police took them forcibly back to Rangoon and confined them to their homes.

Ms Suu Kyi, who won the 1991 Nobel peace prize for her peaceful struggle for democracy in Burma, did not say where her group planned to go, but she challenged the authorities: "Stop us if you dare."

When the government lifted restrictions on Ms Suu Kyi on Thursday, the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said at the UN's headquarters in New York that she was "gratified". The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, also welcomed the move and repeated his call on the junta to engage in a real political dialogue with opposition leaders.

Ms Suu Kyi looked cheerful yesterday as she held red and pink roses handed to her by some of the 200 supporters outside her party offices when she arrived there with the party's chairman, Aung Shwe, and vice-chairman, Tin Oo.

"We always appreciate the international support to our cause and our rights," she said. "I want to thank all those who stood up for our rights.

"We hope that they'll stand by us staunchly for full restoration of rights, not just of the NLD but for all the people of Burma."

The regime kept Ms Suu Kyi under house arrest between 1989 and 1995. The NLD won the general election in 1990, but was prevented from taking power. Hundreds of its members have since been jailed.

In London, Amnesty International expressed concern yesterday about 16 NLD youth members and the chairman of the party's Rangoon division, Soe Myint, who were reported to be still in detention in Rangoon's Insein prison.

webTitle: Suicide bomber kills six at hospital

fields.headline: Suicide bomber kills six at hospital
fields.trailText: A suspected Tamil Tiger suicide bomber triggered a blast outside a hospital in Colombo yesterday, killing six people and injuring more than 20 after a policeman foiled what the authorities believe might have been an attempt on the life of the Sri Lankan health minister.
fields.body:
A suspected Tamil Tiger suicide bomber triggered a blast outside a hospital in Colombo yesterday, killing six people and injuring more than 20 after a policeman foiled what the authorities believe might have been an attempt on the life of the Sri Lankan health minister.

Police said the suicide bomber detonated explosives strapped around his chest after he was asked by a policeman to produce his identification papers outside the main eye hospital in Colombo. The dead included the policeman who intercepted the bomber.

The deputy inspector general of police in the capital, Bodi Liyanage, said the policeman had prevented the bomber from getting closer to his suspected target, the health minister, Nimal Siripala de Silva. The Tigers attempted to kill Mr Siripala de Silva in 1996, while he was visiting the northern Jaffna pensinsula.

"We received information of a suspicious man hanging around outside the eye hospital," said Mr Siripala de Silva. "We believe the suicide bomber was a Tamil Tiger."

Mr Siripala de Silva and a visiting World Health Organisation delegation had passed the site a few minutes before the explosion, said the ministry's permanent secretary, Tilak Ranaviraja.

The attack bought chaos to Colombo. Many of the victims were patients on their way to the eye hospital for treatment.

A witness said ambulances and paramedics struggled to reach the victims as traffic ground to a halt around the scene."It took several minutes before the dead and seriously injured were dealt with."

The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, which has been fighting for 17 years to establish a separate homeland for the Tamil minority, seldom comments on such attacks.

More than 60,000 people have been killed in the war. In June the industry minister, CV Gooneratne, was killed, along with many bystanders, by a suicide bomber.

The explosion coincided with more fighting between the army and Tigers in the northern Jaffna peninsula. The army says that at at least 10 rebels were killed in the latest clashes.

It comes amid rising tension in the run-up to general elections scheduled for October. In a campaign that has often been marred by violence between different parties, the ruling Peoples' Alliance is facing a strong challenge from the United National party.

A diplomat said: "The result is expected to be close. There is a very real possibility of a power stuggle in the country if the opposition wins a majority in parliament and then starts to challenge the authority of the president, Chandrika Kumaratunga."

Violence has increased in recent weeks. Two prominent People's Alliance members were shot dead in the eastern town of Batticaloa, and three senior members of the United National party narrowly escaped with their lives when their motorcade was attacked by gunmen outside Colombo.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Contrary to what we said in a report headed Australia allowed invasion of East Timor, page 16, September 13, the five journalists killed when Indonesian forces attacked the Timorese town of Balibo in 1975 were not all Australian. Two were British.
fields.body:
Contrary to what we said in a report headed Australia allowed invasion of East Timor, page 16, September 13, the five journalists killed when Indonesian forces attacked the Timorese town of Balibo in 1975 were not all Australian. Two were British.

In a report headed Big payout over Guevara photo, page 7, yesterday, we mistakenly said that work by the photographer Korda (Alberto Diaz Gutierrez) was being shown at the National Gallery. His exhibition is, in fact, at the National Theatre in London, until November 1.

Some chronological confusion arose over our extract from Kathleen Burk's book Troublemaker: The Life and Times of AJP Taylor, page 3, Saturday Review, September 2. It all becomes clear if, instead of reading the opening words as, "AJP Taylor was a student in Vienna in 1933 ..." you read "in 1930", the year intended.

The papers of James Boswell, the biographer of Samuel Johnson, were found at Malahide castle in Ireland and at Fettercairn House in Scotland, not (as we said in our obituary of Donald Gallup, page 22, September 13) at Malahide castle in Scotland.

In a graphic headed The rival bodysuits, page 22 of the Guardian guide to the Olympics, published with the paper on September 8, we incorrectly indicated that the suit pictured was the Adidas Full Body Swimsuit. In fact the picture showed the Speedo Fastskin suit.

Homophone corner, from page 4, G2, September 5, "... his gangly build ... leant itself to professional basketball ..." And, from a letter, page 21, yesterday, "We ... drove to the gym [and] worked out on the stationery bike ..." The Readers' editor writes about language and stigma, page 7, today's Saturday Review.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: West Yorkshire
fields.body:
West Yorkshire

There is a delicious pleasure in discovering a hidden gem of wildlife habitat. A secret corner, tucked away, where plough and chemical spray are excluded, where wildlife flourishes and thrives. Rachel Cartledge, of West Yorkshire Ecology and I found just such a spot while surveying tributaries of the River Went for water voles. We came upon a wetland, perhaps three acres in size, wedged between two arable fields, a road and a disused pasture. On three sides it has ditches, full to the brim with water and crammed with reedmace and branched burr-reed, but the real joy was to walk around a stand of willowherb in the centre and find a sea of deep, deep blue devil's-bit scabious. It con trasted beautifully with the last creamy fluff of meadowsweet flowers behind them.

Among the rich vegetation were the trails, droppings and flattened areas which show that roe deer lie up there during the day. We had seen their tracks earlier on the other side of the main beck. As we continued our water vole survey down towards the Went, first a buck, then a doe, broke cover in front of us from the edge of a cornfield. They bounced along the corridor left by tractor use, heads bobbing above the standing corn to keep an eye on us.

There have been other bonuses of this kind during the past few weeks. There was the surprise sighting of a fox drinking in the shallows, mid-afternoon, the bounding run of brown hare from field headlands as I crashed through brambles by the stream's edge, and the less pleasant, but still fascinating, sight of a large, dark brown mink slipping into the Little Went near Wentbridge. It was about 25 yards in front of me, watching me for some moments before turning to swim downstream and into thicker cover.

I have also seen the occasional water vole - and several brown rats. This in spite of my noisy and clumsy progress along the water courses. Water voles are quite widespread in the survey area, but there are also gaps and places where the conditions are right, but the animals are missing.

From Monday, the Country Diary and cartoon strips will appear in G2.

fields.headline: Rock shock
fields.standfirst:
UK scientists urge us to insure against the danger of being flattened by a giant asteroid

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The search for petrol may be at the front of our minds this weekend. But for those who want distraction, there is another big problem to worry about. We in Britain should take the threat more seriously of collision with large rocks from space.
fields.body:
The search for petrol may be at the front of our minds this weekend. But for those who want distraction, there is another big problem to worry about. We in Britain should take the threat more seriously of collision with large rocks from space.

Last December 30, lost among the millennium celebrations, Lord Sainsbury announced the formation of a top-level task force consisting of Sir Crispin Tickell, Dr Harry Atkinson and Professor David Williams, to investigate the asteroid hazard. Their report is due to be published on Monday. They are to confirm that the hazard we face is not trivial, and to recommend a suite of actions that the UK might implement, as a participant in a global programme aimed at ensuring that we are not taken unawares.

Although the US is by far the dominant player in this field, the UK is well placed to lead European efforts to tackle this surprising danger. We must secure the future of the human race against attack from above.

We have got all our eggs stored in one basket. It's called the Earth. We must keep it safe. The dinosaurs couldn't see their nemesis coming. We can, and having realised the danger it would be negligent of us to adopt an ostrich-like stance.

Forget, for the moment, Bruce Willis and the other heroes of those cosmic disaster movies Armageddon and Deep Impact. The way the universe really works is this. In our yearly orbit around the Sun, many space rocks pass us by. Some are large, some small. Some come near, but most keep their distance. The Earth collects about 40,000 tons of celestial debris each year, mainly tiny grains producing the familiar shooting stars seen on a dark night. But every so often a whopper slams into us.

Of concern are those bigger than about a kilometre: maybe a mile at the outside. A crater 10 miles wide and several miles deep would be excavated by one of these. By dint of the extreme speed, the energy released on impact would be equivalent to about 100,000 megatons of TNT. Around 10m times the Hiroshima bomb.

This is the threshold at which a global upset of the environment would be caused (putting it mildly), and we may expect at least a quarter of the human race to perish. How often might that happen? Answer: about once every 100,000 years.

Now, is that anything to be concerned about? As a scientist, I have to compare it against other risks. If the kill-rate is one in four people, the chance of dying that way is one in 400,000 per annum. If you have a remaining life expectancy of 40 years, this means there is a one in 10,000 probability that an asteroid catastrophe will end your days. Statistics for airline disasters indicate that the average westerner's chance of dying in a plane crash is around one in 30,000. So asteroids are more dangerous than jetliners. We spend billions on the latter, and essentially nothing on the former.

Compare the risk against other major catastrophes, such as nuclear power stations or chemical plants exploding. The government has safety guidelines for such things. Take that one chance in 100,000 per annum level of occurrence as reference: the guidelines say that if some accident has that likelihood and it would kill more than 100 people, then money should be spent if it is feasible to reduce the risk. If the death expectancy is more than 10,000, then the risk is defined as being "intolerable", and it must be tackled.

A massive asteroid impact anywhere around the globe has that annual probability, and no matter where it hits one may expect more than 10m Britons to die. The safety guidelines indicate, then, that this is super-intolerable. The government must act.

The average voter still thinks people such as I are joking when we argue that there is a significant hazard posed by asteroids running into the Earth. Bruce Willis has fooled you. As a matter of fact, it is about as funny as cancer, or mass murder. Not to realise that some things are dangerous without having it painfully proven to you is dumb. Hydrogen bombs have never killed anyone. But we can imagine the consequences of a war in which they are used in anger.

What can we do, having recognised the danger? All that is advocated at this stage is a surveillance programme aimed at answering one question: is there a major impact due within the next century? Most likely the answer is "no".

It is like taking out car insurance: you hope you won't need to make a claim. But if the answer is "yes" then, with adequate warning, we can take ameliorative action. The only viable method we know to divert an identified impactor involves nuclear weapons, but it is not like in the movies. We are talking here about having 10 or 20 years to get out there and give it a small but sufficient nudge such that it misses our planetary home, and does not deliver its far more powerful punch.

The parallel with cancer is a pertinent one. Cancer screening costs relatively little and most often the result is negative. But if a tumour is found, then all the feasible cures are unpleasant, and they may only be used if the cancer is picked up early enough. And you won't find it if you don't look.

Ah, but you have never heard of anyone dying due to an asteroid strike? No, there have been no really large impacts during recorded history. Of course not. You wouldn't be here to read about it if there had been. But there was a 15 megaton event over Siberia in 1908 that would have flattened the whole of London if the circumstances had been only slightly different. And Chinese records tell us of a meteorite explosion killing tens of thousands in the 15th century.

Statistics can be misleading. Take air crashes. I'm a member of the Qantas frequent flyer club, an airline that has never had an accident. Does that mean that next time I board a Qantas jet to Sydney I have zero risk of dying? Circumstances can change quickly. Until recently Concorde was regarded as a paragon of air safety. Two decades ago virtually everyone, weather forecasters included, thought that hurricanes never hit England.

The only nation spending any sensible amount on asteroid defence is the United States. And I do mean "defence" - the two most productive search telescopes are owned by the US Air Force. In effect we too, need to declare war on the heavens.

Duncan Steel is reader in space technology at the University of Salford.

D.I.Steel@salford.ac.uk

Answer: about once every 100,000 years. Now, is that anything to be concerned about? As a scientist, I have to compare it against other risks. If the kill-rate is one in four people, the chance of dying that way is one in 400,000 per annum. If you have a remaining life expectancy of 40 years, this means there is a one in 10,000 probability that an asteroid catastrophe will end your days. Statistics for airline disasters indicate that the average westerner's chance of dying in a plane crash is around one in 30,000. So asteroids are more dangerous than jetliners. We spend billions on the latter, and essentially nothing on the former. Compare the risk against other major catastrophes, such as nuclear power stations or chemical plants exploding. The government has safety guidelines for such things. Take that one chance in 100,000 per annum level of occurrence as reference: the guidelines say that if some accident has that likelihood and it would kill more than 100 people, then money should be spent if it is feasible to reduce the risk. If the death expectancy is more than 10,000, then the risk is defined as being "intolerable", and it must be tackled. A massive asteroid impact anywhere around the globe has that annual probability, and no matter where it hits one may expect more than 10m Britons to die. The safety guidelines indicate, then, that this is super-intolerable. The government must act. The average voter still thinks people such as I are joking when we argue that there is a significant hazard posed by asteroids running into the Earth. Bruce Willis has fooled you. As a matter of fact, it is about as funny as cancer, or mass murder. Not to realise that some things are dangerous without having it painfully proven to you is dumb. Hydrogen bombs have never killed anyone. But we can imagine the consequences of a war in which they are used in anger. What can we do, having recognised the danger? All that is advocated at this stage is a surveillance programme aimed at answering one question: is there a major impact due within the next century? Most likely the answer is "no". It is like taking out car insurance: you hope you won't need to make a claim. But if the answer is "yes" then, with adequate warning, we can take ameliorative action. The only viable method we know to divert an identified impactor involves nuclear weapons, but it is not like in the movies. We are talking here about having 10 or 20 years to get out there and give it a small but sufficient nudge such that it misses our planetary home, and does not deliver its far more powerful punch. The parallel with cancer is a pertinent one. Cancer screening costs relatively little and most often the result is negative. But if a tumour is found, then all the feasible cures are unpleasant, and they may only be used if the cancer is picked up early enough. And you won't find it if you don't look. Ah, but you have never heard of anyone dying due to an asteroid strike? No, there have been no really large impacts during recorded history. Of course not. You wouldn't be here to read about it if there had been. But there was a 15 megaton event over Siberia in 1908 that would have flattened the whole of London if the circumstances had been only slightly different. And Chinese records tell us of a meteorite explosion killing tens of thousands in the 15th century. Statistics can be misleading. Take air crashes. I'm a member of the Qantas frequent flyer club, an airline that has never had an accident. Does that mean that next time I board a Qantas jet to Sydney I have zero risk of dying? Circumstances can change quickly. Until recently Concorde was regarded as a paragon of air safety. Two decades ago virtually everyone, weather forecasters included, thought that hurricanes never hit England. The only nation spending any sensible amount on asteroid defence is the United States. And I do mean "defence" - the two most productive search telescopes are owned by the US Air Force. In effect we too, need to declare war on the heavens. Duncan Steel is reader in space technology at the University of Salford. D.I.Steel@salford.ac.uk

fields.headline: Painting Britain green
fields.standfirst:
This week has not diminished the urgency

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: From where Tony Blair is sitting this weekend, the political calculus looks pretty simple. A general election is probably only eight months away and Middle England has turned distinctly nasty.
fields.body:
From where Tony Blair is sitting this weekend, the political calculus looks pretty simple. A general election is probably only eight months away and Middle England has turned distinctly nasty.

Kyoto and Rio are faraway places of which floating voters care little. Worcester and Basildon are the places on the map that really matter. This line of thinking is understandable. Politics is a rough old game and the temptation for the prime minister to toss a few bones to farmers, truckers and (more to the point) Mondeo drivers is strong. But it would still be wrong.

We said throughout the events of the past week that the prime minister was right to face down the protesters because it was a fight the government could not afford to lose. The same applies to the long-term struggle to safeguard the environment, where the list of disasters caused by climate change grows longer daily.

It is not so long since the TV cameras that were this week focused on oil refineries in Britain were trained on a tree in Mozambique where a mother had given birth as flood waters rose. At a more parochial level, Portsmouth council yesterday sent its staff home after floods cut off power to its offices. The Environment Agency said torrential rain across large parts of southern Britain gave it the chance to test out new flood warning systems. So this, too, is a fight the government cannot afford to lose.

To bridge the gap between the short-term political imperative and the longer-term need to halt and then reverse the climate change caused by global warming, the government needs to make a much more explicit link between taxation and "green" public spending. For instance, a systematic programme of home insulation, paid for by higher duties on fuel, would remedy a state of affairs where billions of pounds worth of energy seeps out into the atmosphere every day.

The real problem, however, is that governments have woefully neglected public transport for decades, sometimes for ideological reasons, sometimes just to save money. So trains and buses have become a much more expensive way of travelling or moving goods; movement by road has become relatively cheaper. Without a viable alternative, the impact of higher taxes is to raise business costs and reduce consumer incomes. Companies do not switch freight to the railways or workers leave the car in the garage; they simply boil over with rage at a government that is costing them money.

That cannot change overnight, but it will never change at all unless the government starts to argue for a more progressive alternative. One option would be to tell private motorists and road hauliers that road pricing will be introduced on UK roads in 10 or 15 years time, by which time the government will have made the necessary investment in new lines, new signalling, new rolling stock and new staff to ensure that there is enough capacity, at a competitive price, to cope with extra rail passengers and the extra freight. The road lobby would no longer be able to say that all its taxes were disappearing into a black hole at the Treasury; this would be a something for something deal.

Has the government the political courage to go down this route? Well, the idea of linking higher spending to specific outcomes is part of the new Labour rubric and there is no reason why it could not adopt the same strategy when it comes to the environment. In their bones, most voters - even those clocking up 50,000 miles a year on the M1 - know that we have to find a better way. And those that do not are already going to vote for William Hague anyway.

webTitle: UBS Warburg seeks right fit with recruiting shoe-in

fields.headline: UBS Warburg seeks right fit with recruiting shoe-in
fields.trailText: Leopard-skin stilettos, red-sequinned dancing shoes and hefty walking boots are fronting a quirky recruitment march by one of the major investment banks.
fields.body:
Leopard-skin stilettos, red-sequinned dancing shoes and hefty walking boots are fronting a quirky recruitment march by one of the major investment banks.

With the lure of an introduction fee of £3,000 or £5,000 for director-level hires, UBS Warburg pleads: "Help us to get those shoes filled".

The shoes, pictured on colourful postcards placed on each employee's desk in the City and other major financial centres around the world, advertise the group's new internal website, ihire.

In a reflection of a highly-competitive job market in the City, Warburg launched the campaign to persuade its existing employees to recommend candidates last week.

While other investment banks, such as Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, already pay introduction fees to its staff, few financial firms have adopted such a recruitment drive.

Investment banks have traditionally used headhunters - who can demand up to 20% of the first year's salary for an introduction fee - to find new staff, ranging from specialists in investment banking to share salesmen.

Warburg describes the ihire scheme as one that "rewards you for helping to bring the right people into your organisation - people who fit" and adds: "It'll make your social life easier to plan too".

While some bankers might be concerned that if their friends are sitting alongside them it will more difficult for them to get out of the office, Warburg promises that the best will bring further rewards.

"The better our people, the better we are at what we do. Good performance means financial rewards, a positive reputation in our markets, a stronger brand and a culture of success. And success breeds more success," the campaign pledges.

fields.headline: Morgan resolves race row
fields.standfirst: Former employee drops discrimination claim
fields.trailText: An embarrassing saga that prompted the departure of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's chief lawyer ended yesterday
fields.body:
An embarrassing saga that prompted the departure of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's chief lawyer ended yesterday when the Wall Street bank settled its dispute with a former employee who claimed to have been a victim of racial and sexual discrimination.

Christian Curry, the junior black analyst at the centre of a case that rocked the bank last year, dropped his claims for $1.35bn (£960m) in damages, more than two years after being sacked by the bank.

In return, Morgan Stanley agreed to drop its action seeking restitution of "illegal" expense claims. The bank also agreed to donate $1m to the National Urban League, a charitable organisation devoted to advancing the interests of minorities.

Donald Kempf, the bank's chief legal officer, described the settlement as a "complete vindication". Mr Kempf replaced Christine Edwards, who left the firm along with another lawyer last summer after it emerged that the legal department had paid an informant $10,000 for information about Mr Curry.

The case led to an inquiry by the Manhattan district attorney's office into the bank's behaviour. It was subsequently cleared of acting illegally.

In a statement Mr Curry, who has since found employment at a small Wall Street firm, said: "This has been emotionally draining for my family, my fiancée and me, and to continue would be detrimental to all. While I will receive no payment I am pleased with the result."

Mr Curry had alleged discrimination on the basis of his colour and supposed sexual orientation after he appeared in a gay sex magazine.

The bank instead pointed to receipts from toy shops and restaurants and expenses including lap dancing clubs.

The young man's lawyer, Benedict Morelli, said yesterday: "Certain situations call for people to rise above the fray and attempt to resolve disputes out of court. This is one of those situations."

Mr Morelli added that pre-trial disclosures led him to change his mind. "We now understand that Morgan Stanley Dean Witter engaged in no discrimination or misconduct against Mr Curry."

After it was cleared by the district attourney's last year, Morgan Stanley admitted to having made "a mistake in judgment" by paying for information from an individual who could later have been used as a trial witness.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: City columnist returns to fold
fields.body:
City columnist returns to fold

Edmond Warner, our City columnist, returns today after a break. His firm, Old Mutual Securities, is one of the largest shareholders in the LSE, and so his first analysis focuses on the sorry state of this once great institution.

Warner, 37, shot to prominence in the Square Mile in the early 1990s after being voted the top Extel-rated market strategist in London. He was then working for Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, but was quickly poached by NatWest Markets as managing director, Europe. After overseeing the sale of the firm to Bankers Trust, and the subsequent creation of BT Alex Brown, Warner decided he had had enough of "bulge bracket" investment banking when BT was then sold to Deutsche Bank.

At Old Mutual he is building a team dedicated to what he calls "good old-fashioned stockbroking." Warner's column will appear each Saturday.

EC rules on Triumph bikes

Motorbike manufacturer Triumph has deliberately prevented British customers from buying its bikes abroad, where they can be up to 30% cheaper, and has only stopped because of pressure from the European commission, it emerged yesterday.

The EC yesterday disclosed that it had carried out dawn raids at Triumph's UK offices last year and found evidence that it had instructed its importer for Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg not to sell to UK customers. Raids were also carried out at a number of dealers in Belgium and the Netherlands.

Triumph was able to breathe a sigh of relief yesterday, however, after Brussels announced is would not press ahead with legal proceedings which could have resulted in a massive fine.

Energy shell bankruptcy

The holding firm behind bankrupt electricity group Independent Energy has gone into administration following the appointment of receivers to its three main operating subsidiaries a week ago.

Accountancy firm KPMG, which is seeking buyers for the group, said the move was a technicality required if any money was to be returned to unsecured creditors.

FSA report on pension sales

Compensation for victims of mis-sold mortgage endowments moved a step closer yesterday after the Financial Services Authority said it is to issue a report early next month on "problem categories" of endowment business - believed to include mortgages sold to the elderly and those who did not understand they were buying an equity-linked product.

It confirmed that 60% of the 6m householders with endowments have policies which may fail to to repay mortgages at maturity.

It said that as of the end of August, 3.8m reprojection letters had been sent to people with endowment policies. Of these, 40% fall into the "red" or "amber" category, in which householders will have to increase premiums to keep their policies on track.

webTitle: Row at Bank of England: Sacked six stage protest

fields.headline: Row at Bank of England: Sacked six stage protest
fields.trailText: Demonstrators, including more than 20 officials from the bank workers' union Unifi and staff of the Bank of England, gathered outside the bank yesterday to protest against the sacking of six workers who refused to sign a new contract.
fields.body:
Demonstrators, including more than 20 officials from the bank workers' union Unifi and staff of the Bank of England, gathered outside the bank yesterday to protest against the sacking of six workers who refused to sign a new contract.

The workers have between 16 and 25 years service and range from secretaries to analysts. John Brawley, the national secretary of Unifi, said that the new deal means holiday cuts, withdrawal of mortgage facilities and an end to flexi-leave. "Employees were told to agree to the new contract or be fired. The vast majority signed up because they felt there was no acceptable alternative.

"If you can't trust the Bank of England to stand by its contracts what hope is there for anyone?" He added that Unifi intended to take the bank to an employment tribunal if agreement was not reached.

Of the six staff, who earned between £18,000 and more than £30,000, five were women, including foreign exchange supervisor Lynne Paterson (left). They were unhappy about losing flexi-leave because it meant they would be unable to take a day off if their children were ill.

fields.headline: Footsie hit by late flurry
fields.trailText: Continuing fretting over the impact of high crude prices on corporate profitability, coupled with the strength of the dollar, ensured another tough day for the London market.
fields.body:
Continuing fretting over the impact of high crude prices on corporate profitability, coupled with the strength of the dollar, ensured another tough day for the London market.

Prices were drifting lower for much of the day, but a series of big program trades around the close accounted for about half the fall on the FTSE 100, which came to rest 138.2 points adrift at 6417.3.

Dealers blamed portfolio shuffles ahead of the index'sconstituent changes on Monday for the late flurry of trades. But there had been some serious volatility much earlier in the day, when the "double witching" of futures and options expiries over on the Liffe futures exchange had a whiplash effect on the underlying cash market.

Trading volume of just under 2bn shares illustrated the fact that it was a busy day.

A particular eye-catcher proved to be Dimension Data , the South African computing group which is headed for the Footsie. The shares jumped by a spectacular 331p to 810p, but it remained unclear how much of this reflected a bout of "rogue" trading on the market's Sets order book.

Just before the close, the stock was trading at around 670p a share, before a sudden series of deals at £10 a share. Followers may find the price falling straight back down again on Monday morning.

Meanwhile, Deutsche Bank managed to rattle the broad hi-tech sector on the London market yesterday, amid reports that it had downgraded Sage, the software group.

It is house broker to the company, so the move was taken seriously elsewhere - although the investment bank's software analyst Kevin Ashton did manage to draw a few chuckles when he was quoted on one of the newswires as saying: "We are brokers to the company but this is not a message from them, this is our own feeling."

Later, it emerged that Deutsche had not actually changed its profit forecasts, but the damage had already been done, with shares in Sage down 48p to 531.5p. Mr Ashton had warned that Sage would struggle to maintain the extraordinary rate of organic growth it has managed in recent times.

The knock-on effect could be seen in rivals Logica , down 62p at £20.52 and Misys , off 29.5p at 635.5p. CMG was a particular casualty among all this, dropping 191p to £12.02.

Lower down the scale within the software sector, DCS slumped 55p to 350p after reporting a disappointing set of interim figures.

Some of the heavier telecom-related issues were hit by waves of selling, leaving the likes of Colt Telecom 98p lower at £21.30 and slicing 94p from Marconi to £10.50. Bookham Technology , meanwhile, gave up 215p to £35.50.

Networking specialist Dataflex issued an upbeat trading statement at yesterday's annual meeting, warning that first half profits would actually beat market expectations.

It has been helped in particular by a big contract to supply call routing equipment to Centrica, the British Gas combine which is now trying to take on British Telecom.

Shares in Dataflex were up 16.5p to 292.5p.

Aquarius , a Hertforshire firm making household products, cited the fuel crisis as it rolled out a warning that full- year profits are going to be significantly below market expectations.

The real problems are at the group's Pine Design subsidiary, where wooden bathroom accessories are manufacturered at Eccleshall, Stafford. It is now under threat. If the plant does close, Aquarius will have to take a hit of £2m.

Meanwhile, the finance director, Mark Bates, has decided to leave the company "for personal reasons". He is to take a new job at a company closer to his home in Stockport.

The shares instantly fell 20p to 76.5p.

fields.headline: Liffe seizes the future
fields.trailText: The Liffe exchange is to introduce the arcane products alongside the stock options which have been part of the dealing scene in the City for years.
fields.body:
Another complicated financial instrument will be added to the share punter's armoury with the arrival of stock futures next year.

The Liffe exchange is to introduce the arcane products alongside the stock options which have been part of the dealing scene in the City for years.

Futures contracts, which have not previously been available because of regulatory restrictions, will allow investors to set the price at which they buy or sell a share at a specified date in the future.

Liffe said yesterday it would list futures not only on British shares but European and US ones too, making it one of the first exchanges to cross national boundaries with share trading.

The futures will be traded on Liffe's electronic trading system.

Trading in the stock futures will also be cleared, settled and guaranteed through the London Clearing House.

fields.headline: At this price?  Baldwins
fields.trailText: Baldwins Industrial Services' share price plunged yesterday following news that full year results would be significantly below market forecasts.
fields.body:
Baldwins Industrial Services' share price plunged yesterday following news that full year results would be significantly below market forecasts.

Analysts at Charterhouse Securities, the house broker, reduced their recommendation from "buy" to "hold". The move followed a company statement that operating profitability in recent months had been "materially below expectations."

The shares ended at 272.5p, down 155p or 36.26%.

The surprisingly weak plant-hire market through 1999 and 2000 accounts for the falling revenues of what analysts had thought was one of the industry's more successful companies. This year's British revenues are about 10% below forecasts, or broadly in line with turnover for the last financial year.

To counter this downturn the company has moved cranes to the US and Venezuela where there are better utilisation rates and margins. Although positive in the long term, having the cranes in transit has hit short-term profits.

The cost of setting up a network of depots and sales offices in the US means that the American unit is not yet profitable but sales are "progressing toward plan," the company says.

These factors have resulted in a missing £2.75m of turnover and a loss of about £1.5m in profits.

Ray Stidwell, Baldwins' finance director, expected the downturn to be short term and said: "The company is in very good shape indeed."

Analysts were slightly more cautious, stating that Baldwins was a company with potential in the UK and America, where the market is huge and highly fragmented, but there would need to be evidence that the company was going to pick up.

Charterhouse Securities yesterday revised its forecasts for pre-tax profits from £9m in 2001 and £10.5m in 2002, to £5.6m for the end of 2001 and £7m for 2002.

The shares are not worth chasing until there are signs the worst is over.

webTitle: Leader: Privatisation of universities an option

fields.headline: What kind of freedom?
fields.standfirst: Universities must declare themselves
fields.trailText: The time has come for vice-chancellors to put up or shut up. For years now they have been blustering about leaving the state behind, privatising themselves and disappearing off into a nirvana of academic freedom where only the best and brightest will enter collegiate gates beyond which chancellors, pursuing elitist demons, will have no say.
fields.body:
The time has come for vice-chancellors to put up or shut up. For years now they have been blustering about leaving the state behind, privatising themselves and disappearing off into a nirvana of academic freedom where only the best and brightest will enter collegiate gates beyond which chancellors, pursuing elitist demons, will have no say.

This week, at their annual conference, they graciously said they would inform the nation at year's end whether they would be "opting out" or "topping up", to use two of the fashionable euphemisms for absconding from a government-supported system.

By accident or design, David Blunkett chose their conference to sharpen the terms of debate about higher education's future. He introduced a package (not "new" money - it was implicit in the July spending announcement) that will make it easier for disadvantaged students to win university places.

By next autumn, only 50% of students will be required to pay the £1,000 contribution to tuition costs introduced by Labour two years ago. Funds for bursaries are increased; parents and children in inner-city areas are to be encouraged to think about staying in education beyond 18.

Of course funding is far from perfect. Even though, for the first time since the mid-80s, public support per student will rise in real terms, Labour still wants expansion on the cheap. Even allowing for a generous allocation for research in the July plan, which inevitably will benefit Imperial, Oxbridge and the research institutions, the government has not fully accepted that academic quality costs more. But the Blair government is now moving in the right direction. And it is time the vice-chancellors returned the compliment.

Nottingham's vice-chancellor is a notable supporter of the "privatisation" option. But, with the rest, it has prospered largely on the back of taxpayer support. With other members of the so called Russell group, Nottingham must now state its position.

If it is saying: end public finance and let us enter a future of rich kids and corporate sponsors - then let it go. But if its claim is public money without public responsibility, David Blunkett must say no. He has other obligations - to institutions providing less glamorous but vital 18-plus education, to students and families with a right to a share of the grants and loans disproportionately reserved till recently for privately educated, middle-class entrants.

webTitle: Durlacher plans joint venture in biotech sector

fields.headline: Durlacher plans joint venture in biotech sector
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Durlacher, the internet investment specialist, is dipping a toe into the life sciences sector through a venture with a German venture capitalist, BMP.
fields.body:
Durlacher, the internet investment specialist, is dipping a toe into the life sciences sector through a venture with a German venture capitalist, BMP.

The group, which yesterday announced a 350% rise in annual profits to £12.2m, said it felt the biotechnology sector had reached a point where it was offering some relatively stable opportunities.

Research director Andy Bottomley said: "Biotech traditionally has been boom or bust, and that's not the way this business operates. I like risk, but I don't like gambling. We've been waiting and watching, and we've chosen a time to have a closer look."

Durlacher and BMP will assemble a team, initially of five people, to "figure out the lie of the land" of biotech and nano-technology - the science of manipulating molecular particles. Mr Bottomley said he expected investments in these areas to begin within months.

Durlacher was among the biggest winners from the boom in internet shares earlier this year. Its profits from stockbroking increased by 66% to £16.9m, while earnings from corporate finance quadrupled to £10.5m.

Chief executive Geoffrey Chamberlain said: "These figures prove our model is inherently profitable."

The group's aim is to build large companies by contribut ing support, expertise and logistics to early stage businesses, as well as investing money. Its successes have included Autonomy and 365 Corporation - although its less lucrative moves have included a stake in Net Imperative, which went into liquidation in May.

Mr Chamberlain believes general sentiment towards e-business is improving: "A number of our companies might have listed over the summer if the market hadn't been so terrible. We're now emerging from a trough of excessive pessimism."

Durlacher's shares rose 1.5p to 113p. They touched 440p at the peak of dot.com euphoria during February.

fields.headline: Fit for humans
fields.standfirst: A new Slough may soon take shape
fields.trailText: There is much to be said for Slough, though few ever say it. It is the home of Thames Valley university. It has very desirable communications, being close to the M4 and London's main airport. Slough is the birthplace of the Mars bar, which over the years has given guilty pleasure to millions.
fields.body:
There is much to be said for Slough, though few ever say it. It is the home of Thames Valley university. It has very desirable communications, being close to the M4 and London's main airport. Slough is the birthplace of the Mars bar, which over the years has given guilty pleasure to millions.

Like many towns along the Great Western Railway, it was home to a high proportion of Welsh people, and so had excellent male voice choirs. It is also handy for superior places like Windsor and Eton, though few in either like to mention their closeness to Slough. But Slough is also habitually traduced. Its name does not help, suggesting despond. Long before John Betjeman was famous, he wrote a hymn of hate, inviting friendly bombs to fall on it.

Slough intends to redeem itself. Much of the town centre, it is reported, is likely to be eliminated and replaced by an ambitious project called Heart of Slough. This, the London Evening Standard reports, "envisages precisely what Betje man called for - the demolition of dreary 50s concrete and metal window-frame buildings, a ramshackle bus and railway station and one of the ugliest traffic roundabouts ever built". This sentence contains a significant error, significant because it reflects the tendency to blame everything ugly in British towns on the 50s and 60s - thus sparing the 30s legitimate blame. Betjeman's poem appeared in a book published in 1937. This was a time in which deeply reprehensible ribbon developments were allowed to spread down arterial roads. Later generations, though they made a wealth of their own mistakes, learned from those of the 30s.

The new Slough, it is said, will have a piazza, huge new office developments and a conference centre. For Slough to cease to be one of Britain's laughing-stock towns, along with Basingstoke and recently Milton Keynes, will be progress. But only so long as it does not end up looking exactly like everywhere else.

I thought the Olympic opening ceremony (Sydney in grip of Olympic security, September 15) was an excellent cultural display of themes drawn from Australia's varied and diverse history both social and natural. It also fully utilised the space it was presented in.

Did anyone notice that it was also remarkably similar artistically to Peter Gabriel's Millennium Dome show? I wonder which will receive the plaudits and which the brickbats?
Fred Garnett
London

fields.headline: 'Pop' culture fights back
fields.trailText: Thank you Melvyn Bragg. We need a new perspective if we're to get out of this intellectual cul de sac (They want us to choose between the Beatles and Beethoven. Can't we have both, September 12).
fields.body:
Thank you Melvyn Bragg. We need a new perspective if we're to get out of this intellectual cul de sac (They want us to choose between the Beatles and Beethoven. Can't we have both, September 12).

When, in the early 20th century, technology first enabled people to record and manipulate sounds and images, a whole world of creative possibility was opened up. The forms that resulted - films, sitcoms, rock albums, photographs, radio and television dramas etc - co-exist alongside cultural forms we inherited from the previous century (the novel, the poem, theatre, painting, notated music).

Think how dramatic a transformation this has been. Culture had previously been about objects (books, paintings, sculptures) which lasted; or events (performances) which were transient, though sometimes based on lasting sets of instructions and conventions (plays, classical scores).

Now its become possible to make something (an album, a film, a TV show) out of performances. New, no longer time-bound, performance skills (sometimes drawing on older traditions - the blues, vaudeville; sometimes creating new ones - rap, screen acting) combine with new skills of audio-visual recording and manipulation (editing, sampling, scoring, cinematography). The end result can be transmitted or distributed across vast distances - shrinking the globe.

No wonder the guardians of culture were and still are baffled or appalled. It's much harder to unravel the complex creative processes, the debt to a variety of traditions and technologies, the performance and creative skills involved in, say, The Cops, or Being John Malkovitch, or Joni Mitchell's Blue, or Massive Attack's Unfinished Sympathy, than it is to consign them all to the ephemeral status of "popular culture".

So here are a few more planks for the manifesto. First, it is inconceivable that a century of endeavours by people to be creative with recorded sounds and images will have produced nothing of cultural worth. Second, yes, most technology-based culture is collaborative by nature and often produced in a commercial context - but this does not debase an Astral Weeks or Citizen Cane to any greater extent than a system of patronage debases John Donne or Michelangelo.

Third, new cultural forms based on the recording and manipulating of sounds and images must be understood on their own terms. A song is not a poem, a photograph not a painting, a television drama not a theatre play. Fourth, the way new forms work on us through the moment by moment impact of sounds and images make different, not lesser demands on us. In my opinion the densely woven musical and linguistic textures of Astral Weeks are easily as "difficult" as the structures of countable rhythms, fixed pitches and harmonic architecture in Wagner.

Fifth, we tolerate a double standard whereby some cultural forms are dismissed as 90% dross, whilst others are valued in terms of their most feted achievements. Turn this on its head and Jimmy McGovern and Dennis Potter redeem TV drama, while the novel is dragged to oblivion by Mills and Boon, and the poem cursed by the greeting card industry.

Finally, why in Britain, where our achievements in "popular" music and TV are outstanding, do we demean them by surrendering the critical debate to the elitists and egocentric relativists. Lets consign them all to a permanent loop of the Keats v Dylan Late Show debate and start celebrating - and exploring - all dimensions of our vibrant culture.
Paul Clarke
Cardiff

fields.headline: Old buffers
fields.trailText: I am told John Sutherland has attacked my book, The New Elites, in terms of its author's age (G2, September 2) - a new criterion of criticism which is all the more surprising since Sutherland, I would guess, is even more ancient than me.
fields.body:
I am told John Sutherland has attacked my book, The New Elites, in terms of its author's age (G2, September 2) - a new criterion of criticism which is all the more surprising since Sutherland, I would guess, is even more ancient than me.

Could it be that the old gent was irritated by the following passage? "An evasive or insinuating stance towards pop is frequent amongst writers and intellectuals. When Salman Rushdie published a book about rock singers, The Ground Beneath Her Feet, accompanied by a pop CD, the critics were divided; those in favour often acclaimed the book for what one suspects were not purely literary reasons." Sutherland published a gushing review of the book. He clearly recognised himself as an example of the ingratiating, youth-worshipping new establishment bufferdom I had in mind.
George Walden
London
