fields.headline: Mullally suffers further blow
fields.standfirst: England must name a replacement after a sneeze puts paid to Alan Mullally's chances of making Pakistan
fields.trailText: England must name a replacement after a sneeze puts paid to Alan Mullally's chances of making Pakistan.
fields.body:
An England tour replacement for the injured Alan Mullally will be named on Monday, after official confirmation yesterday that the cracked rib which the Hampshire seamer aggravated by sneezing has also ruled him out of next month's one-day series in Pakistan in addition to the ICC Trophy in Kenya.

"We must avoid, for all parties concerned, that Alan returns to action too quickly before adequate rest," said the England and Wales Board chairman of selectors David Graveney. Mullally is still in the party to tour Sri Lanka next March.

With the County Championship Second Division promotion race hardly getting its head above the water yesterday, the two berths still available look like being decided by contrived finishes today - weather and wet turf permitting.

In Cardiff, the wooden spoonists Middlesex were the only team to hold a bat and Glamorgan had the misfortune to find the visitors' best players, Mark Ramprakash and Justin Langer, barring the way to crucial extra bowling points.

In Bristol, where both Gloucestershire and Nottinghamshire need a win to have any chance of a top-three promotion place, the sodden outfield may rule out even a run-chase today. The home side are due to resume their first innings on 73 for one in reply to 216.

Worcestershire's coach Bill Athey has all but given up hope of promotion after being confined to the pavilion for the second day in a row against the division's already promoted champions Northamptonshire at New Road.

There is little hope of conjuring up a result on the last day and Athey admitted: "We really needed a couple of batting bonus points as well as a win. Our chances are receding by the minute."

Prospects of a win already looked flimsy with five wickets down for only 50 when they replied on Wednesday to a first innings total of 260.

Hampshire, already relegated from the First Division, may yet have insult and pitch points-deduction added to injury despite the washout at Southampton. Sixteen wickets fell on the first day and another 10 before tea on the second to mar Hampshire's 565th and last first-class match at the County Ground.

Mike Denness, chairman of the ECB's "pitches advisory committee" was called in on Thursday and has summoned Raman Subba Row and Chris Wood from Lord's to help him examine the wicket.

webTitle: Spurs agree to let Walker walk on

fields.headline: Spurs agree to let Walker walk on
fields.standfirst: Walker wants out, Bosnich stays put and the Smith flak enters a second day. Those are the stories
fields.trailText: Walker wants out, Bosnich stays put and the Smith flak enters a second day. Those are the stories
fields.body:
Ian Walker's 12-year career at Tottenham looks to be over after the former England goalkeeper had a written transfer request accepted yesterday. The 28-year-old asked for a move after losing his place to Neil Sullivan, who joined from Wimbledon during the summer. He has not played for the first team this season.

"We understand his frustration at his lack of first-team opportunities at the moment," said Tottenham's director of football, David Pleat.

"Ian's form last season was excellent and by bringing in Neil Sullivan, it increased the competition at the club. We now have two top-class goalkeepers and we are perhaps victims of that situation."

Mark Bosnich, another out-of-favour goalkeeper, yesterday turned down a loan move from Manchester United to Middlesbrough.

Bosnich was approached after Mark Schwarzer broke a thumb in a training accident and would have played at Manchester City today.

But his manager Sir Alex Ferguson explained: "He says he's not in a position to go. He doesn't feel right to go on loan at the moment." Boro, who will lose Schwarzer for about six weeks, have borrowed Gary Walsh from Bradford instead.

Meanwhile, Ferguson is resigned to losing Jaap Stam for up to two months after doctors advised the Holland defender he needs an operation on a recurring achilles problem. Stam has been pencilled in to have surgery if and when United have completed the second group stage of the Champions League.

"It would be a good time to get it cleaned out in December," Ferguson said. "That would probably mean Jaap being out for around seven weeks but it might be worth doing."

Swindon's match at home to Cambridge today has been called off because of the fuel crisis, but the weekend's football is otherwise expected to go ahead as planned.

Swindon postponed their game because they could not guarantee enough stewards would be available. The Premiership's sponsors Carling have laid on free coaches to help Newcastle, Derby and Ipswich fans reach their away matches.

The Leeds striker Alan Smith has come in for more criticism from Barcelona. Phillip Cocu claims Smith put him out for up to fortnight with a two-footed challenge. "He looks at the opponent more than he does the ball," said Cocu, whose team-mate Frank de Boer described Smith as "mean and nasty".

The Leeds captain Lucas Radebe has been ordered to rest by a neurologist after suffering headaches since he was concussed in Barcelona on Wednesday. He will miss today's game against Ipswich and almost certainly Tuesday's at home to Milan.

Steve Walsh, 35, has joined Norwich from Leicester. The move reunites the defender with the Norwich manager Bryan Hamilton, who signed him for Leicester 14 years ago.

Red Star Belgrade have appealed against the decision to move their Uefa Cup first-round, second-leg tie against Leicester to a neutral venue.

Aston Villa's Luc Nilis is likely to have a fourth operation on his fractured leg in the next month.

The former Wolves striker John Richards has severed his links with the club after resigning from the board.

webTitle: What Big Al could teach Mr Tony

fields.headline: What Big Al could teach Mr Tony
fields.standfirst: Alan Shearer's popularity knows no boundaries, apparently. Well, except for the River Tyne
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer's popularity knows no boundaries, apparently. Well, except for the River Tyne.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer has often been keen to tell us that football is a matter of records, not popularity polls. Which is just as well, as this week, in a snap poll conducted by the Football365 website, Shearer was voted the most-loathed footballer in the country. England's least-favourite sheetmetal worker's son (as we can now officially call him) scooped an untouchable 35% of the vote.

He was a clear 11 points ahead of Gianluca Vialli's big chum Frank Leboeuf (who won the World Cup, apparently) and scooped twice as many votes for unpopularity as Roy Keane.

Moreover, scoring two goals in Euro 2000 makes a player significantly more unpopular than giving away a crucial penalty, as Phil Neville was reckoned the most loathsome player in the game by only 2% of those sampled.

And, unless Victoria is very quick with the mouse and voted early and often, David Beckham's reign as public enemy No1 is long over: he barely registered with a feeble 1% of the vote. Worse, there is no point in Shearer comforting himself that it was just one or two rogue Sunderland fans distorting the sample.

The opinion polls that confidently told us that the Prime Minister's popularity rating in the country has dropped by 20 percentage points over the past week of queues and blockades, are constructed asking no more than 1,500 people at a time. Football365's survey involved an astonishing 40,000 voters.

But then you have to wonder whether the 365 people asked the wrong question. By restricting the survey merely to players, they missed the opportunity to register the fans' distaste for a man whose every action within the game deserves contempt.

Whatever the statistical evidence, in a week in which he showed once again that the men who run the game have little to learn from the players by way of appalling, disloyal and shameless behaviour, step forward Ken Bates, surely the most hateful man in English football.

fields.headline: Kelly shows up Rovers weakness
fields.standfirst: Sheffield United 2 - 0 Blackburn Rovers
fields.trailText: Sheffield United 2 - 0 Blackburn Rovers
fields.body:
They say never go back, and on this evidence they are clearly right. Sheffield United strolled past Blackburn Rovers last night, thanks to a freakish early goal which will give the former Blades goalkeeper Alan Kelly nightmares.

Paul Devlin's stunning second goal, coming in the wake of a glaring miss from the Rovers substitute James Thomas after his team-mate Nathan Blake had hit a post, consigned the pre-season First Division promotion favourites to their second defeat in four days.

Rovers started the week unbeaten but after a soddy and shambolic display on a miserable night in south Yorkshire they seem to have lost their way. Their manager Graeme Souness described it as "a nightmare" and added: "We gifted them a goal and felt sorry for ourselves for the rest of the first half. We were naive and outmuscled."

That gift of a goal came in the fifth minute when Henning Berg's sloppy back-pass put his goalkeeper under pressure. As Alan Kelly tried to make up for a laboured first touch, in nipped his namesake David Kelly: the attempted clearance ricocheted off him and into the open net from the acutest of angles.

It was United's first goal for more than five hours, but as much laughter as celebration erupted in the stands, which echoed to a chorus of "There's only one Alan Kelly". Afterwards the home manager Neil Warnock could not contain his admiration, saying: "You've seen what we're made of here tonight. It was the best performance by a team of mine in 20 years as a manager."

He can hardly have seen many worse displays by opponents, though. Blackburn were clueless, missing the attacking invention of the injured Matt Jansen up front and any semblance of composure in their defence.

The partnership of Berg, on loan from Manchester United, and Martin Taylor, whose leaden-footed display suggested he was often stuck in the Bramall Lane mud, was given a torrid time by Marcus Bent, who volleyed wide and then headed Devlin's cross wastefully over the bar. As the conditions worsened so did Rovers' predicament. In the 25th minute Devlin, comfortable in possession but apparently heading nowhere as he moved across the edge of the area, exploded a shot from 20 yards into Kelly's top corner.

The cheers had barely died down from that when Bent had a goal disallowed for apparently nudging Taylor, and Rovers' only effort of note was a David Dunn free-kick skied horribly into the Kop.

At least by the time the beleaguered Taylor was substituted early in the second half, Damien Duff had tested Simon Tracey with a curling effort, hinting at a Rovers revival. Blake, another Blades old boy given a chilly welcome, was denied soon afterwards, and Kaba Diawara's clever interchange with Dunn saw Tracey save twice from point-blank range.

The French striker then shot tamely from Berg's header across goal, and Blake fizzed an effort inches wide.

But while United were struggling to rekindle their earlier impetus, surrendering possession too easily, the visitors' soft underbelly was almost exposed for a third time. Alan Kelly's weak punt was volleyed over by Michael Brown on the hour, and David Kelly should have added his second before the end - first heading and then volleying wide.

Souness was left praying that agreement can be reached with the French club St Etienne to seal the £7m transfer of their defender Lucien Mettomo.

Mettomo, a Cameroon international, is currently absent without leave from his club. At times last night Souness must have thought his current lot of defenders had followed suit.

The partnership of Berg, on loan from Manchester United, and Martin Taylor, whose leaden-footed display suggested he was often stuck in the Bramall Lane mud, was given a torrid time by Marcus Bent, who volleyed wide and then headed Devlin's cross wastefully over the bar. As the conditions worsened so did Rovers' predicament. In the 25th minute Devlin, comfortable in possession but apparently heading nowhere as he moved across the edge of the area, exploded a shot from 20 yards into Kelly's top corner. The cheers had barely died down from that when Bent had a goal disallowed for apparently nudging Taylor, and Rovers' only effort of note was a David Dunn free-kick skied horribly into the Kop. At least by the time the beleaguered Taylor was substituted early in the second half, Damien Duff had tested Simon Tracey with a curling effort, hinting at a Rovers revival. Blake, another Blades old boy given a chilly welcome, was denied soon afterwards, and Kaba Diawara's clever interchange with Dunn saw Tracey save twice from point-blank range. The French striker then shot tamely from Berg's header across goal, and Blake fizzed an effort inches wide. But while United were struggling to rekindle their earlier impetus, surrendering possession too easily, the visitors' soft underbelly was almost exposed for a third time. Alan Kelly's weak punt was volleyed over by Michael Brown on the hour, and David Kelly should have added his second before the end - first heading and then volleying wide. Souness was left praying that agreement can be reached with the French club St Etienne to seal the £7m transfer of their defender Lucien Mettomo. Mettomo, a Cameroon international, is currently absent without leave from his club. At times last night Souness must have thought his current lot of defenders had followed suit.

webTitle: They're out to get me, says Francis

fields.headline: They're out to get me, says Francis
fields.standfirst: Despite Birmingham getting off to a flyer, there's still a cloud hanging over St Andrews. Adrian Milledge finds out why
fields.trailText: Despite Birmingham getting off to a flyer, there's still a cloud hanging over St Andrews. Adrian Milledge finds out why.
fields.body:
Petrol in the tank permitting, Trevor Francis should enjoy a relaxed journey in the team coach when his Birmingham City side head for the Hawthorns in search of their fifth successive win tomorrow.

Bet on it, though, at your peril. If Francis is to be believed, the witch-hunt that had just begun when he and his players made the same Sunday morning trip three seasons ago has not been called off.

"Francis to be sacked and club captain Steve Bruce to take over," the City manager read in his Sunday newspaper. His mood, already gloomy after a run of 13 league games that had yielded only one win, blackened further.

A fortnight ago, after City's first win at Nottingham Forest for 38 years, the reappearance of the "Bruce to succeed" tale substantiated Francis's claims that the witch-hunt was still in full cry. It was too much for City's multimillionaire co-owner David Sullivan, especially as football's rumour mill had alleged that his associate Barry Silkman was behind the so-called campaign.

"I would describe Trevor's reaction as paranoia," he said. "Like any other manager in the Football League or the Premiership, he's nine games away from the sack. And if he's worried about a witch-hunt then he should name names."

Francis reacted by demanding a clear-the-air meeting at Sullivan's Essex mansion; a meeting that ended with a peace-in-our-time statement - until, that is, the next time.

And there will be a next time. "I m sure we'll read similar stuff again before the season's out," confirmed the left-back Martin Grainger. "Those who've been here for a while have simply got used to it."

Forget Midlands-produced soaps such as Crossroads and the Archers, the region has its own real-life one at St Andrews thanks to the combustible mix of its two leading men. The fans' hero Francis appears to favour well placed leaks to get his way, in contrast with the blunderbuss style of Sullivan. He says what he thinks when he thinks it, and, when Francis wanted to buy Lee Bradbury from Portsmouth, was not afraid to block the deal.

Imagine the Manchester United chairman doing the same; imagine Sir Alex Ferguson standing for it. Yet for football's version of the Odd Couple such apparent disharmony works. City were the second best supported club in the First Division last season with crowds of 20,000-plus watching them qualify for the play- offs for the second successive year. Currently lying fourth, they are on course to do so again and, as a bonus, by playing the most attractive football seen at St Andrews for years.

The arrival from Sheffield Wednesday of the Northern Ireland midfielder Danny Sonner, who should be fit to play today after a groin injury, and Francis's efforts to get his side playing with more style have not taken long to show an effect.

Neither has the arrival of Gary Megson as manager of West Bromwich Albion. Having masterminded First Division survival by a whisker last season, Megson has made Albion a tougher nut to crack and tomorrow there should not be a repeat of the 3-1 and 3-0 humiliations City have handed out on their last two visits.

Coincidentally, last year's drubbing was followed a couple of days later by the Albion manager Brian Little's departure. His crime? Alleging boardroom interference, intrigue and no money to spend. Witch-hunt or not, Francis, who has spent more than £9m on players, could be a lot worse off.

webTitle: Mad dog finds his bite on Merseyside

fields.headline: Mad dog finds his bite on Merseyside
fields.standfirst: Thomas Gravesen has picked up the Premier pace in no time, says Roy Collins
fields.trailText: Thomas Gravesen has picked up the Premier pace in no time, says Roy Collins.
fields.body:
Thomas Gravesen is clearly a self-confident young man. Either that or the two months of sharing a dressing room with Paul Gascoigne are already beginning to have an effect. Not waiting for any introductions, he playfully bounds across the training- ground car park , pumps your hand and announces : "So, I'm the Everton new boy."

His astonishingly cultured performances for his side this season would appear to give the lie to his newness. So effortlessly has he adjusted to Premiership football that one would think he had been around as long as Gazza. Perhaps this has something to do with the fact that he has spent many of his 24 years studying English football and dreaming of playing in it.

He seemed ready to make the leap three years ago before leaving his home town Danish club Vejle for Hamburg. But on catching a glimpse of himself in a full- length mirror he decided he was a bit too Kate Moss, a bit short of muscles and light of weight to compete. Since then he has added just over two stone and weighs in at a more model English footballing size of 13st 9lb.

"English football is much faster, stronger and more physical than in Germany, though just as good technically," the 24-year-old says. "So I felt I needed to be stronger before coming here, though I still thought it would take me much longer to adjust."

He started as a sweeper with Vejle but showed his midfield intelligence for Denmark against Holland and France in Euro 2000. He was also voted one of the best foreign players in Germany by Kicker magazine, by which time Everton's manager Walter Smith was already preparing a bid for him.

Smith bought him for £2.5m after first selling Everton to him. Gravesen says: "He told me all his plans, all his dreams for Everton and why this was the club that I had to come to. So I just had to say yes."

True to his down-to-earth style, Smith did not weave a vision of championship glory this season, followed by the FA Cup and next season's Champions League. He spoke merely of the continuing progress he expects from the side he is rebuilding at Goodison Park. Having worked beneath similar scaffolding at Hamburg, Gravesen was impressed by the outline.

"It took us three years at Hamburg to become a top-five team," he says. "Here at Everton we have a lot of good players but we are just getting to know each other's ways. I am hoping only that we are a top- 10 side this season and in three years' time that we might be pressing for a Champions League place."

It did not take long for Gravesen to get used to one player's ways. Even before he arrived he discovered that the former England star had circulated a rumour that Everton fans had nicknamed him Mad Dog. "Gazza is always clowning around but no one gets angry. It is good to have that sort of atmosphere at a club."

They used to say that about the Wimbledon Crazy Gang, though on the field at Everton it is not Gazza but Gravesen who has provided the most imaginative input, capping a virtuoso performance against Derby with his first goal for the club. His accurate passing has also provided young Francis Jeffers with the openings to present a flurry of goals as his downpayment on a future England career.

Far from acting like a mad dog, Gravesen has yet to see a yellow card waved in his face after four matches. And he has already become a favourite of fans who, reared on the holy trinity of Harvey, Ball and Kendall, are particularly fond of a creative midfield player.

At present, Premiership life is beautiful for Gravesen, who is prepared to risk the scorn of his former colleagues in Germany when he says: "This is the best league in the world. Everything you want is here and every match you play in is so exciting. In Germany, when you play at the smaller clubs it is sometimes not that exciting but here the atmosphere is always fantastic."

He may sometimes crave for the less frenetic pace in the Bundesliga, which allows for a breather with a session of keep-ball. But he certainly does not miss the diving, which he believes is reaching the point where fans are being put off.

Everton fans, naturally, cannot wait for this afternoon's encounter with Manchester United at Goodison Park which, says Gravesen, will give his side a realistic indicator as to their chances of improving on last season's 13th place. It is, he says, the team's biggest game of the season.

One would have thought he would have singled out next month's derby game at Liverpool for that. But, again betraying the Gazza influence, he insisted he had no idea when the fixture was. "I was too scared to look," he said.

fields.headline: Ranieri ready for Chelsea egos
fields.standfirst: Three-year deal hooks former Fiorentina and Atletico Madrid coach, reports  Martin Thorpe
fields.trailText: Three-year deal hooks former Fiorentina and Atletico Madrid coach, reports Martin Thorpe
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri, who was spotted in the stand making copious notes during Chelsea's Uefa Cup tie with St Gallen on Thursday, has been handed the task of writing a new chapter in the club's history.

Chelsea moved swiftly to fill the managerial vacancy caused by Tuesday's sacking of Gianluca Vialli, replacing an Italian with an Italian. But there the similarity ends.

The 48-year-old Ranieri, who has signed a three-year contract, will not be known as manager, but as head coach, an acknowledgement of his specific area of skills. It is hoped that he will bring a studious approach to the coaching art - more Wenger than Vialli.

He has also taken on some big egos in the boardroom - and dressing-room - and won. It will be surprising if player-power features in his eventual departure. For wherever he has worked, Ranieri has earned huge respect. The only slight worry for the Chelsea purists is that he does have a reputation for playing something of a long-ball game.

Chelsea first approached him on Monday, before Vialli was actually sacked. He was invited to Stamford Bridge and in two days of talks impressed the Chelsea hierarchy with his scholarly love of the game and convinced them of the heights they can reach under his leadership.

A long list of the great and the good applied for the job, but all along Chelsea seemed to have eyes for only one man. "If there are roses, they will bloom," he said before yesterday's talks. They did.

After wrapping up the formalities yesterday, Ranieri is understood to have briefly returned to Italy before he flies back for Chelsea's game against Leicester tomorrow. He will be there as a spectator before formally taking up the reins on Monday.

"He will only be concentrating on the first-team squad, the coaching and the tactics," said Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson. "The administration will be solely handled at the training ground, as far as the team is concerned, by Gwyn Williams, who is termed assistant manager." Ranieri has been promised money to bring in his own players but may have to sell as well.

Few people in Britain will have heard of the Italian. But in Spain and Italy, this snappy dresser is well known, and well respected. Various top clubs in each of those leagues have been eyeing him of late.

Ranieri has never won a league title of the Champions League, which must be what Chelsea want him to do for them, but he has never had the resources or the time with which to do so. The Valencia team that reached this year's European Cup final was, however, based on that he left behind just over a year ago.

Indeed it was his time at Valencia that first caught Hutchinson's eye. Two years ago they beat Barcelona three times in a week and he was impressed.

"I watched all three games on TV. Two were in the cup and one in the league. I kept thinking that Louis van Gaal would come up with something different against Valencia but Claudio Ranieri got the better of him on each occasion.

"I spent three hours with him before the Uefa Cup game against St Gallen, talking about football. I wanted to know about his philosophy on the game and his ideas."

Once again Ranieri impressed. And another advantage is that most of Chelsea's continental players know him. Gianfranco Zola actually played under him at Napoli and no doubt offered a fine testimonial. Ranieri brought Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink to Atletico Madrid last season, where the Dutchman scored 24 goals in a side that was relegated.

Almost everywhere Ranieri has reigned, he has brought success. As a moderate midfielder he was briefly on Roma's books before winning promotion with Catanzaro, Catania and Palermo. As coach he took Cagliari from Serie C to Serie A is successive seasons. He then briefly joined Napoli, taking over Fiorentina in 1993. There he won promotion to Serie A, plus the Italian Cup and domestic Super Cup. He also managed to survive four years under the outspoken chairman Vittorio Cecchi Gori.

From there to Valencia, where he started with a few problems. Ranieri's dislike of prima donnas immediately put him in conflict with the Argentine international Ariel Ortega, who would saunter back from international call-ups at his own pace. Ranieri's response was short and sharp, and Ortega soon fell into line.

Then there was Romario. When Ranieri made known his views on the Brazilian striker's habit of disco-dancing until 4am two days before a match, Romario told him to mind his own business.

"In my private life I do what I like," he said the disco king, "and whoever doesn't like it can get stuffed. If I don't go out, I don't score." Ranieri's response was immediate. He sold Romario back to Brazil.

In his second season, Ranieri took Valencia to fourth and a Champions League place, and won the Spanish Cup. But soon he was tempted by Atletico. That move fell apart when the unpredictable owner Jesus Gill went to jail. He wanted Ranieri to stay but the receivers said no.

So Ranieri found himself out of a job. Until Chelsea called. He is an intellectual thinker about coaching and tactics - he often plays 4-4-2 but is not rigid - as well as the treatment of players. He knows who needs the carrot and who the stick.

He will make his first tactical task sorting out the defence. He will also instil a high work ethic on the pitch. At Fiorentina he angered the fans by regularly dropping Rui Costa, whom he deemed a luxury. Chelsea said when they sacked Vialli that they needed a change of direction. It has arrived.

Real Madrid's Brazilian winger Savio insisted yesterday that he wanted Chelsea, who have expressed interest, to decide one way or the other over any bid.

Emperor Claudio

1986-1987 Vigor Lamezia

Takes first managerial post, aged 35

1987-1988 Campania

1988-1991 Cagliari

Honours: Serie C1 champions 1989, first of two successive promotions

1991-1993 Napoli

Finishes 4th and 11th in Serie A

1993-1997 Fiorentina

Honours: Champions of Serie B 1994; Italian Cup and Supercup winners 1996

1997-1999 Valencia

Honours: Earned Champions League place and won Spanish Cup 1999

1999-2000 Atletico Madrid

Resigns after 26 games with Atletico doomed to relegation
